webTitle: Are you voting in Romania's election?
trailText: If youâre taking part in Romaniaâs election on Sunday weâd like to hear from you
headline: Are you voting in Romania's election?
standfirst: If youâre taking part in Romaniaâs election on Sunday weâd like to hear from you
body:
Related: 'I voted for a safe choice': readers on the Romanian election

The centre-left PSD party in Romania is set to win the most seats in Sunday<83><82><82><82><84>s election as people go to the polls to elect a new government. However, they<83><82><82><82><84>re expected to fall short of a majority leaving it open to a coalition with a rival party.

Despite the dominant party of Romanian politics topping recent polls, the Union Save Romania, a new party, founded barely six months ago to fight the corruption, cronyism and inefficiency in the country, could spoil the celebrations.

If you<83><82><82><82><84>re voting in the election we<83><82><82><82><84>d like you to share your thoughts. You can fill in the form below <83><82><82><82><80><9c> anonymously if you wish <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and we<83><82><82><82><84>ll use a selection of responses in our reporting.

webTitle: Romania v Poland suspended after flare explodes near Robert Lewandowski
trailText: The World Cup qualifier in Bucharest between Romania and Poland was suspended on Friday after a flare thrown from a stand exploded near the Bayern Munich striker Robert Lewandowski
headline: Romania v Poland suspended after flare explodes near Robert Lewandowski
standfirst:
â¢ Group E match held up for 10 minites after incident
â¢ Lewandowski recovered to score Polandâs second goal
body:
Kamil Grosicki scored a brilliant solo goal and Robert Lewandowski netted twice to give Poland a 3-0 win over Romania in a World Cup qualifier marred by crowd trouble on Friday.

Poland moved top of the group after the game at the National Arena in Bucharest was spoiled by crowd violence that forced the Slovenian referee, Damir Skomina, to interrupt the game on two occasions.

Unbeaten Poland lead Group E with 10 points from four matches, followed by Montenegro on seven. Montenegro suffered their first defeat in the group, squandering a two-goal lead to lose 3-2 in Armenia.

Grosicki collected the ball in the centre circle, weaved his way past five Romania defenders and gave the keeper, Ciprian Tatarusanu, no chance with a powerful shot for his ninth international goal after 11 minutes.

Vlad Chiriches came closest to scoring for the home side when Poland<83><82><82><82><84>s keeper, Lukasz Fabianski, parried his close-range effort in the 32nd minute.

Lewandowski almost doubled Poland<83><82><82><82><84>s lead when his curling free-kick went just wide soon after the break. The Bayern Munich striker, however, made amends seven minutes from time when he put the result beyond doubt with a cool finish.

Lewandowski completed the rout when he converted a penalty in stoppage time for his seventh goal in the qualifying campaign.

The match was interrupted for a minute at the end of the first half after fans threw flares and firecrackers on to the pitch.

The ugly scenes continued early in the second half when Lewandowski fell to the ground but escaped unhurt after a firework, thrown by home supporters, landed near the striker. The referee temporarily stopped the match and Lewandowski returned to the game several minutes later.

Romanian police detained six Polish fans for violence before the game. In addition to that, Bucharest police have questioned 17 football fans after clashes at the World Cup qualifier on Friday.

Police fired tear gas before the Group E match, with fans throwing flares on the pitch during the game. Police said 12 Poles and five Romanians were taken for questioning, with 12 fined for the clashes. The nationalities of the 12 fined were not disclosed.

Romania, who lost for the first time under their German coach, Christoph Daum, are fourth in the standings with five points.

Montenegro suffered their first defeat in the group, squandering a two-goal lead to lose 3-2 in Armenia. webTitle: Romania set to go to polls as anti-graft party eyes kingmaker role
trailText: Centre-left PSD set to fall short of majority, with Union Save Romania poised to step in as junior partner in new coalition
headline: Romania set to go to polls as anti-graft party eyes kingmaker role
standfirst: Centre-left PSD set to fall short of majority, with Save Romania Union poised to step in as junior partner in new coalition
byline: Jon Henley European affairs correspondent and Kit Gillet in Bucharest
body:
Romanians go to the polls on Sunday to elect a government, with the centre-left PSD party projected to win the most seats but fall short of a majority, leaving it vulnerable to a rival coalition involving a new anti-corruption party.

After a year of cautious caretaker rule by technocrats since massive street protests over the deaths of 64 people in a Bucharest nightclub fire forced the former PSD regime from power, the dominant party of Romanian politics has topped all recent polls.

But a new party, the Save Romania Union (USR), founded barely six months ago to fight the corruption, cronyism and inefficiency endemic in Romanian public life since the overthrow of the Ceau<83><86><82><84>escu dictatorship in 1989, could spoil the celebrations.

Related: 'I voted for a safe choice': readers on the Romanian election

Polls have credited the USR, led by the mathematician and former civic activist Nicu<83><86><82><84>or Dan, with between 8% and 19% of the vote, which could make it the junior partner in a new coalition with the centre-right PNL, on 18-27%, perhaps lined up behind the outgoing caretaker prime minister, Dacian Ciolo<83><86><82><84>.

A survey last week put the Social Democrats <83><82><82><82><80><9c> who have governed the country in assorted coalitions for 17 of the 27 years since the fall of communism <83><82><82><82><80><9c> on 43% of the national vote, with their liberal ALDE allies on 6%.

PSD, which has promised to boost social spending and reintroduce progressive taxation in place of an unpopular flat-rate income tax, won more than half the posts in June<83><82><82><82><84>s mayoral elections in towns and villages around the country, and has a clear organisational advantage.

<83><82><82><82><93>They are an extremely powerful political machine,<83><82><82><82><9d> said one analyst, Cristian P<83><80><9e><82><92>tr<83><80><9e><82><92><83><80><82>coniu. <83><82><82><82><93>They have half the mayors in Romania, three-quarters of the county councils, and a robust structure of power across the country.<83><82><82><82><9d>

PSD had already begun reversing hugely unpopular austerity programmes before it was forced to resign in October last year after being blamed for the years of official graft and inaction that many Romanians felt lay behind the nightclub fire.

Romania, an enthusiastic EU member for a decade and a major recipient of EU funds, remains one of Europe<83><82><82><82><84>s most corrupt countries: a report by the IPP thinktank last week found that of the 588 MPs elected at the last poll in 2012, 89 <83><82><82><82><80><9c> or 15% <83><82><82><82><80><9c> were either under investigation for graft, had already been convicted, or chose to step down for other positions.

Related: Book 'em: the loophole undermining Romania's anti-corruption drive

Whichever party wins on Sunday must walk a budgetary tightrope. Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s economy is growing strongly at about 5% year on year, but average take-home pay is low at barely <83><82><80><9a><82>420 (<83><80><9a><82>353) a month.

The incoming government will need to find a way to balance an urgent need for investment in neglected infrastructure against huge popular pressure for increases to wages and pensions.

Ciolo<83><86><82><84>, a former EU agriculture commissioner who has led the country<83><82><82><82><84>s technocratic government for the past 12 months, told Reuters last month that the next government should first approve a new public sector wage scheme aimed at evening out major inequalities and raising average wages by 34%.

Other top priorities were encouraging young Romanian medical graduates to stay in the country (there are now more Romanian doctors in France than in Romania), and encouraging teachers and other public sector employees to move to some of the country<83><82><82><82><84>s most disadvantaged areas, Ciolo<83><86><82><84> said.

The PSD leader, Liviu Dragnea, has said he plans to prepare 200 state-owned companies for privatisation, boost the national minimum wage, introduce tax incentives for families whose children attend school regularly, and invest heavily in the national health service, including a big new teaching hospital in Bucharest and eight new regional centres.

But Ciolo<83><86><82><84> warned all parties against making unsustainable promises that he said would inevitably end up increasing voter resentment and fuelling populism. <83><82><82><82><93>Many parties are making some of the same economic policy proposals and promises they made four, eight years ago that have not been enforced,<83><82><82><82><9d> he said.

<83><82><82><82><93>It is clear they are unrealistic proposals that aim to get people<83><82><82><82><84>s attention and votes. In the future, parties need to do more to boost the trust of voters who want Romanian society and institutions to reform.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The man who may make up the numbers

Dan, a 46-year-old mathematician and conservation activist turned party leader, hopes Sunday<83><82><82><82><84>s parliamentary elections will represent a turning point for the country<83><82><82><82><84>s political scene.

Polls suggest his USR party could take a significant share of the vote, its message of greater governmental accountability and transparency striking a chord in a country beset by political scandals, corruption and a lack of confidence in traditional parties.

The party is tiny <83><82><82><82><80><9c> it has just 15 paid staff and a few thousand volunteers <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but has big ambitions. <83><82><82><82><93>We believe we can be kingmakers,<83><82><82><82><9d> Dan told the Guardian recently. <83><82><82><82><93>If not, we will be the opposition.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Related: Reclaiming the streets ... for cars? Why Bucharest is reining in outdoor events

The mathematics researcher at the Romanian Academy, whose profile has risen on the back of regular TV and media appearances, has twice run for mayor of Bucharest. In 2012, Dan stood as an independent on a narrow platform of preserving historic buildings and defending green spaces from urban developers, winning 8.5% of the vote. This year, as the head of a party he founded called the Save Bucharest Union, and running on a broader anti-corruption platform, he finished second with more than 30% of the vote.

The USR, whose candidates include academics, people from the private sector and a handful of former ministers, hopes to provide a strong new political voice. <83><82><82><82><93>This is the first authentic grassroots movement that has the chance to breach parliament,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Tudor Benga, an e-commerce entrepreneur and USR candidate for the Transylvanian city of Brasov.

<83><82><82><82><93>They can get seats,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Alina Mungiu-Pippidi, a Romanian political scientist, who thinks 10% is an attainable target. <83><82><82><82><93>There is sheer desperation among many voters. People don<83><82><82><82><84>t know USR, but there is an anti-system mood in Romania and people are willing to overlook the makeshift nature of the party.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The party says it intends to back Ciolo<83><86><82><84>, the independent politician who took over as interim prime minister in November 2015, and the party<83><82><82><82><84>s success in part depends on this gamble. <83><82><82><82><93>We could have a selfish approach, saying we are against all other political parties, that they are all corrupt and the same, which they<83><82><82><82><84>re not, and we could probably get more seats,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Dan, who balances charisma with the cautious studiousness of an academic. Supporting Ciolo<83><86><82><84> would lead to the best outcome for Romania, he added.

<83><82><82><82><93>We can<83><82><82><82><84>t compete with the main parties at the level of structure, that<83><82><82><82><84>s obvious, but there has been a wait for a change in society, and I think we are the party [people] have been waiting for,<83><82><82><82><9d> he said. Kit Gillet

webTitle: UK 4G coverage worse than in Romania and Peru, watchdog finds
trailText: National Infrastructure Commission says UK is being held back by poor mobile connectivity and calls for end to âdigital desertsâ
headline: UK 4G coverage worse than in Romania and Peru, watchdog finds
standfirst: National Infrastructure Commission says UK is being held back by poor mobile connectivity and calls for end to âdigital desertsâ
body:
Britain<83><82><82><82><84>s 4G mobile phone coverage is worse than that in Albania, Panama, Peru and Romania, with users able to connect barely half the time, a government infrastructure watchdog has found.

In a major new report, the National Infrastructure Commission said the UK is being held back by poor mobile phone connectivity, as it called for an end to <83><82><82><82><93>digital deserts<83><82><82><82><9d> in places that should have adequate signals such as rail routes, roads and city centres.

Countries including the US and Japan already have data volumes four to five higher than the UK, the report found.

The commission, chaired by Andrew Adonis, the crossbench peer and former Labour minister, said the government must now ensure that the next generation of 5G spectrum does not have the failures that dog 4G coverage.

<83><82><82><82><93>Britain is 54th in the world for 4G coverage, and the typical user can only access 4G barely half the time,<83><82><82><82><9d> Adonis said. <83><82><82><82><93>Our 4G network is worse than Romania and Albania, Panama and Peru. Our roads and railways can feel like digital deserts and even our city centres are plagued by not spots where connectivity is impossible.

<83><82><82><82><93>That isn<83><82><82><82><84>t just frustrating, it is increasingly holding British business back as more and more of our economy requires a connected workforce.<83><82><82><82><9d>

In a list of recommendations, it argued there should be a new dedicated cabinet minister in charge of the UK<83><82><82><82><84>s digital future, ensuring mobile connectivity is competitive with the rest of the world.

On top of that, it called for ministers and Ofcom, the media regulator, to work together to ensure a set of standards known as a universal service obligation no later than 2025.

The crucial priorities for coverage are key rail routes, major roads such as motorways and all towns and cities, Adonis said.

<83><82><82><82><93>5G is the future <83><82><82><82><80><9c> ultra-fast and ultra-reliable, it has the potential to change our lives and our economy in ways we cannot even imagine today. But the UK is currently languishing in the digital slow lane,<83><82><82><82><9d> he added.

<83><82><82><82><93>5G offers us a chance to start again and get ahead. If government acts now we can ensure our major transport networks and urban centres are 5G ready in time to give British industry every chance to lead the world in exploiting its applications.

<83><82><82><82><93>But none of this will matter unless we bring our mobile network up to speed. The existing system does not provide the level of coverage we will need in our connected future. We need a new universal service obligation which ensures that the mobile essentials <83><82><82><82><80><9c> like text, talk and data <83><82><82><82><80><9c> are available to us wherever we need them.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Grant Shapps, the former Tory chairman who now leads the British Infrastructure Group of MPs, said the report should be a wakeup call for the government, as he accused them of being too willing to listen to the excuses of mobile phone operators about poor signal.

<83><82><82><82><93>This confirms what we have been saying for a long time. Over the years, ministers have been far too easy on the glib promises given by the telecoms providers and I think that has been combined with ineffective and weak regulation from Ofcom,<83><82><82><82><9d> Shapps said.

<83><82><82><82><93>Britain cannot afford to repeat the outcome of the 5G network that we have had with the 4G network and so the British Infrastructure is calling on the prime minister to appoint a cabinet minister to oversee the recommendations of this report and make sure this person is accountable for delivering 5G throughout the UK.

Related: UK 4G coverage is worse than in Peru. We need a minister for the internet | Charles Arthur

<83><82><82><82><93>Unfortunately there has been a very long history of believing what the telecoms companies say rather than questioning it. The fact the report was commissioned is a good thing but Britain should be all about infrastructure in this post-Brexit world and here is a real wake-up call to make sure it actually happens this time.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The National Infrastructure Commission was established last year by George Osborne, the then chancellor, to advise the government on critical challenges related to the UK<83><82><82><82><84>s networks such as transport, telecommunications, energy and utilities.

5G networks are not expected to become available until 2020 but Ofcom has already begun preparations for auctioning off the spectrum.

The round of 4G auctions raised less than Osborne had hoped for in 2012 and much of the UK is still plagued with <83><82><82><82><93>not spots<83><82><82><82><9d> of poor signal.

In a recent report backed by 90 MPs from all parties, the British Infrastructure Group proposed an amendment to the government<83><82><82><82><84>s digital economy bill to allow Ofcom to fine mobile operators that did not meet the targets of a 2014 agreement.

That deal gave the four large network operators (MNOs) another chance to fix mobile <83><82><82><82><93>not spots<83><82><82><82><9d> after they said they would pump <83><80><9a><82>5bn into improving coverage across the UK by December 2017 in return for the government not pursuing a system of national roaming.

BIG said it found little evidence to suggest that the mobile sector would meet the targets of this agreement to provide coverage to 90% of the UK<83><82><82><82><84>s geographic area, and called for a progress update to be published by the end of 2016.

Romania scored an early penalty but could not defend their slender lead and Admir Mehmediâs 57th minute equaliser meant the points were shared

body:
7.15pm BST

Here<83><82><82><82><84>s the match report from the game:

Related: Admir Mehmedi crashes home to rescue point for Switzerland against Romania

6.53pm BST

That<83><82><82><82><84>s it from me. Join Jacob Steinberg for all the action from France v Albania here (where Pogba and Griezmann have been dropped):

Related: France v Albania: Euro 2016 <83><82><82><82><80><9c> live!

Updated at 6.59pm BST

6.52pm BST

Well, Switzerland were disappointing there. For a team with such potential, they looked blunt in attack - though Embolo was certainly an upgrade on Seferovic - and short of ideas in midfield, where Xhaka and Shaqiri failed to shine.

Romania achieved exactly what they set out to achieve: not to lose. That<83><82><82><82><84>s a first point on the board for them and a win over Albania could see them into the knock-outs. See all the permutations here:

Related: Euro 2016 interactive wallchart: groups, fixtures, venues and more

Updated at 7.01pm BST

6.50pm BST

FULL TIME

Xhaka finds Embolo, who runs at the Romania defence. In his desperation to find an opening, he bulldozes Grigore and earns a yellow card. And that, more or less, is that. Full time.

6.49pm BST

90 min +2: Xhaka lifts a free kick to Land on the left wing, who sends a cross into the area. Goal kick. A minute to go.

6.48pm BST

90 min: Keseru wriggles and twists in the centre of the pitch, desperately trying to hang onto the ball and to keep it from marauding Swiss midfielders. He<83><82><82><82><84>s clipped to the ground when the marauding Swiss midfield get sick of that sort of thing. Shaqiri is hauled off - and has been a bit disappointing - Everton<83><82><82><82><84>s Tarashaj replaces him. Three minutes added time.

6.45pm BST

88 min: Lichsteiner and Lang combine very neatly up the Swiss left wing. Lang clips a good cross into the area that would have destined for Embolo<83><82><82><82><84>s head and, then, the back of the neck had Tatarusanu not climbed well to claim.

6.44pm BST

87 min: Schar concedes a corner and Romania send forward a fair few men. They<83><82><82><82><84>re not taking this draw yet. Chiriches jumps but a Swiss defender beats him to the ball, a good solid clearance.

6.42pm BST

85 min: Free kick to Switzerland 20 metres outside the Romania box. Rodriguez lifts the ball in, the Swiss big men pile in to get on the end of it, Romania clear it with ease.

For anyone concerned about the Germany manager<83><82><82><82><84>s nether regions:

Related: Joachim L<83><92><82>w says sorry for causing a stir with scratch and sniff

6.41pm BST

84 min: Lichsteiner, who has pushed forward now that Lang is playing right back, plays a nice ball into Embolo. The Swiss striker leans on Grigore ever so delicately and the Romanian defender hits the deck. Hmm.

Updated at 6.48pm BST

6.40pm BST

83 min: For Switzerland, Lang replaces Dzemaili to bolster the Swiss defence. For Romania, Stancu - who has just take a knock - is replaced by Andone.

6.37pm BST

80 min: That said, Hoban plays an incisive ball into Torje in the Swiss area. All he had to do was trap it and shoot, but his touch is very heavy and Romania concede possession. They look tired and are struggling even more than normal to keep hold of the ball.

6.35pm BST

78 min: Perhaps chastened by that volley, Dzemaili opts not to shoot when he finds himself with the ball in the D. He attempts a pass to Shaqiri but the Romania defence clear. Switzerland are all over Romania at the moment, with the Romanians puffing hard.

6.34pm BST

76 min: Shaqiri blasts the free kick into the wall, it bounces back for Mehmedi, and he wafts a tame shot at Tatarusanu. A moment or two later, Dzemaili attempts to lash a first time volley at goal from a ball ballooned over his head. The result is not pretty. His manager stands on the touchline shaking his head ruefully.

Updated at 6.44pm BST

6.32pm BST

75 min: Grigore flattens Embolo just outside the Romania box, when the striker was nearly in the clear. Free kick to Switzerland, yellow card to Grigore. Fourth Romania yellow.

6.32pm BST

74 min: Switzerland heap more pressure on Romania. Mehmedi lurks on the Swiss left, then clips a delicious ball high across the area. It goes over Embolo and finds Shaqiri unmarked. Unfortunately, it is behind him and he attempts an outrageous bicycle kick, with the ball ballooning off his shin and high over the goal. Oh.

Updated at 6.39pm BST

6.30pm BST

73 min: Embolo is nearly clear again - though may have been offside - and Tatarusanu has to race out from his goalline to intercept the long through ball from Mehmedi. Embolo is certainly causing more problems than Seferovic.

<83><82><82><82><93>For a game I thought would be a purists<83><82><82><82><84> delight, this has been pretty entertaining stuff. I wouldn<83><82><82><82><84>t say it<83><82><82><82><84>s of stunning quality, but fun goes a long way,<83><82><82><82><9d> reckons K<83><92><82>ri Tulinius, who is right.

6.28pm BST

71 min: Embolo tries to wiggle free in the Romania area but for all his power, his touch is a little agricultural. He knocks the ball so far past Chiriches it goes out for a goal kick.

6.27pm BST

69 min: That<83><82><82><82><84>s always good to see. Romania win a free kick that is virtually in their own half (I exaggerate). Torje sends all the big men into the box, then lashes the ball a full 5,000 yards at goal. Somner has to dive sharply to his left to save his dipping, thunderous drive. There<83><82><82><82><84>s something about an outrageously optimistic free-kick in a European Championship that is just a lot of fun to watch.

6.25pm BST

68 min: Lichsteiner swishes another good cross into the Romania area, taking two defenders out of the game. Embolo gets up to head it in, but catches the ball too fine and it goes out for a kick.

Updated at 6.34pm BST

6.24pm BST

67 min: Dzemaili is in an acre of space in the Romania half. He pauses, then plays a lovely through ball to Embolo who breaks at speed. He can<83><82><82><82><84>t do much with the pass though, so Switzerland head backwards and keep control in the Romania half. They<83><82><82><82><84>re in control at the moment.

You heard this here third:

6.21pm BST

65 min: Hoban hoists a good ball into Keseru - or Kerazoo, as Andy Townsend is calling him on ITV - and he has a free header at goal, which he does not make the most of.

Updated at 6.38pm BST

6.20pm BST

64 min: Seferovic is finally put out of his misery. That<83><82><82><82><84>s his second poor game in a row. Switzerland replace him with the 19-year-old Embolo, a fast, effective and physically imposing striker who probably should have started (he<83><82><82><82><84>ll score an own goal now).

6.18pm BST

60 min: That<83><82><82><82><84>s the end of Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s Razvan Rat. He<83><82><82><82><84>s replaced by Filip, 13 years his junior and approximately 110 caps less experienced.

6.16pm BST

58 min: Shaqiri stands over a ball 10 yards outside the Romania box, having won the free-kick by being flattened while dribbling at pace at the area. He takes a few steps back then clobbers a left-foot shot at goal. It<83><82><82><82><84>s a yard too high.

6.15pm BST

57 min: That was a netbuster from Mehmedi, a thunderous left-foot thrash into the opposite corner. Oof. Breel Embolo was about to come on for Switzerland, had taken his tracksuit off, done his warm-up and then that goal went in. He<83><82><82><82><84>s now sat back down.

6.13pm BST

GOAL! Romania 1-1 Switzerland (Mehmedi, 55)

Mehmedi pulls a ball back across the Romania area to Seferovic, stationary on the penalty spot. The ball is tapped behind for a corner <83><82><82><82> and from it Mehmedi rams the ball home from 15 yards! Powerful strike.

Updated at 6.20pm BST

6.10pm BST

53 min: Switzerland take their turn to attack as the game comes alive - Dzemaili thinks about rifling in a shot but instead crosses. Probably the wrong option and Romania can clear.

6.09pm BST

52 min: Torje toddles up the left wing, with Rodriguez in close attendance. Somehow Torje wangles a throw-in despite being the last man to touch the ball before it goes out. Romania spend the next minute or so flinging dangerous crosses into the area, with Switzerland worriedly clearing them. Finally Torje flings in the most dangerous of the lot and Djourou somehow slides in, two feet from the goal, and hoofs it wide when it looked for all the world like he was going to score an own goal.

Updated at 6.17pm BST

6.07pm BST

50 min: Xhaka gets in a tangle with the ball and is robbed by Sapunaru. In his haste to get the ball back, Xhaka goes in on the Romanian man, who hits the deck. Xhaka is shown a yellow card, but replays suggested Sapunaru simply trod on the Swiss player and hit the deck.

Updated at 6.16pm BST

6.06pm BST

48 min: But Switzerland aren<83><82><82><82><84>t letting Romania have it all their own way. Xhaka lurks outside the Romania box, looking for all the world like he is about to fire a long-range rasper at goal. Instead, he plays a diagonal ball to Shaqiri, who tears into the box but fires his shot into Chipciu<83><82><82><82><84>s leg. Corner. Which is wasted.

Updated at 6.14pm BST

6.04pm BST

47 min: Romania have started brightly, and Torje attempts to race past the Swiss left back Rodriguez. Had he managed it, he would have had a simple pull back to Keseru. But he didn<83><82><82><82><84>t.

6.03pm BST

46 min: Hoban immediately gets a chance. Stancu carves out an opening in the Swiss box, lays the ball off to the new man and he rasps an outside of the boot shot wide of SOmner<83><82><82><82><84>s goal. That was probably the best chance Romania have had all match in open play.

6.02pm BST

PEEP PEEP!

We<83><82><82><82><84>re off again: Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s Hoban replaces Pintilii, who was injured at the end of the first half.

6.01pm BST

David Mooney emails in about St Pauli<83><82><82><82><84>s spectacular move: <83><82><82><82><93>I hope this trend catches on and when Arsenal sign their next twinkle-toed number 10, Arsene comes out for the unveiling in full Lordi regalia.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Weird fact: I once interviewed Lordi in their full Lordi regalia. A little bit of behind the scenes knowledge for you: those costumes absolutely stink. Like proper, proper hum.

5.58pm BST

Here<83><82><82><82><84>s the latest from the Press Association on events in Lille:

Police in Lille have used tear gas on fans following scuffles in the city centre. Supporters were seen running through the streets before officers attempted to disperse them by firing the gas into the crowds. Fans from England, Wales, Slovakia and Russia have been gathering in the city for Group B matches between the countries.

5.56pm BST

Kevin Porter emails: <83><82><82><82><93>ITV commentator: <83><82><82><82><9c>Maybe if you are brought up in an neutral country, you lack aggression<83><82><82><82><84>. Really, where do they recruit these people from, the past? Can the standard of commentary drop any lower?<83><82><82><82><9d> Stay tuned to this here commentary on the Guardian, Kevin, and you may well find out.

5.54pm BST

There<83><82><82><82><84>s a lovely snippet from Jonathan Wilson about Romanian football in this Knowledge column from a few year<83><82><82><82><84>s back: scroll down to the 11th paragraph (begins <83><82><82><82><93>But there<83><82><82><82><84>s more. Jonathan Wilson points us towards etc etc<83><82><82><82><9d>) for a fabulous tale about how Chinese whispers and rampant corruption caused a side to beat another 9-0 thanks to some extravagant extra time.

Related: The Knowledge | Which teams have played for the wrong result? | John Ashdown

5.48pm BST

Some half-time reading for you all, courtesy of Tom Davies

Related: Golden Goal: Ilie Dumitrescu for Romania v Argentina (1994) | Tom Davies

5.48pm BST

Well, Romania have had no possession and seem intent on protecting their lead before mounting the odd counterattack via Chipciu. Switzerland need a new striker and they need Shaqiri to turn up as, increasingly, they<83><82><82><82><84>re getting panicky around the box.

5.47pm BST

PEEP PEEP!

Schar concedes a corner, Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s first of the afternoon. They take it short and then lift the ball to the far post before a Swiss head knocks it behind for Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s second. That one is hoiked in and Seferovic heads it clear. With that, it<83><82><82><82><84>s half-time.

5.45pm BST

45 min: Stancu sells Djourou a dummy and goes past him. Somner, in the Swiss goal, thinks about coming and Stancu<83><82><82><82><84>s eyes light up but Schar is there to clear things up. Nearly a good breakaway move from Romania.

5.44pm BST

43 min: Romania have had almost no possession and could not care less about that. Switzerland pass the ball through them, carving another chance for Seferovic who heads the ball at goal but the Romania keeper claims.

5.42pm BST

41 min: Mehmedi breaks clear in the Romania area and rifles a shot from a tight angle. Chiriches dives in and blocks the ball before it gets further than six inches from Mehmedi<83><82><82><82><84>s boot. Switzerland do very little with the corner, and Romania break but, instead of waiting for more numbers, they blare a shot high and wide over Somner<83><82><82><82><84>s goal.

5.40pm BST

38 min: Pintilii has taken a knock and the Romanian physio applies some magic spray. When play restarts, Romania are lucky not to concede. Lichsteiner is played in up the right wing and clips a wonderful ball back across the area. Behrami is clear in the box and powers a header wide of the posts. Had that been on target - and it should have been, given the quality of the ball and the space Behrami had - it would have been 1-1. Poor from Switzerland.

Updated at 5.52pm BST

5.37pm BST

36 min: Keseru pulls Behrami to the ground for no good reason: yellow card.

5.36pm BST

35 min: The dangerous Chipciu breaks clear down the Romania left again, leaving Schar for dust this time but playing a poor ball into the box. He sets up a Romania attack though, with the ball fizzing about the Swiss box, until eventually a ballooning ball lands in Somner<83><82><82><82><84>s hands. Switzerland don<83><82><82><82><84>t like Romania running at them, as Corporal Jones might have said.

Updated at 5.41pm BST

5.35pm BST

34 min: Corner to Switzerland, who are beginning to look a little tense. Rodriguez lifts an outswinger into the box but Xhaka can<83><82><82><82><84>t get a big enough portion of his head onto the ball. Goal kick.

5.33pm BST

31 min: Dzemaili pokes a good ball through to Seferovic, but does so under heavy attention from Pintilii. The referee decides Pintilii<83><82><82><82><84>s attentions are a little unfair and blows for a foul just outside the D. Rodriguez lines it up, firing the ball at Tatarusanu<83><82><82><82><84>s right hand post. The keeper was there to claim though.

Meanwhile in Lille

Updated at 5.38pm BST

5.30pm BST

28 min: In Lille, trouble is brewing between the England and Russia fans:

5.29pm BST

27 min: Shaqiri has a nibble at Prepelita, conceding a free-kick on the left wing. The ball is launched into the box and the Swiss defence are all over the place. Sapunaru, on the penalty spot, has a chance and smashes a shot which clips the right hand upright and goes out.

5.26pm BST

25 min: Chipciu races clear up the Romanian left, leaving Lichsteiner for dust. He cuts inside, makes room for the shot and can<83><82><82><82><84>t quite wrap enough of his foot around the ball to bend the ball past Somner. He looks dangerous.

The Swiss fans know how to tailgate party:

Related: Euro 2016 picture of the day <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Swiss start with a fondue

5.24pm BST

23 min: Oof 2: And that<83><82><82><82><84>s another thumping challenge: Chipciu clatters Lichsteiner and earns himself yellow too. Shaqiri delivers a good ball into the near post but Seferovic - who is fast having a shocker - can<83><82><82><82><84>t get a decent header on it.

Meanwhile, Swiss anthem-gate rumbles on:

5.22pm BST

22 min: Oof: that<83><82><82><82><84>s a challenge. Prepelita slides into the back of Xhaka who goes down in a crumpled heap. Yellow card for the Romania midfielder.

Updated at 5.33pm BST

5.21pm BST

21 min: Switzerland are nearly level. Schar is a long way out but looks up and aims a howtizer at the Romania goal. Tatarusanu has to tip the ball over the bar as it dips and swerves towards the back of the net. Switzerland waste the corner.

5.20pm BST

19 min: The referee had no option but to award that: Chipciu was twisting, turning and wriggling his way through the Swiss defence. Lichsteiner had a fistful of his shirt and eventually the Romania midfielder simply had to hit the deck. Completely fair enough.

5.18pm BST

GOAL! Romania 1-0 Switzerland (Stancu, 18, pen)

A very cool low shot into the bottom left corner. His second penalty of the tournament.

Updated at 5.24pm BST

5.18pm BST

PENALTY!

Chipciu fights his way into the Swiss box but is tugged down by Lichsteiner.

Updated at 5.28pm BST

5.16pm BST

15 min: Shaqiri plays Seferovic in, the striker lurching into the box with the goal at his mercy. He draws back his foot, he takes aim, then he tickles the ball gently into the Romania keeper<83><82><82><82><84>s hands. How many chances does he need?

Updated at 5.22pm BST

5.14pm BST

12 min: It<83><82><82><82><84>s all Switzerland at the moment, and Lichsteiner finds himself with time and space to whip a cross in, shortly after Dzemaili had a chance to shoot but instead clipped the ball across the face of goal (to nobody). Switzerland<83><82><82><82><84>s problem so far is that their buildup has been solid but there<83><82><82><82><84>s been nobody in the box to hit with the ball.

5.12pm BST

10 min: Dzemaili wriggles free on the outskirts of the Romania box and whips a cross in, which is headed behind for a corner. Shaqiri hoofs the corner into the box and Tatarusanu punches clear.

5.10pm BST

9 min: Romania concede a pretty unnecessary foul, granting Switzerland a free-kick high up their left wing. Rodriguez hoists the ball into the box and all the Swiss big men launch themselves at the ball and - unfortunately for them - the Romanian players. Foul: goal kick.

Updated at 5.12pm BST

5.09pm BST

8 min: Prepelita fizzes a cross into the Swiss box and Chipciu nods it on. Unfortunately, he nods it to Somner, who catches the ball with ease.

5.07pm BST

7 min: Seferovic takes a pass on the edge of the Romania box, breaking free of Chiriches. He was wasteful against Albania, and this is another chance he sends begging - whistling the ball past the keeper<83><82><82><82><84>s left-hand post. Still, it was nice wriggling work to fashion the chance in the first place.

<83><82><82><82><93>Razvan Rat played a pivotal role in my hugely successful Macclesfield side in Football Manager,<83><82><82><82><9d> reports Ian Copestake. <83><82><82><82><93>But that was back in the day before employers stopped allowing people to play it at work. So is Rat slow because he is very old or has the world changed since I lost that job?<83><82><82><82><9d> Because he is very old.

Updated at 5.12pm BST

5.05pm BST

5 min: Lichsteiner takes the ball to the byline and whips a cross over to Seferovic and Mehmedi in the box. His cross is too high, however, and Romania clear.

5.04pm BST

3 min: Seferovic flattens Prepelita in the centre circle, and looks guiltily at the ref. The ref doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t give a flying one, however, so Switzerland attack, jagging the ball about between themselves outside the Romanian box. Eventually, things open up for Xhaka and he whistles a deflected shot at goal. Tatarusanu saves comfortably.

5.01pm BST

1 min: So much for Romania not attacking much. From the throw-in, they charge up the right via Torje, who crosses for Kerseru but Djourou just gets enough on the ball to deny the Romanian striker.

5.01pm BST

PEEP PEEP

We<83><82><82><82><84>re off: Switzerland, in red shirts and white shorts kick off and attack from left to right. The ball immediately goes out for a throw-in to Romania, who are all in yellow.

Updated at 5.08pm BST

4.59pm BST

<83><82><82><82><93>Afternoon Tom,<83><82><82><82><9d> chirps Simon McMahon. <83><82><82><82><93>Is it still possible for Scotland to qualify for the round of 16 with no points?<83><82><82><82><9d>

4.57pm BST

The Romanians are here now, fortunately. Anthem time: Switzerland go first: conservative, sombre, like a businesslike grey suit.

Romania follow: stirring, brooding stuff. Sing along at home.

4.53pm BST

Right, back to the game: the teams are in the tunnel - well, the Swiss are, the Romanians are still in the changing room. The Romanian mascots are lined up, however, perhaps they<83><82><82><82><84>ll do?

4.51pm BST

Charity begging bowl: the Guardian<83><82><82><82><84>s Michael Butler is going on a charity bike ride in aid of Addenbrooke<83><82><82><82><84>s Hospital in Cambridge: this minute-by-minute entry is the equivalent of somebody shaking a bucket at you. Dig deep, dig often.

4.48pm BST

Re. Oliver<83><82><82><82><84>s poser as 16.28, here<83><82><82><82><84>s Gordon Smith: <83><82><82><82><93>You can qualify with one point. If the points in a group end 9,6,1,1 and at least three groups end this way then at least one of them will qualify for the last 16.<83><82><82><82><9d>

What a format!

4.40pm BST

Just in case you haven<83><82><82><82><84>t seen it, this - by quite some distance - is the football story of the day:

Related: St Pauli manager misses unveiling of new signing, so club use man in mask

4.34pm BST

<83><82><82><82><93>Well, if Rat doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t have the legs to chase Shaqiri around all day, at least the Romanians have a spare Lung on the bench,<83><82><82><82><9d> honks Justin Kavanagh. Honk!

4.32pm BST

In answer to Oliver, below, then yes: if every team in a group won one, lost one and drew one each side would finish with four points. The group would be settled on goal difference - so one side would go out as the fourth placed side with four points. It<83><82><82><82><84>s entirely conceivable that a side in another group could finish with three points and go through. I think, but I<83><82><82><82><84>m simple folk.

4.28pm BST

One for the hive mind: <83><82><82><82><93>I<83><82><82><82><84>ve just been looking at my wallchart at work trying to figure something out,<83><82><82><82><9d> emails Oliver, who works in the sort of place where they<83><82><82><82><84>re allowed to look at wallcharts while at work. <83><82><82><82><93>Is it at all possible that a team in fourth place in one group could have a better record than a team in third place in another, but that third place team make it through to the last 16?<83><82><82><82><9d>

4.25pm BST

Catch up on what happened at the Stade Pierre Mauroy, with Jamie Jackson<83><82><82><82><84>s report: Russia 1-2 Slovakia (spoiler alert<83><82><82><82>)

Related: Marek Hamsik<83><82><82><82><84>s sumptuous strike gives Slovakia the edge over Russia

4.18pm BST

In the buildup to the match - it<83><82><82><82><84>s worth giving our interactive guide to the teams and players another look:

Related: Euro 2016: the complete guide to every squad and every player in France

4.08pm BST

Romania have stuck by Razvan Rat, whose lack of pace was put to the test by France. He<83><82><82><82><84>ll be up against Shaqiri this afternoon, which ought mean another tricky day at the office for him. Filip, who might have replaced Rat, remains on the bench.

4.06pm BST

Team news

Romania: Tatarusanu, Sapunaru, Chiriches, Grigore, Rat, Prepelita, Pintilii, Torje, Stancu, Chipciu, Keseru.

Subs: Pantilimon, Matel, Moti, Hoban, Alibec, Stanciu, Andone, Gaman, Filip, Sanmartean, Popa, Lung.

Switzerland: Sommer, Lichtsteiner, Schar, Djourou, Rodriguez, Behrami, Xhaka, Shaqiri, Dzemaili, Mehmedi, Seferovic.

Subs: Hitz, Moubandje, Elvedi, von Bergen, Lang, Embolo, Frei, Zakaria, Fernandes, Tarashaj, Derdiyok, Burki.

Referee: Sergei Karasev (Russia)

Updated at 4.32pm BST

12.24pm BST

Preamble

On the surface, this does not have thrills and spills written all over it. Romania - doughty against France in the opening match of the tournament - conceded just two goals in the qualifiers but in their last five competitive fixtures have scored just five goals (three of them against Faroe Islands, one of them from the penalty spot against France). Switzerland, for their part, made a very good start against Albania, scoring inside the first five minutes, then struggled to keep it up for the rest of the match. So, what we<83><82><82><82><84>ve got here is: team who defend well but don<83><82><82><82><84>t score very much v team that struggled to score against minnows.

That said, Switzerland should score. Just look at the talent available to them. Granit Xhaka is a maestro, Xherdan Shaqiri has scored four and made five goals in his last eight competitive matches. At some point, surely the team have to live up their perennial tag of dark horses and go on a run. Victory here would mean they would be the first team to go into the knockout stages.

There are a few ructions in their squad at the moment though: Shaqiri has threatened to ditch Switzerland for the newly Uefa-recognised Kosovo, particularly if the side offer him the captaincy that Switzerland have not. He<83><82><82><82><84>s been doing his bit for team morale by talking about that in the buildup to this match which is good of him.

Romania will be set up to frustrate and perhaps rightly so. A draw here, then victory over Albania could well see them safely into the knockout stages as one of the best third-placed teams. Their coach, Anghel Iordanescu has just about said as much too: <83><82><82><82><93>We have to be realistic; we have to understand that we<83><82><82><82><84>ll be playing against a very good side. Their 23 players play in big leagues like the Bundesliga. Our objective is to qualify from the group.<83><82><82><82><9d> Romania took confidence from their performance against France, despite their disappointment at conceding a late Dimitri Payet winner, and they will be determined not to lose this one too.

There is some historic needle to the match too. These two teams met in their second match at the 1994 World Cup finals when, under Roy Hodgson, the Swiss beat Romania 4-1 in Detroit. Romania recovered to win the group and went through to the quarter finals (courtesy of the delicious Hagi), though, and Switzerland went home in the round of 16. Three years earlier, Romania beat Switzerland in qualifying for Euro 92, meaning they failed to qualify for the tournament and Scotland got in. So that<83><82><82><82><84>s some 22 year old needle right there.

Let<83><82><82><82><84>s enjoy Romania at the 1994 World Cup all over again, courtesy of Rob Smyth via the link below:

Updated at 3.52pm BST
text: 7.15pm BST Heres the match report from the game:  Related: Admir Mehmedi crashes home to rescue point for Switzerland against Romania   6.53pm BST Thats it from me. Join Jacob Steinberg for all the action from France v Albania here (where Pogba and Griezmann have been dropped):  Related: France v Albania: Euro 2016  live!  Updated at 6.59pm BST  6.52pm BST Well, Switzerland were disappointing there. For a team with such potential, they looked blunt in attack - though Embolo was certainly an upgrade on Seferovic - and short of ideas in midfield, where Xhaka and Shaqiri failed to shine. Romania achieved exactly what they set out to achieve: not to lose. Thats a first point on the board for them and a win over Albania could see them into the knock-outs. See all the permutations here:  Related: Euro 2016 interactive wallchart: groups, fixtures, venues and more  Updated at 7.01pm BST  6.50pm BST Xhaka finds Embolo, who runs at the Romania defence. In his desperation to find an opening, he bulldozes Grigore and earns a yellow card. And that, more or less, is that. Full time.  6.49pm BST 90 min +2: Xhaka lifts a free kick to Land on the left wing, who sends a cross into the area. Goal kick. A minute to go.  6.48pm BST 90 min: Keseru wriggles and twists in the centre of the pitch, desperately trying to hang onto the ball and to keep it from marauding Swiss midfielders. Hes clipped to the ground when the marauding Swiss midfield get sick of that sort of thing. Shaqiri is hauled off - and has been a bit disappointing - Evertons Tarashaj replaces him. Three minutes added time.  6.45pm BST 88 min: Lichsteiner and Lang combine very neatly up the Swiss left wing. Lang clips a good cross into the area that would have destined for Embolos head and, then, the back of the neck had Tatarusanu not climbed well to claim.  6.44pm BST 87 min: Schar concedes a corner and Romania send forward a fair few men. Theyre not taking this draw yet. Chiriches jumps but a Swiss defender beats him to the ball, a good solid clearance.  6.42pm BST 85 min: Free kick to Switzerland 20 metres outside the Romania box. Rodriguez lifts the ball in, the Swiss big men pile in to get on the end of it, Romania clear it with ease. For anyone concerned about the Germany managers nether regions:  Related: Joachim Lw says sorry for causing a stir with scratch and sniff   6.41pm BST 84 min: Lichsteiner, who has pushed forward now that Lang is playing right back, plays a nice ball into Embolo. The Swiss striker leans on Grigore ever so delicately and the Romanian defender hits the deck. Hmm. Updated at 6.48pm BST  6.40pm BST 83 min: For Switzerland, Lang replaces Dzemaili to bolster the Swiss defence. For Romania, Stancu - who has just take a knock - is replaced by Andone.  6.37pm BST 80 min: That said, Hoban plays an incisive ball into Torje in the Swiss area. All he had to do was trap it and shoot, but his touch is very heavy and Romania concede possession. They look tired and are struggling even more than normal to keep hold of the ball.  6.35pm BST 78 min: Perhaps chastened by that volley, Dzemaili opts not to shoot when he finds himself with the ball in the D. He attempts a pass to Shaqiri but the Romania defence clear. Switzerland are all over Romania at the moment, with the Romanians puffing hard.  6.34pm BST 76 min: Shaqiri blasts the free kick into the wall, it bounces back for Mehmedi, and he wafts a tame shot at Tatarusanu. A moment or two later, Dzemaili attempts to lash a first time volley at goal from a ball ballooned over his head. The result is not pretty. His manager stands on the touchline shaking his head ruefully. Updated at 6.44pm BST  6.32pm BST 75 min: Grigore flattens Embolo just outside the Romania box, when the striker was nearly in the clear. Free kick to Switzerland, yellow card to Grigore. Fourth Romania yellow.  6.32pm BST 74 min: Switzerland heap more pressure on Romania. Mehmedi lurks on the Swiss left, then clips a delicious ball high across the area. It goes over Embolo and finds Shaqiri unmarked. Unfortunately, it is behind him and he attempts an outrageous bicycle kick, with the ball ballooning off his shin and high over the goal. Oh. Updated at 6.39pm BST  6.30pm BST 73 min: Embolo is nearly clear again - though may have been offside - and Tatarusanu has to race out from his goalline to intercept the long through ball from Mehmedi. Embolo is certainly causing more problems than Seferovic. For a game I thought would be a purists delight, this has been pretty entertaining stuff. I wouldnt say its of stunning quality, but fun goes a long way, reckons Kri Tulinius, who is right.  6.28pm BST 71 min: Embolo tries to wiggle free in the Romania area but for all his power, his touch is a little agricultural. He knocks the ball so far past Chiriches it goes out for a goal kick.  6.27pm BST 69 min: Thats always good to see. Romania win a free kick that is virtually in their own half (I exaggerate). Torje sends all the big men into the box, then lashes the ball a full 5,000 yards at goal. Somner has to dive sharply to his left to save his dipping, thunderous drive. Theres something about an outrageously optimistic free-kick in a European Championship that is just a lot of fun to watch.  6.25pm BST 68 min: Lichsteiner swishes another good cross into the Romania area, taking two defenders out of the game. Embolo gets up to head it in, but catches the ball too fine and it goes out for a kick. Updated at 6.34pm BST  6.24pm BST 67 min: Dzemaili is in an acre of space in the Romania half. He pauses, then plays a lovely through ball to Embolo who breaks at speed. He cant do much with the pass though, so Switzerland head backwards and keep control in the Romania half. Theyre in control at the moment. You heard this here third:  @TomBry Embolo is the future! Went to school with him, amazing player. Will lead the Swiss to victory!  6.21pm BST 65 min: Hoban hoists a good ball into Keseru - or Kerazoo, as Andy Townsend is calling him on ITV - and he has a free header at goal, which he does not make the most of. Updated at 6.38pm BST  6.20pm BST 64 min: Seferovic is finally put out of his misery. Thats his second poor game in a row. Switzerland replace him with the 19-year-old Embolo, a fast, effective and physically imposing striker who probably should have started (hell score an own goal now).  6.18pm BST 60 min: Thats the end of Romanias Razvan Rat. Hes replaced by Filip, 13 years his junior and approximately 110 caps less experienced.  6.16pm BST 58 min: Shaqiri stands over a ball 10 yards outside the Romania box, having won the free-kick by being flattened while dribbling at pace at the area. He takes a few steps back then clobbers a left-foot shot at goal. Its a yard too high.   6.15pm BST 57 min: That was a netbuster from Mehmedi, a thunderous left-foot thrash into the opposite corner. Oof. Breel Embolo was about to come on for Switzerland, had taken his tracksuit off, done his warm-up and then that goal went in. Hes now sat back down.  6.13pm BST Mehmedi pulls a ball back across the Romania area to Seferovic, stationary on the penalty spot. The ball is tapped behind for a corner  and from it Mehmedi rams the ball home from 15 yards! Powerful strike. Updated at 6.20pm BST  6.10pm BST 53 min: Switzerland take their turn to attack as the game comes alive - Dzemaili thinks about rifling in a shot but instead crosses. Probably the wrong option and Romania can clear.  6.09pm BST 52 min: Torje toddles up the left wing, with Rodriguez in close attendance. Somehow Torje wangles a throw-in despite being the last man to touch the ball before it goes out. Romania spend the next minute or so flinging dangerous crosses into the area, with Switzerland worriedly clearing them. Finally Torje flings in the most dangerous of the lot and Djourou somehow slides in, two feet from the goal, and hoofs it wide when it looked for all the world like he was going to score an own goal. Updated at 6.17pm BST  6.07pm BST 50 min: Xhaka gets in a tangle with the ball and is robbed by Sapunaru. In his haste to get the ball back, Xhaka goes in on the Romanian man, who hits the deck. Xhaka is shown a yellow card, but replays suggested Sapunaru simply trod on the Swiss player and hit the deck. Updated at 6.16pm BST  6.06pm BST 48 min: But Switzerland arent letting Romania have it all their own way. Xhaka lurks outside the Romania box, looking for all the world like he is about to fire a long-range rasper at goal. Instead, he plays a diagonal ball to Shaqiri, who tears into the box but fires his shot into Chipcius leg. Corner. Which is wasted. Updated at 6.14pm BST  6.04pm BST 47 min: Romania have started brightly, and Torje attempts to race past the Swiss left back Rodriguez. Had he managed it, he would have had a simple pull back to Keseru. But he didnt.  6.03pm BST 46 min: Hoban immediately gets a chance. Stancu carves out an opening in the Swiss box, lays the ball off to the new man and he rasps an outside of the boot shot wide of SOmners goal. That was probably the best chance Romania have had all match in open play.  6.02pm BST Were off again: Romanias Hoban replaces Pintilii, who was injured at the end of the first half.  6.01pm BST David Mooney emails in about St Paulis spectacular move: I hope this trend catches on and when Arsenal sign their next twinkle-toed number 10, Arsene comes out for the unveiling in full Lordi regalia. Weird fact: I once interviewed Lordi in their full Lordi regalia. A little bit of behind the scenes knowledge for you: those costumes absolutely stink. Like proper, proper hum.  5.58pm BST Heres the latest from the Press Association on events in Lille:  Police in Lille have used tear gas on fans following scuffles in the city centre. Supporters were seen running through the streets before officers attempted to disperse them by firing the gas into the crowds. Fans from England, Wales, Slovakia and Russia have been gathering in the city for Group B matches between the countries.   5.56pm BST Kevin Porter emails: ITV commentator: Maybe if you are brought up in an neutral country, you lack aggression. Really, where do they recruit these people from, the past? Can the standard of commentary drop any lower? Stay tuned to this here commentary on the Guardian, Kevin, and you may well find out.  5.54pm BST Theres a lovely snippet from Jonathan Wilson about Romanian football in this Knowledge column from a few years back: scroll down to the 11th paragraph (begins But theres more. Jonathan Wilson points us towards etc etc) for a fabulous tale about how Chinese whispers and rampant corruption caused a side to beat another 9-0 thanks to some extravagant extra time.  Related: The Knowledge | Which teams have played for the wrong result? | John Ashdown   5.48pm BST Some half-time reading for you all, courtesy of Tom Davies  Related: Golden Goal: Ilie Dumitrescu for Romania v Argentina (1994) | Tom Davies   5.48pm BST Well, Romania have had no possession and seem intent on protecting their lead before mounting the odd counterattack via Chipciu. Switzerland need a new striker and they need Shaqiri to turn up as, increasingly, theyre getting panicky around the box.   5.47pm BST Schar concedes a corner, Romanias first of the afternoon. They take it short and then lift the ball to the far post before a Swiss head knocks it behind for Romanias second. That one is hoiked in and Seferovic heads it clear. With that, its half-time.  5.45pm BST 45 min: Stancu sells Djourou a dummy and goes past him. Somner, in the Swiss goal, thinks about coming and Stancus eyes light up but Schar is there to clear things up. Nearly a good breakaway move from Romania.  5.44pm BST 43 min: Romania have had almost no possession and could not care less about that. Switzerland pass the ball through them, carving another chance for Seferovic who heads the ball at goal but the Romania keeper claims.  5.42pm BST 41 min: Mehmedi breaks clear in the Romania area and rifles a shot from a tight angle. Chiriches dives in and blocks the ball before it gets further than six inches from Mehmedis boot. Switzerland do very little with the corner, and Romania break but, instead of waiting for more numbers, they blare a shot high and wide over Somners goal.  5.40pm BST 38 min: Pintilii has taken a knock and the Romanian physio applies some magic spray. When play restarts, Romania are lucky not to concede. Lichsteiner is played in up the right wing and clips a wonderful ball back across the area. Behrami is clear in the box and powers a header wide of the posts. Had that been on target - and it should have been, given the quality of the ball and the space Behrami had - it would have been 1-1. Poor from Switzerland. Updated at 5.52pm BST  5.37pm BST 36 min: Keseru pulls Behrami to the ground for no good reason: yellow card.  5.36pm BST 35 min: The dangerous Chipciu breaks clear down the Romania left again, leaving Schar for dust this time but playing a poor ball into the box. He sets up a Romania attack though, with the ball fizzing about the Swiss box, until eventually a ballooning ball lands in Somners hands. Switzerland dont like Romania running at them, as Corporal Jones might have said. Updated at 5.41pm BST  5.35pm BST 34 min: Corner to Switzerland, who are beginning to look a little tense. Rodriguez lifts an outswinger into the box but Xhaka cant get a big enough portion of his head onto the ball. Goal kick.  5.33pm BST 31 min: Dzemaili pokes a good ball through to Seferovic, but does so under heavy attention from Pintilii. The referee decides Pintiliis attentions are a little unfair and blows for a foul just outside the D. Rodriguez lines it up, firing the ball at Tatarusanus right hand post. The keeper was there to claim though. Meanwhile in Lille Police fire tear gas to clear area. pic.twitter.com/n3x4Ys43qm Updated at 5.38pm BST  5.30pm BST 28 min: In Lille, trouble is brewing between the England and Russia fans:  Latest from Lille https://t.co/1miu3wNnQr  5.29pm BST 27 min: Shaqiri has a nibble at Prepelita, conceding a free-kick on the left wing. The ball is launched into the box and the Swiss defence are all over the place. Sapunaru, on the penalty spot, has a chance and smashes a shot which clips the right hand upright and goes out.  5.26pm BST 25 min: Chipciu races clear up the Romanian left, leaving Lichsteiner for dust. He cuts inside, makes room for the shot and cant quite wrap enough of his foot around the ball to bend the ball past Somner. He looks dangerous. The Swiss fans know how to tailgate party:  Related: Euro 2016 picture of the day  Swiss start with a fondue   5.24pm BST 23 min: Oof 2: And thats another thumping challenge: Chipciu clatters Lichsteiner and earns himself yellow too. Shaqiri delivers a good ball into the near post but Seferovic - who is fast having a shocker - cant get a decent header on it. Meanwhile, Swiss anthem-gate rumbles on: @TomBry The Swiss recognise that their anthem is meh, and chose another one -- the process is still ongoing. Paul. https://t.co/9QObiyE43h  5.22pm BST 22 min: Oof: thats a challenge. Prepelita slides into the back of Xhaka who goes down in a crumpled heap. Yellow card for the Romania midfielder. Updated at 5.33pm BST  5.21pm BST 21 min: Switzerland are nearly level. Schar is a long way out but looks up and aims a howtizer at the Romania goal. Tatarusanu has to tip the ball over the bar as it dips and swerves towards the back of the net. Switzerland waste the corner.  5.20pm BST 19 min: The referee had no option but to award that: Chipciu was twisting, turning and wriggling his way through the Swiss defence. Lichsteiner had a fistful of his shirt and eventually the Romania midfielder simply had to hit the deck. Completely fair enough.  5.18pm BST A very cool low shot into the bottom left corner. His second penalty of the tournament. Updated at 5.24pm BST  5.18pm BST Chipciu fights his way into the Swiss box but is tugged down by Lichsteiner. Updated at 5.28pm BST  5.16pm BST 15 min: Shaqiri plays Seferovic in, the striker lurching into the box with the goal at his mercy. He draws back his foot, he takes aim, then he tickles the ball gently into the Romania keepers hands. How many chances does he need? Updated at 5.22pm BST  5.14pm BST 12 min: Its all Switzerland at the moment, and Lichsteiner finds himself with time and space to whip a cross in, shortly after Dzemaili had a chance to shoot but instead clipped the ball across the face of goal (to nobody). Switzerlands problem so far is that their buildup has been solid but theres been nobody in the box to hit with the ball.  5.12pm BST 10 min: Dzemaili wriggles free on the outskirts of the Romania box and whips a cross in, which is headed behind for a corner. Shaqiri hoofs the corner into the box and Tatarusanu punches clear.  5.10pm BST 9 min: Romania concede a pretty unnecessary foul, granting Switzerland a free-kick high up their left wing. Rodriguez hoists the ball into the box and all the Swiss big men launch themselves at the ball and - unfortunately for them - the Romanian players. Foul: goal kick. Updated at 5.12pm BST  5.09pm BST 8 min: Prepelita fizzes a cross into the Swiss box and Chipciu nods it on. Unfortunately, he nods it to Somner, who catches the ball with ease. @Tombry Did someone say charity begging bowl time? We're drawing all 800 Euro2016 Panini stickers to raise money :) pic.twitter.com/dI9tbQVxfq  5.07pm BST 7 min: Seferovic takes a pass on the edge of the Romania box, breaking free of Chiriches. He was wasteful against Albania, and this is another chance he sends begging - whistling the ball past the keepers left-hand post. Still, it was nice wriggling work to fashion the chance in the first place. Razvan Rat played a pivotal role in my hugely successful Macclesfield side in Football Manager, reports Ian Copestake. But that was back in the day before employers stopped allowing people to play it at work. So is Rat slow because he is very old or has the world changed since I lost that job? Because he is very old. Updated at 5.12pm BST  5.05pm BST 5 min: Lichsteiner takes the ball to the byline and whips a cross over to Seferovic and Mehmedi in the box. His cross is too high, however, and Romania clear. @TomBry You're right, the Swiss anthem is. But until 1961 it was even duller, to the same tune as God Save the Queen https://t.co/gukrlJRw6X  5.04pm BST 3 min: Seferovic flattens Prepelita in the centre circle, and looks guiltily at the ref. The ref doesnt give a flying one, however, so Switzerland attack, jagging the ball about between themselves outside the Romanian box. Eventually, things open up for Xhaka and he whistles a deflected shot at goal. Tatarusanu saves comfortably.  5.01pm BST 1 min: So much for Romania not attacking much. From the throw-in, they charge up the right via Torje, who crosses for Kerseru but Djourou just gets enough on the ball to deny the Romanian striker.  5.01pm BST Were off: Switzerland, in red shirts and white shorts kick off and attack from left to right. The ball immediately goes out for a throw-in to Romania, who are all in yellow. Updated at 5.08pm BST  4.59pm BST Afternoon Tom, chirps Simon McMahon. Is it still possible for Scotland to qualify for the round of 16 with no points? @TomBry Properly, I think we need to view this Group stage as "last qualifying matches." But my, they have been fun so far. More please!  4.57pm BST The Romanians are here now, fortunately. Anthem time: Switzerland go first: conservative, sombre, like a businesslike grey suit. Romania follow: stirring, brooding stuff. Sing along at home.  4.53pm BST Right, back to the game: the teams are in the tunnel - well, the Swiss are, the Romanians are still in the changing room. The Romanian mascots are lined up, however, perhaps theyll do?  4.51pm BST Charity begging bowl: the Guardians Michael Butler is going on a charity bike ride in aid of Addenbrookes Hospital in Cambridge: this minute-by-minute entry is the equivalent of somebody shaking a bucket at you. Dig deep, dig often.  4.48pm BST Re. Olivers poser as 16.28, heres Gordon Smith: You can qualify with one point. If the points in a group end 9,6,1,1 and at least three groups end this way then at least one of them will qualify for the last 16.  What a format!  4.40pm BST Just in case you havent seen it, this - by quite some distance - is the football story of the day:   Related: St Pauli manager misses unveiling of new signing, so club use man in mask   4.34pm BST Well, if Rat doesnt have the legs to chase Shaqiri around all day, at least the Romanians have a spare Lung on the bench, honks Justin Kavanagh. Honk!  4.32pm BST In answer to Oliver, below, then yes: if every team in a group won one, lost one and drew one each side would finish with four points. The group would be settled on goal difference - so one side would go out as the fourth placed side with four points. Its entirely conceivable that a side in another group could finish with three points and go through. I think, but Im simple folk.  4.28pm BST One for the hive mind: Ive just been looking at my wallchart at work trying to figure something out, emails Oliver, who works in the sort of place where theyre allowed to look at wallcharts while at work. Is it at all possible that a team in fourth place in one group could have a better record than a team in third place in another, but that third place team make it through to the last 16?  4.25pm BST Catch up on what happened at the Stade Pierre Mauroy, with Jamie Jacksons report: Russia 1-2 Slovakia (spoiler alert)  Related: Marek Hamsiks sumptuous strike gives Slovakia the edge over Russia   4.18pm BST In the buildup to the match - its worth giving our interactive guide to the teams and players another look:   Related: Euro 2016: the complete guide to every squad and every player in France   4.08pm BST Romania have stuck by Razvan Rat, whose lack of pace was put to the test by France. Hell be up against Shaqiri this afternoon, which ought mean another tricky day at the office for him. Filip, who might have replaced Rat, remains on the bench.  4.06pm BST Romania: Tatarusanu, Sapunaru, Chiriches, Grigore, Rat, Prepelita, Pintilii, Torje, Stancu, Chipciu, Keseru.  Subs: Pantilimon, Matel, Moti, Hoban, Alibec, Stanciu, Andone, Gaman, Filip, Sanmartean, Popa, Lung.  Switzerland: Sommer, Lichtsteiner, Schar, Djourou, Rodriguez, Behrami, Xhaka, Shaqiri, Dzemaili, Mehmedi, Seferovic.  Subs: Hitz, Moubandje, Elvedi, von Bergen, Lang, Embolo, Frei, Zakaria, Fernandes, Tarashaj, Derdiyok, Burki.  Referee: Sergei Karasev (Russia)  Updated at 4.32pm BST  12.24pm BST On the surface, this does not have thrills and spills written all over it. Romania - doughty against France in the opening match of the tournament - conceded just two goals in the qualifiers but in their last five competitive fixtures have scored just five goals (three of them against Faroe Islands, one of them from the penalty spot against France). Switzerland, for their part, made a very good start against Albania, scoring inside the first five minutes, then struggled to keep it up for the rest of the match. So, what weve got here is: team who defend well but dont score very much v team that struggled to score against minnows. That said, Switzerland should score. Just look at the talent available to them. Granit Xhaka is a maestro, Xherdan Shaqiri has scored four and made five goals in his last eight competitive matches. At some point, surely the team have to live up their perennial tag of dark horses and go on a run. Victory here would mean they would be the first team to go into the knockout stages.  There are a few ructions in their squad at the moment though: Shaqiri has threatened to ditch Switzerland for the newly Uefa-recognised Kosovo, particularly if the side offer him the captaincy that Switzerland have not. Hes been doing his bit for team morale by talking about that in the buildup to this match which is good of him. Romania will be set up to frustrate and perhaps rightly so. A draw here, then victory over Albania could well see them safely into the knockout stages as one of the best third-placed teams. Their coach, Anghel Iordanescu has just about said as much too: We have to be realistic; we have to understand that well be playing against a very good side. Their 23 players play in big leagues like the Bundesliga. Our objective is to qualify from the group. Romania took confidence from their performance against France, despite their disappointment at conceding a late Dimitri Payet winner, and they will be determined not to lose this one too.  There is some historic needle to the match too. These two teams met in their second match at the 1994 World Cup finals when, under Roy Hodgson, the Swiss beat Romania 4-1 in Detroit. Romania recovered to win the group and went through to the quarter finals (courtesy of the delicious Hagi), though, and Switzerland went home in the round of 16. Three years earlier, Romania beat Switzerland in qualifying for Euro 92, meaning they failed to qualify for the tournament and Scotland got in. So thats some 22 year old needle right there.  Lets enjoy Romania at the 1994 World Cup all over again, courtesy of Rob Smyth via the link below:  Related: The Joy of Six: Counter-attacking goals  Updated at 3.52pm BST

trailText: Armando Sadikuâs first-half header gives Albania their first ever win in tournament football; whether they make the knockout stages depends on results elsewhere, while Romania are definitely out
headline: Romania 0-1 Albania: Euro 2016 â as it happened
standfirst: Armando Sadikuâs first-half header gives Albania their first ever win in tournament football; whether they make the knockout stages depends on results elsewhere, while Romania are definitely out
body:
12.10am BST

Match report

Related: Armando Sadiku winner makes Albania history in win over Romania

9.59pm BST

Do we need 24 teams in this competition? Well, maybe not. Except, how can we even contemplate fewer after watching the Albanians go at it. They now have a reasonable chance of making the knockouts - they need results to go for them, and all look possible. Sweden and Ireland fail to beat Belgium and Italy, and then either Czech Republic and Turkey draw, or Germany cane Northern Ireland. Either way, they<83><82><82><82><84>ve made a major contribution to this tournament.

Anyhow, thanks all for your company and comments - night night.

Updated at 10.04pm BST

9.55pm BST

FULL-TIME: ALBANIA 1-0 ROMANIA

ALBANIA HAVE THEIR FIRST WIN IN TOURNAMENT FOOTBALL! WHAT A PERFORMANCE THAT WAS! THEY MAY QUALIFY FOR THE SECOND PHASE - ROMANIA ARE OFF HAME!

Updated at 12.19am BST

9.54pm BST

90+5 min Abrashi chases down the goalline and overruns the ball but slides in heroically, forcing a corner! That will be it!

9.53pm BST

90+4 min Romania have created almost nothing these last ten minutes; Albania have prevented them creating almost nothing these last ten minutes. Stanciue finds space outside the box, smashes a shot over, and this is basically done!

9.52pm BST

90+3 min Torja shoves Lila to the ground, and is booked. The ref somehow avoids awarding a free-kick, but it makes no odds - Albania clear when the ball comes in, AND THEY<83><82><82><82><84>RE NEARLY THERE!

9.51pm BST

90+2 min France and Switzerland have drawn 0-0. Memushaj, who has been superb, flicks a ball around the corner, putting Roshi in, but draws the foul at the same time. More time elapses, and the ball goes towards Cana at the far post - he hads into the keeper<83><82><82><82><84>s arms.

Updated at 9.52pm BST

9.49pm BST

90+1 min Memushaj and Roshi do very well to win a corner down the left, then equally well to spend 30 seconds not taking it.

9.49pm BST

90 min One of the Albanians is down, clutching his head and face, so there<83><82><82><82><84>s a short break while he pretends to recover. There<83><82><82><82><84>ll be a minimum additional five minutes of play.

9.48pm BST

89 min But Andone throws himself at a short ball, knocking Mavraj out of the road - only for Ajeti, who has been superb, to block tackle a clearance. That<83><82><82><82><84>s an actual block tackle, not one of these.

9.46pm BST

88 min Lyon is about to witness the mother, father, any other of all parties.

Updated at 9.55pm BST

9.46pm BST

87 min Monstrous effort from Albania to win another corner, this time from right, and from it comes another free header - Hysaj guides it wide from 10 yards.

9.45pm BST

9.45pm BST

86 min Albania break, and Roshi<83><82><82><82><84>s fresh legs pace downfield, winning a corner - he exhorts the fans to even greater efforts, then Mavraj wins the header at the near post, ruffling the side-netting and causing some to celebrate the clinching goal.

9.43pm BST

84 min Again, Torje breaks with conviction, attacking the Albanian box - so Ajeti kncks him over from behind. Free-kick, 30 yards out, just left of centre, and Memushaj is booked for encroachment before Torje<83><82><82><82><84>s kick hits the wall.

Updated at 10.14pm BST

9.41pm BST

83 min Albania make their final change, Cana on for Basha.

9.40pm BST

81 min Stanciu weaves past Basha 40 yards out and accelerates towards goal, but as he shoots his left foot gives way and the ball flies miles over the top. The Albanian fans are absolutely having it.

9.37pm BST

79 min Albania are sitting in now, and Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s changes have made a differenc, or, put another way, Iordanescu got his team wrong. No, you tell him.

9.36pm BST

78 min Change for Albania: Roshi replaces Lenjani.

9.35pm BST

Before an eminently winnable group closer against Romania a sense of what might have been has crept in. Against France they defended brilliantly for 89 minutes before breaking at the death, conceding twice for a largely undeserved 2-0 defeat.
