Albania go absolutely wild, and theyve every right to go wild.  Updated at 10.16pm BST  8.44pm BST ALBANIA HAVE THEIR FIRST GOAL AT A MAJOR TOURNAMENT! AND DONT THEY DESERVE IT!  Updated at 10.17pm BST  8.43pm BST 41 min This has been lamentable from Romania, and again they cede possession in midfield, where Memushaj, whos playing well, cant control Agollis ball as it drops. It wasnt an easy skill - killing a ball at shin-height and transferring it into stride at the same time - but had he managed it, he was away.   8.40pm BST 39 min Dont believe me? Simply inspect his sideboards, here.   8.40pm BST 37 min Romania are going to absolutely get it at half-time. Anghel Iordanescu is not a man with whom it pays to trifle.   8.37pm BST 35 min Super stuff from Albania, Memushaj taking a quick throw from Agolli and nashing into the box from the right, absolutely murdering Prepelita on the outside with a delicious turn. then, he might look across goal where two men wait - admittedly shepherded by two defenders - but instead forces a shot towards the near post, where Tatrusanu saves.  Updated at 8.41pm BST  8.34pm BST 33 min A choice Romanian cut.  8.33pm BST 31 min Sadiku pulls off left and his trickery earns Albania a throw in, deep in the Romania half. Agolli chucks it straight to Sapunaru, and Romania clear.   8.30pm BST 29 min Despite the miss - did I mention, Albania missed an incredible opportunity? - they are on top at the moment. Romania cant hold onto possession at all.   8.29pm BST 28 min I was at the 1989 game in your clip, emails Justin Horton. What I mostly remember is that due to the bar at the top of the fencing, I had the choice between watching disembodied heads above it, or disembodied legs chasing the ball below it. Happy days, not. Yes, that was the first England game after Hillsbrough, if memory serves. What a total mess the old Wembley is; what a shame they couldnt do a better job of building the new one.   8.28pm BST 26 min Lila chases a long ball which is fielded by Tatarusanu, whom he petulantly shoves. Immediately, history is replayed and Lenjani slots his cross home, putting Albania in front.  Updated at 8.28pm BST  8.26pm BST 25 min What a miss that was!   8.26pm BST 23 min What a magnificent, spectacular, outstanding, classic miss! Albania sweep forwards, Agolli finding Memushaj with a lovely ball. He has options left and right and picks the latter, finding Lila, whose cross is perfect, picking out Lenjani at the back post. The keeper is more or less down, but from five yards he elects to slide, wellying his effort well over the bar. Some unkind folk might consider that karmic retribution for a right-winder wearing number 3 - and a left-winger, Lila, wearing 2.  Updated at 8.48pm BST  8.24pm BST 22 min Hysaj rattles through Sapunaru, winning the ball then cleaning him out with his trailing leg. To his chagrin, there follows a free-kick wide on the right, which Stanciu wastes.   8.23pm BST 21 min I really dont grasp why Romania feel they need two holding midfielders for this game. Similarly, I had no idea why Deschamps felt that he needed the same against Albania last week. Sure, they make it physical, but the key is to outpass them, not outfight them.   8.21pm BST 20 min Basha strides through midfield and has options both left and right, so drags a useless shot straight at Tatarusanu.  Updated at 8.28pm BST  8.20pm BST 19 min Given how badly they need to win, Romania are not playing with a great deal of intensity or abandon.  Updated at 8.20pm BST  8.19pm BST 18 min Elsewhere in Group A, Paul Pogba has nearly scored thrice, hitting the bar twice.  Updated at 8.19pm BST  8.18pm BST 15 min Not much going on so far - thus a goal from my childhood scored against Albania by the immaculate Peter Beardsley.  8.15pm BST 13 min Cant believe youve not mentioned Norman Wisdom, tweets Manc in Sofia. Wisdoms were the only films allowed to be shown in Albania during the dictatorship of Enver Hoxha, so here we go.  8.13pm BST 12 min Romania conceded just two goals in qualifying - but then, Albania ought to have scored against France, and what a defence they have.   8.11pm BST 10 min Id go with Eurovision-style voting, says the mild mannered Marie Meyer. Talking of which, this is probably my favourite ever winning song. TUNE!  8.10pm BST 8 min Romania turn it up when play restarts, and Hysaj heads away weakly, his clearance falling onto the laces of Sadiku, who swivels to volley hard - Berisha punches clear well.   8.08pm BST 6 min Basha announces his presence, flying through the air to absolutely De Jong Hoban. He gets a yellow card when really that might have been a red - has Graham Poll returned from retirement?  Updated at 8.22pm BST  8.06pm BST 5 min Romania attack down the left, and Hoban slides forward to try a curler into the far bottom corner. Berisha is paying attention, but only just - he shovels a parry thats not far from Stanciu, following up, before diving on the loose ball.  Updated at 8.19pm BST  8.04pm BST 3 min First shot on goal of the night - Alibec lays back to Stanciu, and from 25 yards he slams with his laces just over the top.   8.04pm BST 3 min The Romanian fans are absolutely going for it. That said, Im not sold on the merits of yellow as a colour for a football kit - its a bit insipid, in mine. And no, Id not tell that to the sun.   8.02pm BST 1 min The ball does some bouncing around in centrefield. Good for it.   8.01pm BST 1 min Romania get us underway.   8.01pm BST Im not going to lie, we are not in for a goalfest. But then we havent had that all tournament, and weve seen hardly any boring games, so.   7.57pm BST Loving the extra matches, tweets Paul, though 3rd place qual. criteria needs work. Why are they playing two at the same time on a Sunday? To prevent collusion in the final round of games.   7.56pm BST Time for the anthems. Might a game be about to start on time?   7.51pm BST When I were a lad, eee, me and me mates used to play a game called Not Kosher. The rules were: everyone gets on the bed, which is Kosher. Last one left on the bed wins, everyone removed therefrom is not Kosher.  To be clear, this predates the Royal Rumble.   7.50pm BST How else might you split teams in the event of a tie? How about breath-holding? Or slapsies?   7.49pm BST More permutation news: If Switzerland lose 2-1, and Romania win 1-0, the second place is down to the fair play rule, means number of bookings Makes perfect sense.   7.47pm BST Someones put Seven Nation army on the PA. What a ruse! Inspired!  7.47pm BST Also for your delectation:   Related: Switzerland v France: Euro 2016  live!   7.41pm BST Taking of those Albanian fans, theyre already at it tonight, in and bouncing. Which makes one wonder whether English fans are too preoccupied with the admittedly preoccupying preoccupations of slaking thirst and looking cool. Because theyd still be in the pub wearing different clothes and all that.   7.38pm BST So, lets hear your thoughts: did Uefa get it right - presumably for the wrong reasons - in expanding the competition and giving us loads more lovely football? Or is it ridiculous playing 36 games to eliminate only eight teams?   7.36pm BST One team remain unchanged: the Albanian supporters, an undoubted star of the group stages.   7.34pm BST So, one change for Albania: Basha replaces the suspended Kekeli. Romania, meanwhile, replace Rat with Matel, Pintilli with Hoban, Chipciu with Popa and Keseru with Alibec.   7.28pm BST Albania (4-3-3): Berisha; Hysaj, Ajeti, Mavraj, Agolli; Basha, Abrashi, Memushaj; Lenjani, Sadiku, Lila. Romania (4-2-3-1): Tatarusanu; Sapunaru, Grigore, Chiriches, Matel; Prepelita, Hoban; Popa, Stanciu, Stancu; Alibec. Updated at 7.31pm BST  6.48pm BST Slow, slow, quick; after two rounds of games, here begins the crucial third round; over the next four nights, we shall discover which teams progress to the knockout stages. Almost all of them! I hear you holler and yes, that is so. But its also so that no team is yet eliminated, which is going to make for one hell of a bagarre. Starting right here.  So, any win for Romania will probably be enough - and if France beat Switzerland, they might qualify in second place. Albania, meanwhile, are also not out of things, but need a thumping win followed by incompetence elsewhere.  Its time to see whos got what. Kick-off: 8pm BST  10.41am BST Daniel will be here soon enough. Until then, read how the Albania coach, Gianni De Biasi, is keeping himself upbeat by dangling a carrot full of incentives in front of his squad:   It may have been a wilful attempt to keep expectations at rock bottom but pre-tournament discussion in Albania centred for the most part on the nations happiness to have reached their first tournament. A dream, said the manager, Gianni De Biasi, on the eve of their opening game, intimating that the real achievement was just getting to France. Now they are two games in, the feeling must be some way different. Before an eminently winnable group closer against Romania a sense of what might have been has crept in. The Switzerland match, where they fell behind early on but created numerous chances, slipped away on account of the captain Lorik Canas entirely avoidable sending off in the first half. Against France they defended brilliantly for 89 minutes before breaking at the death, conceding twice for a largely undeserved 2-0 defeat. Read the full article here:  Related: Gianni De Biasi rues Albanias missed chances as Romania eye last 16

webTitle: Xherdan Shaqiri drops a bombshell as Swiss prepare for Romania | David Hytner
trailText: Stoke Cityâs Xherdan Shaqiri has disturbed the calm at Switzerlandâs camp by claiming he may declare for Kosovo after being overlooked as captain
headline: Xherdan Shaqiri drops a bombshell as Swiss prepare for Romania
standfirst:
Stoke City forward has disturbed the calm at Switzerlandâs camp by claiming he may declare for Kosovo after being overlooked as captain

  • Romania v Switzerland â Euro 2016 Group A
body:
Everything was calm at the Switzerland training base in Montpellier. The team could draw confidence from the 1-0 win over Albania in their opening Euro 2016 Group A tie and, with a tough test looming against Romania in Paris on Wednesday evening, there was a cautious optimism that at the fourth time of asking they could finally advance into the knockout stages of this competition.

Then Xherdan Shaqiri dropped what can only be described as a bombshell. <83><82><82><82><93>What if the coach of Kosovo wants me as the captain? Of course, I am thinking about it then,<83><82><82><82><9d> the Switzerland winger said.

Related: Arsenal<83><82><82><82><84>s new midfielder Granit Xhaka impresses in Switzerland win

The context to the soundbite is that Kosovo have been recognised as an independent football nation. They were admitted by Uefa on 3 May and Fifa on 13 May, and they will contest qualification to the 2018 World Cup in Russia; they have been placed in a group that contains Croatia, Iceland, Ukraine, Turkey and Finland.

Shaqiri was born in 1991 in Kosovo. His family emigrated to Switzerland when he was a baby and he declared for the country in which he was raised. The Stoke City player was given his senior international debut in 2010 by Ottmar Hitzfeld, the manager at the time, and he was a surprise inclusion in his squad for that year<83><82><82><82><84>s World Cup. He has since played at the 2014 World Cup. He is one of the glamour names in Vladimir Petkovic<83><82><82><82><84>s squad.

The possibility exists, however, that Shaqiri could be allowed to switch his allegiance, despite having played competitive matches for Switzerland, because Kosovo is a new nation. The suggestion he was open to the possibility has coloured the news agenda before the Romania game.

Petkovic has other players in his squad who were born in Kosovo or have Kosovo-Albanian heritage and, as such, would be eligible to switch <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the midfielders Granit Xhaka, Valon Behrami, Admir Mehmedi and Blerim Dzemaili and the forward Shani Tarashaj. All of them bar Tarashaj, a 21-year-old prospect who has signed for Everton, started against Albania.

There is nervousness in Albania, too, that some of their players who are eligible to switch to Kosovo might choose to do so while some in the same situation with other countries, including Belgium<83><82><82><82><84>s Adnan Januzaj <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the Manchester United winger <83><82><82><82><80><9c> have indicated that they will think about it.

Xhaka and Behrami, Petkovic<83><82><82><82><84>s central midfield pair, said before the start of the championship that they would remain true to Switzerland, and the issue was supposed to have been parked until after the finals. Shaqiri has brought it back to the fore.

His timing has been criticised in Switzerland. Why now, as the team prepare for a crucial game? There have been the inevitable and understandable questions about the impact on team harmony.

Shaqiri is not backward in coming forwards. He is a player who craves the spotlight, who wants to be the top dog, and there are those in Switzerland who have interpreted his comment about Kosovo as a bit of self-promotion, an attempt to offer a reminder of his worth.

Shaqiri<83><82><82><82><84>s line about the captaincy could also be significant. When Petkovic took the difficult decision to drop the long-time captain, Gokhan Inler, after the midfielder had endured a frustrating season at Leicester City, he gave the armband to Stephan Lichtsteiner, the Juventus full-back, and named Xhaka and Behrami as vice-captains. Shaqiri was not happy and he said so. How could he have been excluded from the inner circle?

It is other Switzerland players who are currently in the spotlight, particularly Xhaka, who has completed a move to Arsenal from Borussia M<83><92><82>nchengladbach for around <83><80><9a><82>30m and Breel Embolo, the 19-year-old forward who is expected to leave Basel this summer for the highest fee ever paid to a Swiss club.

It has been reported that Manchester United have had talks with his agent <83><82><82><82><80><9c> who is Shaqiri<83><82><82><82><84>s brother, Erdin <83><82><82><82><80><9c> while other clubs in England and Germany have been credited with an interest. Embolo can play anywhere in the attacking line and there has been a clamour for him to start against Romania, most likely in place of Mehmedi. Embolo came on for him in the 62nd minute against Albania.

Lichtsteiner has been feted and then there is Yann Sommer, the goalkeeper. He made some vital interventions against Albania, including a decisive, late, one-on-one block from a substitute, Shkelzen Gashi.

Shaqiri is determined to regain centre stage.

Switzerland v Romania, Stade V<83><92><82>lodrome, 8pm BST Wednesday 15 June

Switzerland (probable): Sommer; Lichsteiner, Schar, Djourou, Rodriguez; Behrami, Dzemaili, Xhaka; Shaqiri, Seferovic, Mehmedi.

Romania (probable): Tatarusanu; Sapunaru, Grigore, Chiriches, Rat; Hoban, Pintilii; Stanciu, Popa, Stancu; Andone.

Referee S Karasev (Rus)

webTitle: Armando Sadiku winner makes Albania history in win over Romania
trailText: Armando Sadiku scored against Romania just before half-time for Albaniaâs first win in a tournament but they have to wait to find out if they have reached the last 16 of Euro 2016
headline: Armando Sadiku winner makes Albania history in win over Romania
standfirst: NA
byline: Andy Hunter at Stade de Lyon
body:
Amir Abrashi pumped his fists and screamed at the equally passionate Albanian support congregated behind Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s goal. He had only won a corner but also precious time in the country<83><82><82><82><84>s wait for its debut victory at a major tournament. Seconds later it arrived, and Albania<83><82><82><82><84>s live-wire midfielder dropped to his knees in tears. History in the making.

Their first win at the European Championship secured, Albania must wait until the group phase is over to discover whether they will play any further part as one of the third-placed qualifiers. England are a possible opponent in the last 16 for a team with a goal difference of minus two. <83><82><82><82><93>I hope we can stay,<83><82><82><82><9d> said coach Giovanni De Biasi. <83><82><82><82><93>I<83><82><82><82><84>m a positive person and I think we deserve it. We<83><82><82><82><84>ve shown we can play these games against top teams who have more quality than us.<83><82><82><82><9d> More quality perhaps, but not more character, pride and, on the evidence of this victory, game intelligence.

Related: Switzerland quell Paul Pogba storm to earn France draw and last-16 spot

Backed by fanatical, fantastic support, Albania eliminated Romania with flashes of creativity and impregnable defending, leaving an indelible mark both with the celebrations that followed Armando Sadiku<83><82><82><82><84>s decisive first-half header and the final whistle. De Biasi was awarded Albanian citizenship after the Italian coach delivered their first appearance at an international tournament. He could run for the presidency after this. <83><82><82><82><93>We won with heart and with quality,<83><82><82><82><9d> De Biasi added. <83><82><82><82><93>We were able to contain a squad with strength and quality and that had conceded only two goals in the qualifying phase. Technically we decided to wait for Romania and try to attack the spaces. We expected a strong start from them but were ready to counterattack. We defended very well, very solid and we closed the spaces.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The contrast with Romania coach Anghel Iordanescu and his deflated players was stark. Iordanescu was named Coach of the Century by the Romanian FA after leading the country to the quarter-finals of the 1994 World Cup and the last 16 four years later. His third time may end in bitter recrimination and was asked whether, as coach of the century, he was now responsible for the shame of the century. <83><82><82><82><93>You have never done anything constructive in your life,<83><82><82><82><9d> Iordanescu told his accuser. <83><82><82><82><93>If this is the shame of the century let the Romanian press judge me and put the question [of whether he will continue in the job] to the president of the FA.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Albania<83><82><82><82><84>s passage to France had turned De Biasi<83><82><82><82><84>s team into a symbol of national unity but was also assisted by the fall-out from the <83><82><82><82><9c>Battle of Belgrade<83><82><82><82><84> when Serbian supporters invaded the pitch after a drone carrying a <83><82><82><82><9c>Greater Albania<83><82><82><82><84> flag flew over the stadium. Uefa punished both teams for the abandoned qualifier before Albania won three points on appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport.

Related: Romania 0-1 Albania: Euro 2016 <83><82><82><82><80><9c> as it happened

Having gone to such lengths to reach their first international tournament, there was deflation at how the Euros had unfolded against Switzerland and France but also a clear determination to make their mark at the third attempt. Occasionally it was made on Romanian ankles as the game opened at a ferocious pace. The Czech referee Pavel Kralovec allowed several late challenges to go unpunished, though he did book Migjen Basha for a flying leap into the shoulder of Ovidiu Hoban with only eight minutes gone. Basha was fortunate to escape a second yellow for clipping Lucian Sanmartean as the Romania substitute weaved his way towards goal in the second half.

As in their opening two defeats, Albania started carelessly with naivety in possession helping Romania to dominate the early exchanges. Their threat faded once Albania found some composure and invention on the ball. A superb move should have resulted in the ball finding the Romanian net when Sadiku, Ermir Lenjani and Amir Abrashi combined down the left before the striker released Andi Lila down the opposite flank with a perfect pass. Lila crossed first time for Lenjani who blazed over from six yards but was spared lasting ignominy by an offside flag.

The flowing move injected belief into the Albanian ranks. Basha miscued another free shot on goal from Ledian Memushaj<83><82><82><82><84>s corner before their long-awaited breakthrough arrived moments before half-time. Collecting a throw-in on the right, Memushaj swept a deep cross to the far post where Sadiku rose above a defender and goalkeeper Ciprian Tatarusanu to head over the line. Cue scenes of unbridled joy as the striker sank to his knees before a delirious Albanian bench.

One of Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s substitutes, Florin Andone, struck the bar after an incisive one-touch move sent him clear of the Albania defence but that was a rare scare for a defence that worked tirelessly, and bravely, to stifle a limited attacking threat. Arlind Ajeti, outstanding in the heart of Albania<83><82><82><82><84>s back-line, caught the mood to perfection. <83><82><82><82><93>We have made a historical event,<83><82><82><82><9d> he said.

Related: Romania v Albania: Euro 2016 <83><82><82><82><80><9c> as it happened

Arlind Ajeti, outstanding in the heart of Albanias back-line, caught the mood to perfection. We have made a historical event, he said.  Related: Romania v Albania: Euro 2016  as it happened

webTitle: Dimitri Payets stunner rescues Frances welcome party against Romania
trailText: Dimitri Payet scored a superb late goal for the hosts France to earn a 2-1 win over Romania in the opening game of Euro 2016
headline: Dimitri Payetâs stunner rescues Franceâs welcome party against Romania
standfirst: NA
byline: David Hytner at Stade de France
body:
When Dimitri Payet<83><82><82><82><84>s number went up, the enormity of what he had just done hit him with the force of a wrecking ball. France<83><82><82><82><84>s Euro 2016 curtain-raiser looked set to end in frustration and, possibly, recriminations but with one sumptuous swing of his left boot Payet changed the complexion of the evening.

Related: Payet strikes as France see off Romania - Euro 2016 Football Daily

With the 90 minutes almost up, and Romania looking value for a draw, the West Ham United forward picked up possession outside the area, jinked inside and let fly. The shot flew unerringly into the far, top corner and the championship had its lift-off moment.

Payet had excelled during his debut Premier League campaign but this was something else. Romania were crushed and, when Payet was substituted in injury-time and the stadium rose to acclaim him, the tears welled in his eyes. He tried to hold them back but he could not.

When they trickled down his face, it was the standout image of a helter-skelter evening in which France had been charged with offering a tonic to a nation that surely needed one. The buildup had been testing, with the national state of emergency lending an understandable edginess. Elsewhere for France there have been the strikes and the floods, the race rows and the scandals. The football was supposed to bring succour.

It did so in the end, but only after a performance that was undercut by anxiety and which did little to embellish France<83><82><82><82><84>s status as the tournament favourites. They were indebted to Hugo Lloris for a close-range block from Bogdan Stancu in the early running and also for a gilt-edged miss by the Romania midfielder at the beginning of the second half. The result could have gone the other way.

Related: France<83><82><82><82><84>s match-winner Dimitri Payet overcome by emotion of late drama

Olivier Giroud had one of those games with which Arsenal supporters have become familiar over the second half of the season. Three times he missed chances <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the first was clear-cut <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but he was able to give France the lead after an error from the Romania goalkeeper Ciprian Tatarusanu, who came for a Payet cross only to miss it. Tatarusanu felt he had been impeded by Giroud and the Romania manager, Anghel Iordanescu, said he could not and did not want to answer questions about the incident.

Romania were never out of contention and they drew level when France failed to clear Adrian Popa<83><82><82><82><84>s cross from the right. The excellent Nicolae Stanciu surged towards goal and he was blocked by a reckless challenge from Patrice Evra. The stadium howled when the penalty was bravely and correctly awarded by the Hungarian referee, Viktor Kassai, and Stancu rolled it past Lloris. Payet, though, would fashion the sting in the tale.

After the pomp of the opening ceremony, which had featured can-can dancers, a levitating Eiffel Tower and David Guetta <83><82><82><82><80><9c> among many other things <83><82><82><82><80><9c> France struggled to come to terms with the occasion.

Didier Deschamps, the manager, referenced how his players had begun in <83><82><82><82><93>timid<83><82><82><82><9d> fashion.

The hosts spurned two glorious chances to get the early goal they craved. Payet crossed only for the unmarked Giroud to head wastefully wide and Antoine Griezmann hit the post at the second attempt after initially missing his kick from Bacary Sagna<83><82><82><82><84>s cross. The ball rebounded to him off Vlad Chiriches.

Romania ought to have been in front with their first meaningful chance, and what a chance it was. Stanciu<83><82><82><82><84>s corner was flicked on and Stancu looked certain to score at the far post from three yards out. His shot, though, was too close to Lloris, who saved instinctively. It was a pivotal moment. From the resulting corner Florin Andone looped a header on to the roof of the net.

Related: Olivier Giroud divides opinion but was pivotal as France conquered Romania

Deschamps accepted his team<83><82><82><82><84>s performance was far from perfect and it was curious to see how peripheral Paul Pogba was. Griezmann also laboured and both of them were substituted. Griezmann dragged his heels as he departed. Evra had a poor game and there were times when France looked shaky at the back.

Griezmann went close towards the end of a subdued first half and Giroud, having outmuscled Chiriches on a corner, headed high but Romania could lament Stancu<83><82><82><82><84>s miss in the 47th minute. Stanciu<83><82><82><82><84>s cross was perfect and so was the timing of Stancu<83><82><82><82><84>s run and first touch. The side-on volley was set up but he shinned it wide.

France sought to turn the screw. Giroud worked Tatarusanu when he might have done better and Pogba <83><82><82><82><80><9c> France<83><82><82><82><84>s poster boy for the championship <83><82><82><82><80><9c> extended the Romania goalkeeper more fully with a vicious volley from Payet<83><82><82><82><84>s cross.

The breakthrough came when Tatarusanu flapped at another Payet delivery. Perhaps he had been unnerved by the manner in which Giroud jumped; the striker appeared to lead with his elbow. There was no serious contact, though, and Giroud was able to guide a header into the empty net.

Game over? Not at all. Only Evra knew what he was thinking about when he hung out a leg at Stanciu and Stancu sensed redemption with his penalty conversion. The last word, however, went to Payet.

webTitle: Romania bans trophy hunting of brown bears, wolves, lynx and wild cats
trailText: Unexpected move reverses a trend that has seen increasing numbers of large carnivores shot by hunters each year since Romaniaâs accession to the European Union
headline: Romania bans trophy hunting of brown bears, wolves, lynx and wild cats
standfirst: Unexpected move reverses a trend that has seen increasing numbers of large carnivores shot by hunters each year since Romaniaâs accession to the European Union
body:
Romania has banned all trophy hunting of brown bears, wolves, lynx and wild cats in a surprise decision that gives Europe<83><82><82><82><84>s largest population of large carnivores a reprieve from its most severe and immediate threat.

The move on Tuesday reverses a trend which has seen the number of large carnivores being shot by hunters grow year on year since Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s accession into the European Union in 2007. In 2016, the largest hunting quotas yet gave hunters the mandate to shoot 550 bears, 600 wolves and 500 big cats over 12 months.

Over the last decade, hunting has grown into a multimillion-euro industry in Romania, with hunters from all over the world paying up to <83><82><80><9a><82>10,000 (<83><80><9a><82>8,800) to claim a <83><82><82><82><9c>trophy<83><82><82><82><84> <83><82><82><82><80><9c> hunting parlance for the carcass of a hunted animal <83><82><82><82><80><9c> from the Carpathian mountains.

The government has claimed that in order to exist, the industry relies on a loophole in European law which allows for the culling of wild animals that have been proven to be a danger to humans. Under the habitats directive, all large carnivores are protected in European Union member states, yet the state can order the killing of specific animals if shown to have attacked a person or damaged private property.

<83><82><82><82><93>Hunting for money was already illegal, but it was given a green light anyway,<83><82><82><82><9d> environment minster, Cristiana Pasca-Palmer, told the Guardian. <83><82><82><82><9c>The damages [clause in the habitats directive] acted as a cover for trophy hunting.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Each year, hundreds of hunting associations across the country would submit two numbers; the total population of each large carnivore species, and the total number which they believed to be likely to cause damages. The second number would then act as a basis for a government-issued hunting quota for each species. These quotas were then carved up between hunting companies and sold as hunting rights to the public.

<83><82><82><82><93>This method raised some questions,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Pasca-Palmer. <83><82><82><82><93>How can hunting associations count how many animals are causing damages a priori <83><82><82><82><80><9c> before the damages have happened? By introducing the ban, what we are doing is simply putting things back on the right track, as the habitats directive originally intended.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Wildlife NGOs claim that the methodology also tended to dramatically overestimate the populations of large carnivores. The official figure for the number of bears in Romania is over 6,000, and for wolves is 4,000. Yet with hundreds of hunting associations each responsible for monitoring a small area of land, and animals prone to wandering, it is understood that individual animals were often counted multiple times, potentially pushing the total population statistics up by thousands.

Related: Romanian politician calls for the army to help control bear population

Announced late on Tuesday evening, the ban is expected to divide Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s population, pitching rural and urban dwellers against each other. The government<83><82><82><82><84>s decision has strong support in the larger cities, which have seen a growing movement against hunting in recent months. But in much of Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s remote countryside large carnivores are a daily threat to villagers and a persistent nuisance to livestock farmers, and many see hunting as the only solution.

Csaba Domokos, a bear specialist with wildlife protection NGO Milvus group, is convinced that the success or failure of the hunting ban rides on the government<83><82><82><82><84>s ability to address the rural population<83><82><82><82><84>s fears.

<83><82><82><82><93>Damages caused by large carnivores are a very real concern in the countryside,<83><82><82><82><9d> he said. <83><82><82><82><93>The system up until now did not work; hunting does not reduce conflicts between carnivores and humans; in fact many studies show that with wolves and large cats, it can actually increase the problem.

<83><82><82><82><93>But the rural population believe that hunting is the answer, and unless they can be convinced otherwise, people may well start to take the problem into their own hands. The ban is a great step, but we don<83><82><82><82><84>t want hunting to be replaced by poaching.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Domokos points out that hunters also have a vested interested in the protection of their quarry. <83><82><82><82><93>To some extent, hunting acts as a financial incentive for wildlife management, from preventing poaching to conserving habitats. There is some concern that once you take that away, the government will not invest enough to replace it.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The government<83><82><82><82><84>s response is to take management into its own hands. A special unit is to be set up within the paramilitary police force that will assess any reports of damages by large carnivores and deal with the culprit animal directly. The ministry of environment have discussed the possibility of relocating the target animals abroad to countries interested in <83><82><82><82><9c>rewilding<83><82><82><82><84>.

The ban comes amid a growing push for the protection of Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s wild mountains that has seen anti-corruption officers convict dozens of foresters, hunters and local officials in recent years.

Gabriel Paun, an activist and conservationist behind a petition that collected 11,000 signatures in the weeks before the hunting ban, sees the government<83><82><82><82><84>s decision as a step towards a safer future for Europe<83><82><82><82><84>s wild spaces: <83><82><82><82><93>The Carpathian mountains are home to more biodiversity than anywhere else in Europe, but for too long they have been ruthlessly exploited for forestry and hunting. Let<83><82><82><82><84>s hope the government<83><82><82><82><84>s decision is a sign of things to come.<83><82><82><82><9d>

webTitle: Social workers help Romania's abandoned children off the streets
trailText: More than 25 years have passed since CeauÈescuâs rule ended but children are still fleeing orphanages for a life of homelessness. Now social workers are helping them access healthcare, education and citizenship
headline: Social workers help Romania's abandoned children off the streets
standfirst: More than 25 years have passed since CeauÈescuâs rule ended but children are still fleeing orphanages for a life of homelessness. Now social workers are helping them access healthcare, education and citizenship
body:
Seven-year-old Alina studies a picture-dictionary with her volunteer teacher in a day centre for the street children of Bucharest. Her clothes are clean and her was hair neatly combed that morning. This is not how she arrived at the centre. Washed away is the froth of paint and glue from her lips and chin.

Alina sleeps in a railway station. She finds hiding places in the shadows, away from predators, abusers and the winter rain. An estimated 1,000 children live on the city<83><82><82><82><84>s streets <83><82><82><82><80><9c> although social workers tell me the actual figure could be double that. The children shelter in public buildings or in the maze of tunnels buried beneath Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s capital city.

A social worker at the day centre explains that most of the children have run away from orphanages, though some were born on the streets. This was the case with Alina. Her mother initially accepted state care, but when Alina turned two, her mother had to leave her alone in an orphanage or risk living together on the streets. She chose the latter and, shortly afterwards, died from substance abuse.

At the day centre Alina has a volunteer helping her learn to read. She is also learning to become a clown. Street juggling and performance is a safe and legitimate way for her to make money. <83><82><82><82><93>Clowns are magicians,<83><82><82><82><9d> the social worker adds. <83><82><82><82><93>They can make all sorts of things happen <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and when the children put on the costume they no longer see themselves as dirty sub-humans. It allows their brain to see themselves in a new positive way<83><82><82><82><9d>. This is critical in a culture where it is normal for homeless children to inhale from plastic bags filled with industrial paint.

Related: Ceausescu<83><82><82><82><84>s children | Wendell Steavenson

The street children are a legacy from the days of the Ceau<83><86><82><84>escu dictatorship. In the 1960s a decree banning abortion, contraception and promoting large families resulted in a baby boom. Abandonment and neglect became normal practice and abuse of these children in orphanages commonplace. Often they ran away from the orphanages, preferring the uncertainty of street life. These children had their own children and now, three or four generations later, they live short, vulnerable, painful lives on the streets.

Social work was also outlawed under Ceau<83><86><82><84>escu and the profession had to start again after his execution in 1989. There was a lot to catch up on. For the past 25 years, successive governments have tried, unsuccessfully, to curb poverty but financial support alone, such as cash transfers, has not worked. By 2014, 52.2% of children in Romania are at risk of poverty or social exclusion (pdf), while more than 40% of the population live under the poverty line.

Without social workers and <83><82><82><82><80>their skills, a country cannot progress in terms of social inclusion

Dragos Pislaru

According to Ana Radulescu, general manager of ASproAS, a professional social worker association: <83><82><82><82><93>Providing financial support is only one part of the solution. This strategy by itself will not shift the causes of poverty.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Recognising that past attempts to alleviate poverty have failed, the new minister of labour and social protection, Dragos Pislaru, understands that social work is fundamental to enable people to sustainably escape cycles of poverty. <83><82><82><82><93>Romania can only move forward when we understand that inclusion is not achieved just by giving money away,<83><82><82><82><9d> Pislaru says. <83><82><82><82><93>A society cannot progress economically when an important part of the country lives in social exclusion. Without social workers and their skills, a country cannot progress in terms of social inclusion.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Under this government, Radulescu says: <83><82><82><82><93>Social workers are being recognised for competencies that help people not only access resources, but also use those resources in changing their lives.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Pislaru, Radulescu and social workers are working together to promote integration across government departments. Their joint vision is to ensure that social workers are active in every community social service by bringing together experienced social workers to empower individuals and communities to regain control, confidence and security in their own lives.

Related: 20 years on, life is still tough for Romania's street children

The government<83><82><82><82><84>s recognition of the importance of social work means Alina and her fellow street children now have more hope for change than ever before. Social workers are liaising with officials to establish systems whereby street children can register as citizens, and thereby gain access to healthcare, education and other entitlements. This is not an easy task: many of the children cannot cite their family heritage to complete the paperwork. More complicated still is that many of them inherently distrust government, understandably given many must turn to crime and prostitution to survive. Yet social workers are encouraging a system of registration that helps the government approach these children non-judgementally and sympathetically.

Social workers globally are always advocates for holistic welfare systems that, premised on preserving people<83><82><82><82><84>s dignity, are essential to peaceful, productive and sustainable societies. The role of social work in Romania in particular will be crucial to overcoming the crippling social problems left behind by decades of dictatorship.

Join the Social Care Network to read more pieces like this. Follow us on Twitter (@GdnSocialCare) and like us on Facebook to keep up with the latest social care news and views.

Related: 20 years on, life is still tough for Romania's street children  The governments recognition of the importance of social work means Alina and her fellow street children now have more hope for change than ever before. Social workers are liaising with officials to establish systems whereby street children can register as citizens, and thereby gain access to healthcare, education and other entitlements. This is not an easy task: many of the children cannot cite their family heritage to complete the paperwork. More complicated still is that many of them inherently distrust government, understandably given many must turn to crime and prostitution to survive. Yet social workers are encouraging a system of registration that helps the government approach these children non-judgementally and sympathetically.  Social workers globally are always advocates for holistic welfare systems that, premised on preserving peoples dignity, are essential to peaceful, productive and sustainable societies. The role of social work in Romania in particular will be crucial to overcoming the crippling social problems left behind by decades of dictatorship. webTitle: Romania kicked out of Eurovision after failing to pay debt
trailText: European Broadcasting Union, which runs contest, says Romaniaâs national broadcaster owes more than Â£7.9m
headline: Romania kicked out of Eurovision after failing to pay debt
standfirst: European Broadcasting Union, which runs contest, says Romaniaâs national broadcaster owes more than Â£7.9m
byline: Kit Gillet in Bucharest and Jessica Elgot
body:
Romania has suffered a fate worse than nul points after being booted out of this year<83><82><82><82><84>s Eurovision competition because it failed to clear its debts to the European Broadcasting Union.

The EBU, which runs Eurovision, said Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s national broadcaster, Televiziunea Romana, had failed to pay debts totalling more than <83><80><9a><82>7.9m.

Ingrid Deltenre, director general of the EBU, said it was <83><82><82><82><93>regrettable that we are forced to take this action<83><82><82><82><9d> but four attempts to get a response from the Romanian government had received no reply.

<83><82><82><82><93>The continued indebtedness of TVR jeopardises the financial stability of the EBU itself,<83><82><82><82><9d> Deltenre said, confirming that the Romanian act, Ovidiu Anton, would be taken out of the running order of the second semi-final on 12 May.

When the expulsion was first rumoured, TVR insisted it had paid off debts for the period 2008 to 2012, but added: <83><82><82><82><93>The latest payment was made in January this year in the amount of <83><82><80><9a><82>250,000 after which TVR informed the international organisation that it can<83><82><82><82><84>t sustain these payments any more.<83><82><82><82><9d>

On Monday, Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s prime minister, Dacian Ciolos, said the government would seek a solution to avoid being locked out of the competition. A deadline for payment was extended until Thursday, but no payment was received, according to EBU.

In recent weeks, the ministry of finance has suggested TVR, which recorded losses of more than <83><80><9a><82>4.2m last year, may face insolvency proceedings and a dramatic restructuring.

<83><82><82><82><93>This is of course disappointing for the artist chosen to represent Romania, for our colleagues at TVR who have prepared their participation so well this year and, not least, for Romanian viewers and the many Eurovision fans in the country,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Jon Ola Sand, executive supervisor of the Eurovision song contest at the EBU.

Anton, who was set to perform his English-language song Moment of Silence, said he had also been kept in the dark. <83><82><82><82><93>I don<83><82><82><82><84>t think this should happen to any artist,<83><82><82><82><9d> he told the Guardian last week.

<83><82><82><82><93>No one has contacted me. I<83><82><82><82><84>ve just heard the rumours and seen the news. <83><82><82><82><93>I<83><82><82><82><84>m just going to pretend I didn<83><82><82><82><84>t hear anything and keep preparing until I am told otherwise. Hopefully it will be solved.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Romania has never finished higher than third in the competition in 22 years of participating. The contest will be held in Sweden this year, with the final on 14 May.

Pre-ordered CDs will include the Romanian entry and Romanian press and fans will still be able to attend the contest in Stockholm, but will be moved to sit with the international delegation for non-participating countries, a spokesman said.

The ruling may also affect whether Televiziunea Romana can broadcast Euro 2016 and this summer<83><82><82><82><84>s Olympic Games in Rio.

Ingrid Deltenre, director general of the EBU, said it was regrettable that we are forced to take this action but four attempts to get a response from the Romanian government had received no reply.  The continued indebtedness of TVR jeopardises the financial stability of the EBU itself, Deltenre said, confirming that the Romanian act, Ovidiu Anton, would be taken out of the running order of the second semi-final on 12 May.  When the expulsion was first rumoured, TVR insisted it had paid off debts for the period 2008 to 2012, but added: The latest payment was made in January this year in the amount of 250,000 after which TVR informed the international organisation that it cant sustain these payments any more. On Monday, Romanias prime minister, Dacian Ciolos, said the government would seek a solution to avoid being locked out of the competition. A deadline for payment was extended until Thursday, but no payment was received, according to EBU.  In recent weeks, the ministry of finance has suggested TVR, which recorded losses of more than 4.2m last year, may face insolvency proceedings and a dramatic restructuring.  This is of course disappointing for the artist chosen to represent Romania, for our colleagues at TVR who have prepared their participation so well this year and, not least, for Romanian viewers and the many Eurovision fans in the country, says Jon Ola Sand, executive supervisor of the Eurovision song contest at the EBU. Anton, who was set to perform his English-language song Moment of Silence, said he had also been kept in the dark. I dont think this should happen to any artist, he told the Guardian last week.  No one has contacted me. Ive just heard the rumours and seen the news. Im just going to pretend I didnt hear anything and keep preparing until I am told otherwise. Hopefully it will be solved. webTitle: Romania may be booted off Eurovision over TV station's debt
trailText: National station has amassed â¬10m debt to the European Broadcasting Union, with singer Ovidiu Antonâs place in the contest now in question
headline: Romania may be booted off Eurovision over TV station's debt
standfirst: National station has amassed â¬10m debt to the European Broadcasting Union, with singer Ovidiu Antonâs place in the contest now in question
body:
Romania says it has been warned it could be excluded from this year<83><82><82><82><84>s Eurovision song contest after the national television station TVR amassed a debt of <83><82><80><9a><82>10m (<83><80><9a><82>7.9m) to the European Broadcasting Union (EBU).

In a statement, TVR said it had been told it risked being barred from broadcasting the annual singing show, and Romania prevented from fielding candidates, due to unpaid bills dating back to 2011-2012.

<83><82><82><82><93>The Romanian National Television has requested understanding and tolerance regarding its disastrous financial situation, which has been understood by EBU, which until now has postponed drastic measures,<83><82><82><82><9d> TVR said on Saturday.

TVR said it had paid off debts for the period 2008 to 2012, but added: <83><82><82><82><93>The latest payment was made in January this year in the amount of <83><82><80><9a><82>250,000 after which TVR informed the international organisation that it can<83><82><82><82><84>t sustain these payments any more.<83><82><82><82><9d>

TVR recorded losses of over <83><80><9a><82>4.2m last year, according to the latest report it submitted to the Romanian parliament.

After first appearing in the contest in 1994, Romania have never finished higher than third.

Ovidiu Anton, this year<83><82><82><82><84>s Romanian entry <83><82><82><82><80><9c> who is set to perform his English-language song Moment of Silence, may now be forced out of the lineup.

<83><82><82><82><93>I don<83><82><82><82><84>t think this should happen to any artist,<83><82><82><82><9d> he told the Guardian. <83><82><82><82><93>No one has contacted me. I<83><82><82><82><84>ve just heard the rumours and seen the news. I<83><82><82><82><84>m just going to pretend I didn<83><82><82><82><84>t hear anything and keep preparing until I am told otherwise. Hopefully it will be solved.<83><82><82><82><9d>

According to the TVR statement, EBU is awaiting responses from the Romanian government, parliament and finance ministry over the debt.

There are also concerns that the underfunded television network might be unable to broadcast Euro 2016 and this summer<83><82><82><82><84>s Olympic games in Rio unless the debt is paid.

This year<83><82><82><82><84>s Eurovision song contest will be held in Stockholm, Sweden, with the semi-finals taking place on 10 and 12 May and the grand final on 14 May.

In a statement, TVR said it had been told it risked being barred from broadcasting the annual singing show, and Romania prevented from fielding candidates, due to unpaid bills dating back to 2011-2012. The Romanian National Television has requested understanding and tolerance regarding its disastrous financial situation, which has been understood by EBU, which until now has postponed drastic measures, TVR said on Saturday.  TVR said it had paid off debts for the period 2008 to 2012, but added: The latest payment was made in January this year in the amount of 250,000 after which TVR informed the international organisation that it cant sustain these payments any more. TVR recorded losses of over 4.2m last year, according to the latest report it submitted to the Romanian parliament. After first appearing in the contest in 1994, Romania have never finished higher than third. Ovidiu Anton, this years Romanian entry  who is set to perform his English-language song Moment of Silence, may now be forced out of the lineup. I dont think this should happen to any artist, he told the Guardian. No one has contacted me. Ive just heard the rumours and seen the news. Im just going to pretend I didnt hear anything and keep preparing until I am told otherwise. Hopefully it will be solved.  According to the TVR statement, EBU is awaiting responses from the Romanian government, parliament and finance ministry over the debt. There are also concerns that the underfunded television network might be unable to broadcast Euro 2016 and this summers Olympic games in Rio unless the debt is paid.  This years Eurovision song contest will be held in Stockholm, Sweden, with the semi-finals taking place on 10 and 12 May and the grand final on 14 May.

webTitle: Romania: hellhole or country of romance and mystery?
trailText: The image of Romania has taken a battering in Britain. We travel to Bucharest to find a city transformed
headline: Romania: hellhole or country of romance and mystery?
standfirst:
Romaniaâs image has taken a battering in the British press and our survey found it the EU country Britons would least like to live in. Carole Cadwalladr returns to Bucharest after 20 years to find a city transformed

â¢ Read the results of the Observerâs Britons and Europe survey
â¢ Read Julian Comanâs analysis of the survey results
â¢ Firas Alshater: âOne way of not living in the past is to make people laughâ
â¢ Brexit is a feminist issue by Helen Lewis
â¢ What EU cartoonists think of Brexit
body:
So, the good news, I tell the first Romanian I interview, is that a British newspaper wants to print a story about Romania that isn<83><82><82><82><84>t about immigrants stealing their jobs or Gypsy beggars getting their teeth fixed free on the NHS. And the bad news, he asks? I pause. That, according to the Observer<83><82><82><82><84>s survey, most Brits believe that Romanians come to Britain to steal our jobs and get their teeth fixed on the NHS.

In fact, the survey doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t say that, exactly, but it<83><82><82><82><84>s not far off. It says that of all the countries in Europe in which we would least like to live, the very worst place <83><82><82><82><80><9c> cited by a massive 25% of all respondents, leaps and bounds ahead of anywhere else <83><82><82><82><80><9c> is Romania. That as a nation, we believe Romanians are <83><82><82><82><93>aggressive<83><82><82><82><9d> and <83><82><82><82><93>lazy<83><82><82><82><9d>. That hardly any of us have actually been there (fewer than 1% in the last five years). And a massive 58% of us believe that Romania is one of the five EU nations that has sent the most migrants to the UK.

Which may give some clue as to what<83><82><82><82><84>s going on here. Because it turns out that not only do we know hardly anything about Romania but what we do know isn<83><82><82><82><84>t even true. In fact, there are fewer than 100,000 Romanians in Britain. (Compared with nearly 700,000 Poles, for example). Figures from 2014 show that fewer than 2,500 of them claimed benefits here. They are overwhelmingly net contributors to the British economy.

To say that Romania has had a poor press in Britain is a bit like saying that Nicolae Ceau<83><80><82>escu was slightly to the left of Jeremy Corbyn. But then, at a hip cafe in downtown Bucharest, Cristian Lup<83><80><82>a, the editor of a pioneering magazine, Dec<83><92><82>t o Revist<83><80><9e><82><92>, reminds me of the press coverage that accompanied the news that Romanians and Bulgarians were going to be allowed to work in Britain in January of last year. <83><82><82><82><93>It was crazy. There was this panic that the Romanians would invade.<83><82><82><82><9d>

It seems like a long time ago given what has happened in Europe since, but at the time the threat of a tidal wave of Romanian immigrants dominated headlines for months, prompting outpourings from Nigel Farage, questions in the Commons, and an entire primetime Channel 4 series, which sparked protests outside the British embassy in Bucharest.

<83><82><82><82><93>It had this very alarmist title,<83><82><82><82><9d> Lup<83><80><82>a says. <83><82><82><82><93>The Romanians Are Coming <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and it really played on these stereotypes. They followed this very poor man who had nine kids and didn<83><82><82><82><84>t speak English who came to try and find work in Britain. They weren<83><82><82><82><84>t really looking for the people who are creating branding campaigns in London.<83><82><82><82><9d>

I catch up on the first episode when I<83><82><82><82><84>m back in Britain and I see what he means. It features Gypsy beggars and a man getting his teeth fixed on the NHS. There was an attempt at some balance, but balance in the TV sense, so it included an episode on a Romanian princess.

But then, there<83><82><82><82><84>s the basic confusion in Britain over who Romanians actually are, Lup<83><80><82>a tells me. Most people in Britain don<83><82><82><82><84>t understand the difference between Roma people <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Gypsies <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and Romanians <83><82><82><82><80><9c> citizens of Romania. The two are endlessly conflated and confused not least because many Roma are Romanians <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the country is home to the biggest population in Europe. <83><82><82><82><93>A lot of people here get angry when some Roma go abroad and something bad happens. They feel like they are giving the country a bad name. It speaks to some deep prejudices that exist here. Racism and embedded prejudice.<83><82><82><82><9d>

In fact, Britain is just late to the party on this one. For centuries, all over Europe, Roma have been despised, discriminated against, excluded and, in the second world war, exterminated. In some ways we<83><82><82><82><84>re just playing catch-up. Do we really have such a negative view of Romanians? Or, have we just acquired one of Europe<83><82><82><82><84>s most ancient prejudices? Is it Gypsy-bashing by another name?

Whatever it is, it makes Andrei Tarnea uncomfortable. He<83><82><82><82><84>s the director of the Aspen Institute in Romania, an American nonprofit group, but tells me how he started out working in the foreign ministry in the 1990s. <83><82><82><82><93>And these very nice people who I came to know very well <83><82><82><82><80><9c> very ordinary, decent people <83><82><82><82><80><9c> displayed this very casual antisemitism all the time.<83><82><82><82><9d>

It struck Tarnea because, though they didn<83><82><82><82><84>t know it, he is a Jew, one of very few left in Romania <83><82><82><82><80><9c> those who weren<83><82><82><82><84>t killed in the Holocaust left in communist times. <83><82><82><82><93>One of my biggest fears is that the anti-Roma sentiment in Europe today very strongly mirrors what was going in the 1930s.<83><82><82><82><9d>

He<83><82><82><82><84>s something of a passionate European, Tarnea, and he<83><82><82><82><84>s already been talking fluently on the subject for an hour but he also can<83><82><82><82><84>t keep the agitation out of his voice. <83><82><82><82><93>It<83><82><82><82><84>s not just the things that Ukip says, or the Front National in France, but mainstream publications too. You hear the same discourse about foreigners, Romanians etc. And the gusto with which certain politicians use it for political ends, it<83><82><82><82><84>s very similar. Don<83><82><82><82><84>t forget that the first fascist government in Europe wasn<83><82><82><82><84>t Germany; it was, like now, in Hungary.

<83><82><82><82><93>It might sound ridiculous. But I have this almost irrational belief <83><82><82><82><80><9c> well, it<83><82><82><82><84>s not irrational, it<83><82><82><82><84>s actually perfectly rational <83><82><82><82><80><9c> that certain toxic ideas take on a life of their own. I feel Europe is at a turning point. And Britain staying in or [going] out may be a defining factor.<83><82><82><82><9d>

It<83><82><82><82><84>s striking how many Romanians are well informed on Brexit. But then, the idea of voluntarily exiting the union in which they were only recently accepted is preposterous. <83><82><82><82><93>It would be ridiculous for us. We were not part of Europe for 50 years,<83><82><82><82><9d> an investment banker called Matei Paun tells me. <83><82><82><82><93>To be very blunt, it just seems that in Britain there<83><82><82><82><84>s a considerable amount of hubris and arrogance involved. It<83><82><82><82><84>s a very myopic view of the world and what<83><82><82><82><84>s happening.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Of course, the idea that Romanians love Europe will simply reinforce the idea, for some people, that you<83><82><82><82><84>re living high on the hog, and we<83><82><82><82><84>re paying for it, I say.

<83><82><82><82><93>That<83><82><82><82><84>s because it<83><82><82><82><84>s never been properly explained that Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s 20 million consumers is a good thing for UK firms, let alone 100 million eastern Europeans.<83><82><82><82><9d>

But then, history <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and the traumatic effects of Europe<83><82><82><82><84>s recent history <83><82><82><82><80><9c> is a whole lot closer to the surface in Romania than it is Britain. It<83><82><82><82><84>s still dealing with the consequences of the second world war and its aftermath in very direct ways. Philip <83><92><82><80><9c> Ceallaigh, an Irish writer who lives in Bucharest, tells me how different those born in the 1990s are from the generation that preceded them. <83><82><82><82><93>They have no idea. Which is great. They are healthy. They really are no different from young people in western Europe whereas their parents are a different species. They were totally traumatised and still are to a degree.<83><82><82><82><9d>

I know what he means. I went to Romania in the winter of 1991, and of all the post-Soviet hellholes I visited during that period, the country seemed stuck in a different category of bleakness. I<83><82><82><82><84>ve never been anywhere where people just looked so beaten down and depressed. One of the saddest people I<83><82><82><82><84>ve ever encountered was a small boy on a Bucharest metro train who came barefoot into our carriage and played what sounded like a funeral dirge on his violin.

But the city really has changed. Its 19th-century buildings have been spruced up, you can take an English-speaking Uber driver instead of fighting to the death over the fare with a chain-smoking taxi driver, and then there are the hipsters. <83><82><82><82><93>Pulled pork has arrived,<83><82><82><82><9d> Lup<83><80><82>a tells me.

<83><92><82><80><9c> Ceallaigh went in the 1990s when such things appeared to be impossible fantasies and has been there more or less ever since. <83><82><82><82><93>I knew I wanted to be a writer and there<83><82><82><82><84>s no way I could afford to be one in Dublin. You can live very comfortably here on not much money.<83><82><82><82><9d> He<83><82><82><82><84>s just published an essay in Granta about the Bucharest that Ceau<83><80><82>escu swept away <83><82><82><82><80><9c> a third of the old city was bulldozed, six square kilometres, home to 57,000 people, including the entire Jewish quarter.

<83><82><82><82><93>It seems like it<83><82><82><82><84>s quite a frivolous debate in Britain. Britain doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t really need the EU and the EU doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t really need Britain. It wasn<83><82><82><82><84>t ruined by the 20th century in the way that most of the rest of Europe, and all of eastern Europe was. People tend to overlook how the EU came into existence. Everyone was killing each other and the continent was in ruins. It<83><82><82><82><84>s given us a generation of peace. Countries that were at war in the 1990s <83><82><82><82><80><9c> in the former Yugoslavia <83><82><82><82><80><9c> no longer are. Without the EU, Romania would have gone the way of Russia or Egypt. There was no institutional basis for democracy.<83><82><82><82><9d>

<83><92><82><80><9c> Ceallaigh<83><82><82><82><84>s new book is on European writers of the interwar period <83><82><82><82><80><9c> all Jewish <83><82><82><82><80><9c> when Bucharest, a multicultural city nicknamed the <83><82><82><82><93>Paris of the east<83><82><82><82><9d> bloomed, and he<83><82><82><82><84>s been immersed in the period. <83><82><82><82><93>The thing, as now, is that people took it for granted. They lived in an enlightened culture and they simply couldn<83><82><82><82><84>t envisage the kind of regimes that followed. We live in a similarly enlightened culture and we can<83><82><82><82><84>t conceive it either.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Later, I walk around Bucharest talking to young people involved in the creative arts <83><82><82><82><80><9c> all over Bucharest there are people doing interesting things and they all tell me how much easier it is to do things here, how much more impact they can have, how dynamic the city is in some ways compared to western Europe <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and it takes me a good 20 minutes to walk along the pavement that runs the length of the parliament building, the monstrous palace that Ceau<83><80><82>escu built that was the centrepiece of his new city.

It<83><82><82><82><84>s still as grim as I remember it being. A daily reminder of what happens when you get caught on the wrong side of history. It<83><82><82><82><84>s not surprising that the debate about Europe looks so different from here. Just look at the neighbours: a collapsing Ukraine is right next door. <83><82><82><82><93>I think Europe is losing its soul,<83><82><82><82><9d> Andrei Tarnea tells me. <83><82><82><82><93>In Britain, the discussion stops at the wallet and the ballot box.<83><82><82><82><9d> The questions simply look bigger from here.

There<83><82><82><82><84>s a lone tourist taking a photograph of the palace. Because while the city has its attractions and there<83><82><82><82><84>s been some hopeful talk of Bucharest being the new Berlin, nobody I meet actually manages to say it with a straight face, and most tourists head straight to Transylvania, home to Dracula, and also, intermittently, Prince Charles. He owns a couple of guesthouses there and has set up a Romanian foundation. John Akeroyd, a naturalist who has accompanied him on his forays into the Romanian countryside, tells me that <83><82><82><82><93>it<83><82><82><82><84>s the last place in Europe that has the same extensive landscape that existed in the 18th century or even medieval times. It<83><82><82><82><84>s probably why Prince Charles likes it. It<83><82><82><82><84>s like the Cotswolds would have been in the 18th century.<83><82><82><82><9d>

But then according to Michael Bird, an English journalist who runs an investigative website based in Bucharest, Romania tends to <83><82><82><82><93>inspire two extreme reactions in the British press. Either it<83><82><82><82><84>s a hellhole for the rightwing press. Or it has this mysterious romanticism. It<83><82><82><82><84>s where the middle ages meets totalitarianism. Nineteen Eighty-Four meets Game of Thrones.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Back in London, in my local coffee shop, I chat to the only Romanian I know, Mike <83><82><82><82><80><9c> actually Mihai <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the friendly barista. Is it true we have a negative view of Romanians? <83><82><82><82><93>You do but it<83><82><82><82><84>s understandable.<83><82><82><82><9d> Understandable? <83><82><82><82><93>People see these guys begging. Who wants that? On the other hand, it<83><82><82><82><84>s mostly ignorance. People say, <83><82><82><82><9c>They<83><82><82><82><84>re taking our jobs!<83><82><82><82><84> Dude, if you want the job, it<83><82><82><82><84>s yours. Come and do it.<83><82><82><82><9d>

It was crazy. There was this panic that the Romanians would invade.
