It had this very alarmist title, Lupa says. The Romanians Are Coming  and it really played on these stereotypes. They followed this very poor man who had nine kids and didnt speak English who came to try and find work in Britain. They werent really looking for the people who are creating branding campaigns in London. I catch up on the first episode when Im back in Britain and I see what he means. It features Gypsy beggars and a man getting his teeth fixed on the NHS. There was an attempt at some balance, but balance in the TV sense, so it included an episode on a Romanian princess. But then, theres the basic confusion in Britain over who Romanians actually are, Lupa tells me. Most people in Britain dont understand the difference between Roma people  Gypsies  and Romanians  citizens of Romania. The two are endlessly conflated and confused not least because many Roma are Romanians  the country is home to the biggest population in Europe. A lot of people here get angry when some Roma go abroad and something bad happens. They feel like they are giving the country a bad name. It speaks to some deep prejudices that exist here. Racism and embedded prejudice. In fact, Britain is just late to the party on this one. For centuries, all over Europe, Roma have been despised, discriminated against, excluded and, in the second world war, exterminated. In some ways were just playing catch-up. Do we really have such a negative view of Romanians? Or, have we just acquired one of Europes most ancient prejudices? Is it Gypsy-bashing by another name? Whatever it is, it makes Andrei Tarnea uncomfortable. Hes the director of the Aspen Institute in Romania, an American nonprofit group, but tells me how he started out working in the foreign ministry in the 1990s. And these very nice people who I came to know very well  very ordinary, decent people  displayed this very casual antisemitism all the time. It struck Tarnea because, though they didnt know it, he is a Jew, one of very few left in Romania  those who werent killed in the Holocaust left in communist times. One of my biggest fears is that the anti-Roma sentiment in Europe today very strongly mirrors what was going in the 1930s. Hes something of a passionate European, Tarnea, and hes already been talking fluently on the subject for an hour but he also cant keep the agitation out of his voice. Its not just the things that Ukip says, or the Front National in France, but mainstream publications too. You hear the same discourse about foreigners, Romanians etc. And the gusto with which certain politicians use it for political ends, its very similar. Dont forget that the first fascist government in Europe wasnt Germany; it was, like now, in Hungary. It might sound ridiculous. But I have this almost irrational belief  well, its not irrational, its actually perfectly rational  that certain toxic ideas take on a life of their own. I feel Europe is at a turning point. And Britain staying in or [going] out may be a defining factor. Its striking how many Romanians are well informed on Brexit. But then, the idea of voluntarily exiting the union in which they were only recently accepted is preposterous. It would be ridiculous for us. We were not part of Europe for 50 years, an investment banker called Matei Paun tells me. To be very blunt, it just seems that in Britain theres a considerable amount of hubris and arrogance involved. Its a very myopic view of the world and whats happening. Of course, the idea that Romanians love Europe will simply reinforce the idea, for some people, that youre living high on the hog, and were paying for it, I say. Thats because its never been properly explained that Romanias 20million consumers is a good thing for UK firms, let alone 100 million eastern Europeans. But then, history  and the traumatic effects of Europes recent history  is a whole lot closer to the surface in Romania than it is Britain. Its still dealing with the consequences of the second world war and its aftermath in very direct ways. Philip  Ceallaigh, an Irish writer who lives in Bucharest, tells me how different those born in the 1990s are from the generation that preceded them. They have no idea. Which is great. They are healthy. They really are no different from young people in western Europe whereas their parents are a different species. They were totally traumatised and still are to a degree. I know what he means. I went to Romania in the winter of 1991, and of all the post-Soviet hellholes I visited during that period, the country seemed stuck in a different category of bleakness. Ive never been anywhere where people just looked so beaten down and depressed. One of the saddest people Ive ever encountered was a small boy on a Bucharest metro train who came barefoot into our carriage and played what sounded like a funeral dirge on his violin. But the city really has changed. Its 19th-century buildings have been spruced up, you can take an English-speaking Uber driver instead of fighting to the death over the fare with a chain-smoking taxi driver, and then there are the hipsters. Pulled pork has arrived, Lupa tells me.  Ceallaigh went in the 1990s when such things appeared to be impossible fantasies and has been there more or less ever since. I knew I wanted to be a writer and theres no way I could afford to be one in Dublin. You can live very comfortably here on not much money. Hes just published an essay in Granta about the Bucharest that Ceauescu swept away  a third of the old city was bulldozed, six square kilometres, home to 57,000 people, including the entire Jewish quarter. It seems like its quite a frivolous debate in Britain. Britain doesnt really need the EU and the EU doesnt really need Britain. It wasnt ruined by the 20th century in the way that most of the rest of Europe, and all of eastern Europe was. People tend to overlook how the EU came into existence. Everyone was killing each other and the continent was in ruins. Its given us a generation of peace. Countries that were at war in the 1990s  in the former Yugoslavia  no longer are. Without the EU, Romania would have gone the way of Russia or Egypt. There was no institutional basis for democracy.  Ceallaighs new book is on European writers of the interwar period  all Jewish  when Bucharest, a multicultural city nicknamed the Paris of the east bloomed, and hes been immersed in the period. The thing, as now, is that people took it for granted. They lived in an enlightened culture and they simply couldnt envisage the kind of regimes that followed. We live in a similarly enlightened culture and we cant conceive it either. Later, I walk around Bucharest talking to young people involved in the creative arts  all over Bucharest there are people doing interesting things and they all tell me how much easier it is to do things here, how much more impact they can have, how dynamic the city is in some ways compared to western Europe  and it takes me a good 20 minutes to walk along the pavement that runs the length of the parliament building, the monstrous palace that Ceauescu built that was the centrepiece of his new city. Its still as grim as I remember it being. A daily reminder of what happens when you get caught on the wrong side of history. Its not surprising that the debate about Europe looks so different from here. Just look at the neighbours: a collapsing Ukraine is right next door. I think Europe is losing its soul, Andrei Tarnea tells me. In Britain, the discussion stops at the wallet and the ballot box. The questions simply look bigger from here. Theres a lone tourist taking a photograph of the palace. Because while the city has its attractions and theres been some hopeful talk of Bucharest being the new Berlin, nobody I meet actually manages to say it with a straight face, and most tourists head straight to Transylvania, home to Dracula, and also, intermittently, Prince Charles. He owns a couple of guesthouses there and has set up a Romanian foundation. John Akeroyd, a naturalist who has accompanied him on his forays into the Romanian countryside, tells me that its the last place in Europe that has the same extensive landscape that existed in the 18th century or even medieval times. Its probably why Prince Charles likes it. Its like the Cotswolds would have been in the 18th century. But then according to Michael Bird, an English journalist who runs an investigative website based in Bucharest, Romania tends to inspire two extreme reactions in the British press. Either its a hellhole for the rightwing press. Or it has this mysterious romanticism. Its where the middle ages meets totalitarianism. Nineteen Eighty-Four meets Game of Thrones. Back in London, in my local coffee shop, I chat to the only Romanian I know, Mike  actually Mihai  the friendly barista. Is it true we have a negative view of Romanians? You do but its understandable. Understandable? People see these guys begging. Who wants that? On the other hand, its mostly ignorance. People say, Theyre taking our jobs! Dude, if you want the job, its yours. Come and do it.

webTitle: Golden Goal: Ilie Dumitrescu for Romania v Argentina (1994) | Tom Davies
trailText: Dumitrescuâs second goal against Argentina in the last 16 of the World Cup was neither a dazzling solo effort nor a long-range howitzer but it surpassed all others scored at USA 94 and crystallised all of Romaniaâs strengths
headline: Golden Goal: Ilie Dumitrescu for Romania v Argentina (1994)
standfirst: Dumitrescuâs second goal against Argentina in the last 16 of the World Cup was neither a dazzling solo effort nor a long-range howitzer but it surpassed all others scored at USA 94 and crystallised all of Romaniaâs strengths
body:
Every generation of World Cup watchers has its cherished romantic failures. For a whole swathe of fans, Brazil<83><82><82><82><84>s beautiful losers of 1982 were formative, in both opening their eyes to a whole new way in which the game could be played and in giving the brutal lesson that such teams usually fall short, often in heartbreaking fashion.

That team of Zico, Falc<83><92><82>o, Eder et al became the standard-bearers of a certain type of poignant choke but there are others less celebrated: France in 1986 maybe; Argentina in 2006; perhaps even Ghana in 2010, denied a semi-final slot by Luis Su<83><92><82>rez<83><82><82><82><84>s sleight of hand.

Related: Golden Goal: Cristiano Ronaldo for Manchester United v Arsenal (2009) | Rob Smyth

However, perhaps the most undeservedly unsung of all World Cup romantic failures distinguished themselves in the next showpiece following the <83><82><82><82><84>82 heartache that Brazil actually won <83><82><82><82><80><9c> USA 94. They wore yellow, they attacked with dash and panache, they were cajoled by an extravagantly gifted superstar-playmaker, they supplied the tournament<83><82><82><82><84>s best match and goal <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and they fell short, agonisingly, on penalties. Not Brazil, of course <83><82><82><82><80><9c> corporately hyped but functional and unattractive champions <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but the Gheorghe Hagi-inspired Romanians, who peaked just a little too soon in their second-round 3-2 win over Argentina, a match that has probably not been bettered in the knockout stages of a World Cup since.

Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s emergence had been evident at the previous World Cup. Inevitably accompanied by a narrative of post-Ceausescu optimism, the reviled ruler having been toppled only six months previously, Romania stepped out of the shadows at Italia 90, reaching the knockout stages for the first time, where they dominated but were unable to break down Jack Charlton<83><82><82><82><84>s Republic of Ireland at their most obdurately Charlton-esque, losing on penalties. Only one of their squad played outside Romania; by 1994, eight did, including the captain, Hagi, at Brescia, Florin Raducioiu at Milan and Dan Petrescu at Genoa. The well-regarded coach Anghel Iordanescu, a European Cup winner with Steaua Bucharest in 1986, had plenty to work with, then, when he took the reins in 1993.

The 1994 World Cup came at an intriguingly transitional moment in modern football<83><82><82><82><84>s evolution. The first major tournament of the Champions League/Premier League era, it showcased an emerging globalisation of the game at a time when prevailing attitudes were simultaneously becoming more outward-looking yet more elitist, hence the unmerited fawning over the easily marketable Brazil and Italy as <83><82><82><82><93>dream finalists<83><82><82><82><9d> during the tournament. Tactics were changing, styles were changing <83><82><82><82><80><9c> mostly for the better after the turgid Italia 90 and the recalibration ushered in by the introduction of the backpass rule in 1992. Although England were absent <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and not remotely missed <83><82><82><82><80><9c> USA 94 would stamp its mark all over the Premier League, most obviously in the slew of not always successful signings made by English clubs of many of its star performers.

Which brings us back to Ilie Dumitrescu and Romania <83><82><82><82><80><9c> unheralded, unmarketed and the most attractive side of the tournament by some distance, until they fell at the quarter-final stage.

They could have fallen much earlier. The roots of their romantic story began with the thwarting of another <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Wales<83><82><82><82><84>s charge for a first finals place since 1958. Qualification was sealed amid drama and tragedy in Cardiff in November 1993, Romania winning their final qualifier 2-1 with goals from Hagi and Raducioiu, a victory that owed much to Paul Bodin<83><82><82><82><84>s pivotal penalty miss at 1-1 in a match overshadowed by the death of a fan, John Hill, who was hit by a flare fired across the Arms Park stands after the match. Romania had played wonderfully well that evening and were deserved winners but their excellence did not receive much attention amid the match<83><82><82><82><84>s flurry of talking points. Thus was an under-the-radar pattern established.

The draw for the finals pitted them against Colombia, USA and Switzerland, with Colombia up first in Los Angeles. If any team were the dark-horse picks going into the tournament, they were Colombia. Celebrated 5-0 maulers of Argentina a year earlier, the team of Carlos Valderrama, Tino Asprilla and co promised much and on 18 June, a day that had already produced one of the great World Cup occasions <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Ireland<83><82><82><82><84>s 1-0 win over Italy in a New York turned raucously green in celebration <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Colombia v Romania was set to provide the most invigorating of nightcaps.

Which it did <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but not in the manner forecast. Romania, playing with speed and verve on the counterattack, won 3-1, Hagi<83><82><82><82><84>s speculative/stunning long-range effort from wide on the left touchline the highlight of a terrific performance. (As in Cardiff seven months earlier, tangential but genuine tragedy was to accompany Romanian progress here, too <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Colombia<83><82><82><82><84>s first-round exit was followed by the murder of their defender Andr<83><92><82>s Escobar, scorer of an own goal in their defeat by the USA in their second match).

If victory at the Rose Bowl flagged up Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s potential as the new dark horses, their second match suggested where it might all go wrong: a second-half collapse in the sweltering indoor Silverdome in Detroit gave Switzerland a 4-1 win, which left Romania needing at least a point to progress. Their final group opponents: the newly cock-a-hoop hosts, buoyed by the win over Colombia and a creditable draw with the Swiss in their opener. But Romania squeaked through, eking out a 1-0 win through a smart Hagi-engineered goal on the break that was to prove a portent of greater highs to come, Petrescu providing the finish with a low, angled shot that caught out the USA goalkeeper, Tony Meola, at the near post.

Victory ensured Romania topped their group, earning a second-round tie against Argentina, one of the four best third-placed teams in the convoluted 24-team format. Some vague semblance of wordcount discipline dictates that we must not divert too deeply into the colourful details of Argentina<83><82><82><82><84>s own campaign but some context is certainly required. Memories of Argentina<83><82><82><82><84>s ugly contribution to the 1990 final <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and that of their tearful and sulky captain Diego Maradona that night in Rome <83><82><82><82><80><9c> hung heavily over the two-times winners at the start of USA 94, and their reputation in the eyes of many, particularly an English media still wont to play the aggrieved Hand of God card, lay unsalvaged.

Related: Golden Goal: Ken McNaught for Aston Villa v Barcelona (1982 Super Cup) | Paul Doyle

However, they came out of the blocks with a swagger in the States, blitzing Greece 4-0 thanks to a turbo-charged Maradona display, and securing progress to the knockout stage with a 2-1 win over an impressive Nigeria in an excellent match in Boston, after which their momentum was jolted when Maradona failed a drugs test for ephedrine doping and was booted out of the tournament, the dream of a golden career-autumn signoff for the game<83><82><82><82><84>s greatest player ignominiously destroyed. Argentina duly lost their third game, 0-2 to the tournament<83><82><82><82><84>s other great dark horses, Bulgaria, which consigned them to third place in their group <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and a second-round meeting with Romania.

Argentina remained the favourites but there was a sense that the momentum was with Romania for the tie at the Rose Bowl, although the latter would be without the suspended striker Raducioiu. Maradona<83><82><82><82><84>s departure inevitably cast its shadow. Yet this was still a positive and inventive Argentinian side, who through talents such as Gabriel Batistuta, Fernando Redondo and the emerging Ariel Ortega, could take a game to anyone, as they did in the opening stages on this occasion in Pasadena. However, Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s counterattacking <83><82><82><82><80><9c> as canny as it was easy on the eye <83><82><82><82><80><9c> had their measure and they drew first blood in the 11th minute. Steaua Bucharest<83><82><82><82><84>s Dumitrescu <83><82><82><82><80><9c> pushed into a more attacking role for this match by Raducioiu<83><82><82><82><84>s absence <83><82><82><82><80><9c> curled a free-kick from the left into the opposite corner after the goalkeeper Luis Islas was spotted off his line, to register his first goal of the tournament.

Argentina<83><82><82><82><84>s response was swift, Batistuta winning and converting a debatable penalty five minutes later after being nudged off the ball by Daniel Prodan near the byline. A breathless pattern of attack and counterattack was thereby established, a pattern that suited Romania perfectly and through which they regained the lead after 18 minutes with the most exquisitely subtle goal of the World Cup.

Back then, goal of the tournament contenders were <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and indeed mainly still are <83><82><82><82><80><9c> generally believed to fall into two broad categories: the dazzling solo effort or the thunderous and unstoppable long-range howitzer. Goals that come from a casually dinked finish just outside the six-yard box past a haplessly wrongfooted goalkeeper tick neither box. Yet Dumitrescu<83><82><82><82><84>s effort surpassed all others scored that summer, and crystallised all his team<83><82><82><82><84>s strengths.

The move began deep in Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s half with the dispossession of Redondo, effectively closed down and crowded out, and enabling Petrescu to pick up possession. He worked it wide on the right to Hagi, who produced his first magical contribution to the move by clipping the ball beyond two markers into space for the onrushing Dumitrescu, who swiftly returned it to the captain back out on the right touchline. Hagi, by now almost level with the penalty area, faced a wall of four Argentinian defenders as he advanced and prepared to cross.

Had a photographer been behind his eyeline, they could have snapped something akin to the celebrated shot of a lone Maradona confronting a solid line of Belgian opponents in 1982. The Maradona of the Carpathians <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the somewhat stilted nickname bestowed upon Hagi <83><82><82><82><80><9c> had the game in the palm of his hand, though. A master of adjusting the pace of play to his requirements, he spotted that Dumitrescu had continued his run and conjured the most majestic and precise low curved cross that took out all four defenders and ran perfectly into the path of his unmarked and onside team-mate <83><82><82><82><80><9c> <83><82><82><82><93>a genius pass<83><82><82><82><9d>, said Dumitrescu afterwards. The back line carved apart, Dumitrescu played his part by keeping nerve and head and artfully wrongfooting Chamot with a delightful, almost gentle, near-post finish that nestled in the left-hand corner of the goalkeeper<83><82><82><82><84>s net. This was no fluke, this was the team of the moment elegantly taking control.

There was also a nonchalant class to Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s third goal in the 58th minute <83><82><82><82><80><9c> another breakaway, another piece of Hagi-Dumitrescu telepathy, the latter turning creator this time, delaying his rolled path into Hagi<83><82><82><82><84>s path with almost contemptuous ease for the captain to belt the ball into the roof of the net. Abel Balbo pulled one back for Argentina with a quarter of an hour remaining to set up the kind of compelling, nervous finish that cemented the match<83><82><82><82><84>s classic status <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but Romania held on. <83><82><82><82><93>Romania are fast emerging as the surprise team of the tournament and Hagi its outstanding individual,<83><82><82><82><9d> Paul Wilson wrote in the following day<83><82><82><82><84>s Guardian.

And yet, and yet <83><82><82><82> they couldn<83><82><82><82><84>t build on it. Paired with Sweden in the quarter-finals, in the first match of the finals in which they could truly be adjudged favourites, Romania never quite found the same fluency, although they still played their part in a gripping tie that went to extra-time at 1-1, and when Raducioiu<83><82><82><82><84>s second goal of the match put them ahead after 101 minutes, the dream looked set to continue. However, Kennet Anderson struck with five minutes remaining, Sweden won 5-4 on penalties and USA 94 had seen the last of Hagi<83><82><82><82><84>s glorious side.

Romania never rescaled the heights reached in that golden summer, although they remained a creditable international side for the remainder of that decade, beating and outpassing England en route to making the knockout stages at both France 98 and Euro 2000. Dumitrescu (Tottenham and West Ham) and Raducioiu (West Ham) had fitful stints in the Premier League on the back of their performances in the US, while Petrescu became a consistent high-end performer at Chelsea. Iordanescu, meanwhile, is now back in charge of the national team going into this year<83><82><82><82><84>s expanded European Championship <83><82><82><82><80><9c> his third stint as national coach <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but his side go to France 2016 as rank outsiders, exciting little optimism; the days in which his country were standard-bearers for a renascent eastern Europe long gone. Indeed, only two eastern European sides have reached the last eight of the World Cup since the heady days of USA 94 <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Croatia in 1998 and Ukraine eight years later. The recent sad death of the Trifon Ivanov, uncompromising stalwart of the charismatic Bulgaria side that knocked out Germany and reached the semi-finals in the States, stirred further fond memories of a tournament that still divides opinion.

One of the reasons it does is that USA 94 began to unravel a little after its quarter-finals. Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s departure deprived us of what would have been a fascinating, defining match between Old Brazil and New Brazil in the semi-finals, and perhaps after that a final against the Roberto-Baggio-and-10-others combination that had somehow staggered into the final in the Azzurri shirts of Italy. Two winnable fixtures for a Romania side playing as well as they had until the game against Argentina. The real dream final a fine World Cup deserved would have pitted Romania against the other beaten semi-finalists, the Bulgaria of Hristo Stoitchkov and co. A sponsor<83><82><82><82><84>s nightmare but in 1994 a purist<83><82><82><82><84>s dream. However, World Cups do not pan out like that <83><82><82><82><80><9c> we<83><82><82><82><84>d learned that in <83><82><82><82><84>82.

Yet this was still a positive and inventive Argentinian side, who through talents such as Gabriel Batistuta, Fernando Redondo and the emerging Ariel Ortega, could take a game to anyone, as they did in the opening stages on this occasion in Pasadena. However, Romanias counterattacking  as canny as it was easy on the eye  had their measure and they drew first blood in the 11th minute. Steaua Bucharests Dumitrescu  pushed into a more attacking role for this match by Raducioius absence  curled a free-kick from the left into the opposite corner after the goalkeeper Luis Islas was spotted off his line, to register his first goal of the tournament. Argentinas response was swift, Batistuta winning and converting a debatable penalty five minutes later after being nudged off the ball by Daniel Prodan near the byline. A breathless pattern of attack and counterattack was thereby established, a pattern that suited Romania perfectly and through which they regained the lead after 18 minutes with the most exquisitely subtle goal of the World Cup. Back then, goal of the tournament contenders were  and indeed mainly still are  generally believed to fall into two broad categories: the dazzling solo effort or the thunderous and unstoppable long-range howitzer. Goals that come from a casually dinked finish just outside the six-yard box past a haplessly wrongfooted goalkeeper tick neither box. Yet Dumitrescus effort surpassed all others scored that summer, and crystallised all his teams strengths. The move began deep in Romanias half with the dispossession of Redondo, effectively closed down and crowded out, and enabling Petrescu to pick up possession. He worked it wide on the right to Hagi, who produced his first magical contribution to the move by clipping the ball beyond two markers into space for the onrushing Dumitrescu, who swiftly returned it to the captain back out on the right touchline. Hagi, by now almost level with the penalty area, faced a wall of four Argentinian defenders as he advanced and prepared to cross.  Had a photographer been behind his eyeline, they could have snapped something akin to the celebrated shot of a lone Maradona confronting a solid line of Belgian opponents in 1982. The Maradona of the Carpathians  the somewhat stilted nickname bestowed upon Hagi  had the game in the palm of his hand, though. A master of adjusting the pace of play to his requirements, he spotted that Dumitrescu had continued his run and conjured the most majestic and precise low curved cross that took out all four defenders and ran perfectly into the path of his unmarked and onside team-mate  a genius pass, said Dumitrescu afterwards. The back line carved apart, Dumitrescu played his part by keeping nerve and head and artfully wrongfooting Chamot with a delightful, almost gentle, near-post finish that nestled in the left-hand corner of the goalkeepers net. This was no fluke, this was the team of the moment elegantly taking control. There was also a nonchalant class to Romanias third goal in the 58th minute  another breakaway, another piece of Hagi-Dumitrescu telepathy, the latter turning creator this time, delaying his rolled path into Hagis path with almost contemptuous ease for the captain to belt the ball into the roof of the net. Abel Balbo pulled one back for Argentina with a quarter of an hour remaining to set up the kind of compelling, nervous finish that cemented the matchs classic status  but Romania held on. Romania are fast emerging as the surprise team of the tournament and Hagi its outstanding individual, Paul Wilson wrote in the following days Guardian. And yet, and yet  they couldnt build on it. Paired with Sweden in the quarter-finals, in the first match of the finals in which they could truly be adjudged favourites, Romania never quite found the same fluency, although they still played their part in a gripping tie that went to extra-time at 1-1, and when Raducioius second goal of the match put them ahead after 101 minutes, the dream looked set to continue. However, Kennet Anderson struck with five minutes remaining, Sweden won 5-4 on penalties and USA 94 had seen the last of Hagis glorious side. Romania never rescaled the heights reached in that golden summer, although they remained a creditable international side for the remainder of that decade, beating and outpassing England en route to making the knockout stages at both France 98 and Euro 2000. Dumitrescu (Tottenham and West Ham) and Raducioiu (West Ham) had fitful stints in the Premier League on the back of their performances in the US, while Petrescu became a consistent high-end performer at Chelsea. Iordanescu, meanwhile, is now back in charge of the national team going into this years expanded European Championship  his third stint as national coach  but his side go to France 2016 as rank outsiders, exciting little optimism; the days in which his country were standard-bearers for a renascent eastern Europe long gone. Indeed, only two eastern European sides have reached the last eight of the World Cup since the heady days of USA 94  Croatia in 1998 and Ukraine eight years later. The recent sad death of the Trifon Ivanov, uncompromising stalwart of the charismatic Bulgaria side that knocked out Germany and reached the semi-finals in the States, stirred further fond memories of a tournament that still divides opinion. One of the reasons it does is that USA 94 began to unravel a little after its quarter-finals. Romanias departure deprived us of what would have been a fascinating, defining match between Old Brazil and New Brazil in the semi-finals, and perhaps after that a final against the Roberto-Baggio-and-10-others combination that had somehow staggered into the final in the Azzurri shirts of Italy. Two winnable fixtures for a Romania side playing as well as they had until the game against Argentina. The real dream final a fine World Cup deserved would have pitted Romania against the other beaten semi-finalists, the Bulgaria of Hristo Stoitchkov and co. A sponsors nightmare but in 1994 a purists dream. However, World Cups do not pan out like that  wed learned that in 82.

webTitle: Admir Mehmedi crashes home to rescue point for Switzerland against Romania
trailText: Switzerlandâs Admir Mehmedi thumped home a fizzing volley to give his side a share of the spoils after Bogdan Stancuâs second penalty of the tournament for Romania
headline: Admir Mehmedi crashes home to rescue point for Switzerland against Romania
standfirst: NA
byline: David Hytner at Parc des Princes
body:
Switzerland had shouldered a great weight of history and the parallels had looked clear. One of the nation<83><82><82><82><84>s greatest results had come against Romania, in the second group tie at the 1994 World Cup, when a thumping 4-1 victory got them through to the last 16. A guy called Roy Hodgson was their manager at the time.

The challenge here for Vladimir Petkovic and his players was to write a new chapter of success; to fire qualification to the knockout phase of the European Championship for the first time.

Related: Marek Hamsik<83><82><82><82><84>s sumptuous strike gives Slovakia the edge over Russia

They did not manage to emulate Alain Sutter and the class of 94 in terms of the result or performance but, in this expanded championship, where so few teams fall at the group phase, the draw <83><82><82><82><80><9c> on the back of their 1-0 victory over Albania last Saturday <83><82><82><82><80><9c> ought to be enough to send them through.

Switzerland were the better team, they were the more forward-thinking and, after the criticism that followed the disjointed performance against Albania, who had played for most of the game with 10 men, Petkovic could feel happier.

This was a glimpse of the team<83><82><82><82><84>s potential and in Granit Xhaka, Arsenal<83><82><82><82><84>s new midfield signing, Switzerland had the game<83><82><82><82><84>s outstanding talent. It was a pleasure to watch his range of passing. Like all of the best players Xhaka seems to have an extra second or two on the ball, before any tackles come in on him.

The downside was Switzerland<83><82><82><82><84>s profligacy. They created a clutch of presentable chances only for a mixture of poor finishing and the reactions of Ciprian Tatarusanu, the Romania goalkeeper, to thwart them.

<83><82><82><82><93>We will not create eight good chances against France,<83><82><82><82><9d> Xhaka said, looking ahead to his team<83><82><82><82><84>s final Group A tie. <83><82><82><82><93>We have to start scoring. It is the last wheel in our system.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Switzerland<83><82><82><82><84>s goal was a beauty and it came from Admir Mehmedi, after Ricardo Rodr<83><92><82>guez<83><82><82><82><84>s corner had ricocheted off Johan Djourou. Mehmedi<83><82><82><82><84>s technique was perfect and his left-foot shot flew into the far corner of the net.

It cancelled out Bogdan Stancu<83><82><82><82><84>s 18th-minute penalty for a Romania team who could also have regrets, not least in the shape of the two clear chances they passed up midway though the first half. Alexandru Chipciu cut inside and banged a right-foot shot past the far post and Cristian Sapunaru spun and clipped the far upright, after Gabriel Torje<83><82><82><82><84>s free-kick had sparked panic.

Romania showed resilience and fight <83><82><82><82><80><9c> they had four players booked <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and the main thing was that they did not lose. With Albania to come, they, too, retain a shot at the last 16. Once again, however, they were unhinged by a wonder goal. Their 2-1 defeat by France on the opening night, when they had performed creditably, was triggered by Dimitri Payet<83><82><82><82><84>s 89th-minute rocket.

Anghel Iordanescu had been Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s manager at the 1994 World Cup and here, in his third spell in charge, he made sweeping and surprising changes from the France game. Among the four players he rested was the No10, Nicolae Stanciu, who had excelled in the opening match. Iordanescu said his players had been <83><82><82><82><93>suffering physically<83><82><82><82><9d> with the matches coming so close together.

Romania went ahead early on and, as against France, their goal was a penalty. Stephan Lichtsteiner had Chipciu<83><82><82><82><84>s shirt, and it was no mere grab, which was enough for the Russian referee, Sergei Karasev. As against France again, Stancu converted. <83><82><82><82><93>If you whistle for that, then you will have a lot of penalties,<83><82><82><82><9d> Petkovic complained. Lichtsteiner, though, ought to have been smarter.

By then Switzerland could and should have been in front but, from two excellent chances, Haris Seferovic could not finish. First he tricked inside Vlad Chiriches to open up the shooting chance, only to put his effort wide and then, confronted by Tatarusanu, he was denied by the goalkeeper.

It was lively and entertaining, if not particularly structured, which was no bad thing for the neutral. Switzerland had further first-half chances, with Fabian Sch<83><92><82>r working Tatarusanu from 25 yards and Blerim Dzemaili heading wide when gloriously placed on 39 minutes, from Lichtsteiner<83><82><82><82><84>s cross.

Romania have been notoriously parsimonious; they conceded only twice in their 10 qualification ties and Switzerland faced a test of their mettle. They would have been further behind in the 52nd minute were it not for a crucial intervention by Djourou, who stretched to put Torje<83><82><82><82><84>s volleyed cross behind for a corner. Behind him, for what would have been a tap-in, had been Claudiu Keseru.

Mehmedi<83><82><82><82><84>s equaliser came at a moment when the substitute, Breel Embolo, was stripped and ready to come on. Embolo had replaced Mehmedi in the Albania game and it was easy to think Petkovic was about to make the same change. After Mehmedi<83><82><82><82><84>s shot had hit the net, Petkovic stood Embolo down.

The 19-year-old would replace Seferovic in the 64th minute. Switzerland pressed for the winner but they did not truly threaten it. Mehmedi<83><82><82><82><84>s goal had lit up the occasion.

webTitle: Gianni De Biasi rues Albanias missed chances as Romania eye last 16
trailText: There is a sense of what might have been for Albania after two narrow defeats, while Romania are relying on their defence to reach the knockout stage
headline: Gianni De Biasi rues Albaniaâs missed chances as Romania eye last 16
standfirst:
â¢ âI still believe we can qualifyâ De Biasi insists despite two defeats
â¢ Romania can finish second in Group A if France beat Switzerland
body:
It may have been a wilful attempt to keep expectations at rock bottom but pre-tournament discussion in Albania centred for the most part on the nation<83><82><82><82><84>s happiness to have reached their first tournament. <83><82><82><82><93>A dream,<83><82><82><82><9d> said the manager, Gianni De Biasi, on the eve of their opening game, intimating that the real achievement was just getting to France. Now they are two games in, the feeling must be some way different.

Before an eminently winnable group closer against Romania a sense of what might have been has crept in. The Switzerland match, where they fell behind early on but created numerous chances, slipped away on account of the captain Lorik Cana<83><82><82><82><84>s entirely avoidable sending off in the first half. Against France they defended brilliantly for 89 minutes before breaking at the death, conceding twice for a largely undeserved 2-0 defeat.

Related: Euro 2016: France into last 16 after late show against Albania

<83><82><82><82><93>My team resisted right until the end but we didn<83><82><82><82><84>t defend throughout, especially in the first half and at the start of the second,<83><82><82><82><9d> De Biasi said. <83><82><82><82><93>When you don<83><82><82><82><84>t take your chances and score goals, you don<83><82><82><82><84>t get big results. My team held up pretty well and we<83><82><82><82><84>re disappointed to concede a goal a minute from the end.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Albania still retain a slim chance of progressing to the last 16, though it appears unlikely. To do so would require a heavy win to ensure a positive goal difference. And even then they would have to watch the other groups play to completion, hoping that two third-placed sides finish with weaker records.

While De Biasi says <83><82><82><82><93>I believe we can qualify<83><82><82><82><9d>, Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s defence does not look like giving too many chances away. Though they have conceded twice to France and once to Switzerland, Anghel Iordanescu<83><82><82><82><84>s team <83><82><82><82><80><9c> shipping just two goals in qualifying <83><82><82><82><80><9c> are renowned for their rearguard.

Related: Admir Mehmedi crashes home to rescue point for Switzerland against Romania

Instead Iordanescu<83><82><82><82><84>s biggest concern is in attack. Both their goals have come from the penalty spot, put away clinically by the midfielder Bogdan Stancu in each game, though victory by any scoreline is likely to ensure their progress <83><82><82><82><80><9c> at least as one of the best four third-placed finishers. If France beat Switzerland and Romania win, then Romania could go through in second depending on goal difference.

No wonder, then, the striker Florin Andone has descended into hyperbole. He has described this match as a matter of <83><82><82><82><93>life and death<83><82><82><82><9d>.

Andone was dropped for the 1-1 draw against Switzerland but is in line for a recall in Lyon after his replacement, Claudiu Keseru, disappointed.

<83><82><82><82><93>We must show the mentality of winners against Albania,<83><82><82><82><9d> he told Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s Digi Sport television. <83><82><82><82><93>It will be very difficult because Albania are a very good team, they run a lot and are very aggressive. But we are aware that a victory could send us through so we will give it a 100% effort.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The now or never stakes promise a more attacking game, with both managers expected to change personnel and, in Albania<83><82><82><82><84>s case, shape. Andone is likely to lead Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s 4-2-3-1, with Ovidiu Hoban tipped to start in midfield in place of the injured Mihai Pintilii. Cana will return to Albania<83><82><82><82><84>s defence but, most notably, De Biasi is tempted to return to a 4-3-3 after packing midfield with five players for France. The midfielder Burim Kukeli is suspended, after being booked in both games, and the 22-year-old Ergys Kace is poised to deputise.

webTitle: Vlad Chiriches: how defender bounced back from Spurs spell to lead Romania from the back
trailText: The former Tottenham centre-back is now with Napoli in Italy and is âdreaming of making a historical performanceâ at Euro 2016
headline: Vlad Chiriches: how defender bounced back from Spurs spell to lead Romania from the back
standfirst: The former Tottenham centre-back is now with Napoli in Italy and is âdreaming of making a historical performanceâ at Euro 2016
body:
Vlad Chiriches has not had an easy time of things at club level with either Tottenham Hotspur or Napoli, but that has no bearing on his influence for Romania. He was a powerful presence throughout the Euro 2016 qualifiers and travels to France as one of the team<83><82><82><82><84>s undisputed leaders, aiming to cause a surprise with the national team while proving his critics wrong.

Related: Euro 2016: the complete guide to every squad and every player in France

This first appearance at a major international tournament will be the biggest test of Chiriches<83><82><82><82><84> career. We may finally find out if he is capable of fulfilling his immense potential at last. Those inside the camp are certain he can, as Romania look to achieve their goal of reaching the knock-out phase. <83><82><82><82><93>Chiriches<83><82><82><82><84> role is fundamental,<83><82><82><82><9d> believes the manager, Anghel Iordanescu, although the 26-year-old does not want to place too much pressure on his own shoulders. <83><82><82><82><93>The generation I<83><82><82><82><84>m part of has an asset <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the unity inside the group,<83><82><82><82><9d> he says. <83><82><82><82><93>I<83><82><82><82><84>m not one for making statements; I just need to stay focused. It would be a mistake to think of anything other than my game.<83><82><82><82><9d>

His impact in the Premier League and, latterly, Serie A might not have been the most positive <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Chiriches has started just 18 league games in the last two seasons <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but he has retained his aura in the national team. Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s defence is their selling point; they conceded just twice during the qualifying campaign, fewer than anyone else, and the commanding centre-back was at the heart of that achievement.

Perhaps it helps that Chiriches is used to getting straight back up after being hit. He spent a season as a youth player at Benfica but was forced to return home after a series of bad injuries, at one point fearing that his career would not get off the ground.

<83><82><82><82><93>I was afraid football was over for me,<83><82><82><82><9d> Chiriches says. <83><82><82><82><93>But I went down to the second division, put the effort in and gave my all to return to the level I was at before. God helped me with my every decision. I was training with Benfica<83><82><82><82><84>s first team and then two injuries ended everything for me <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but that didn<83><82><82><82><84>t destroy me.<83><82><82><82><9d>

He might not have managed it without the motivating presence of one family member. <83><82><82><82><93>My mother was very important <83><82><82><82><80><9c> she helped me a lot and said I would come back,<83><82><82><82><9d> he says. <83><82><82><82><93>And it was exactly as she said. I owe her a lot. She was the one who insisted I took my school studies seriously too, and I was very good in maths and history.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Football was always the ambition though, even if it took time to settle into life as a central defender. <83><82><82><82><93>I was a left midfielder when I was a kid,<83><82><82><82><9d> he explains. <83><82><82><82><93>I started when I was eight, then I left home for good at 14. That<83><82><82><82><84>s the sacrifice I had to make as a kid in order to become a professional. I had nothing guaranteed; I was only a child with a dream. I had to live away from my family and that hurt, but it was worth it.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Chiriches<83><82><82><82><84> fall from grace at Tottenham was sudden. He went from being man of the match in a 2-1 win at Old Trafford on 1 January 2014 to backup status in under six months. A back injury did not help; nor did a change of managers at his club and perhaps video footage of him falling over, seemingly drunk, in the snow back in his homeland did not count in his favour either. Whatever the cause, he fell out of favour and never hit the same heights again.

<83><82><82><82><93>I wasn<83><82><82><82><84>t playing, so I wasn<83><82><82><82><84>t happy,<83><82><82><82><9d> he says. The defender<83><82><82><82><84>s subsequent move to the right side of the defence did not help and he made just three appearances for Tottenham in the second half of the 2014-15 season <83><82><82><82><80><9c> although it did not harm his position in the Romania team.

<83><82><82><82><93>The national team gave me so much,<83><82><82><82><9d> he says. <83><82><82><82><93>It is all about the pride and joy you feel when you play for your country. It<83><82><82><82><84>s always immense to be among those selected and I enjoy every minute of it. Being here helped me stay focused and our results gave great satisfaction.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Chiriches can expect to wear the captain<83><82><82><82><84>s armband in Paris on 10 June when Romania open the tournament against host nation France. The Romania dressing room is abuzz with delight rather than fear.

<83><82><82><82><93>France will be tough and playing at home makes them even tougher,<83><82><82><82><9d> he says. <83><82><82><82><93>I<83><82><82><82><84>m dreaming of making a historical performance, but I know how difficult this will be. We are fighting for our country and for our dreams, and nobody can take that away.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Chiriches<83><82><82><82><84> central defensive partnership with Dragos Grigore has been the bedrock of Iordanescu<83><82><82><82><84>s team throughout qualifying. When he arrived in the Premier League, Chiriches was known for his ability to come out of defence with the ball. He was forced to adapt his style in England and such forays were rarely seen; there are no such restrictions in the national team, though, and his offensive raids often launch dangerous attacks.

Despite Chiriches<83><82><82><82><84> enthusiasm for marauding upfield, Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s current style of play rarely demonstrates a great appetite for attacking. They put on an encouraging performance in a 0-0 draw with Spain in March, though, and that served as a spectacular confidence boost for players and fans alike. Against the reigning European champions, Iordanescu<83><82><82><82><84>s men put on an electric display and would not have been flattered by a win.

<83><82><82><82><93>The generation I<83><82><82><82><84>m part of made it to France thanks to a major collective effort,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Chiriches. <83><82><82><82><93>It guided us throughout the qualifying campaign, and this unity is our main asset. I hope it helps us now, as it has done so far. Going to France for the final tournament cannot be compared to anything else, and we hope to do things the right way. A good performance could help provide a new perspective on Romania as a nation.<83><82><82><82><9d>

At his best, Chiriches might just help make that happen. His <83><80><9a><82>8.5m move to Tottenham from Steaua Bucharest in 2013 set a Romanian league transfer record with his skill, use of the ball and comfort in possession setting a new standard for centre-backs in the country. He scored spectacular goals against Ajax and Molde in the Europa League, while his elegance and creativity were such that Steaua changed their tactics to allow him the freedom his talent merited.

Now he goes to Euro 2016 with the aim of showing the world a new version of Romanian brilliance <83><82><82><82><80><9c> perhaps not the same kind which the likes of Gheorghe Hagi, Adrian Ilie, Dan Petrescu or Adrian Mutu displayed, but one based on a collective strength that could be the envy of its peers.

<83><82><82><82><93>These are the occasions that make you fall in love with football,<83><82><82><82><9d> he says. <83><82><82><82><93>I can<83><82><82><82><84>t wait for the tournament to begin. Down there, on the pitch, the joy of playing will be huge for all of us. We<83><82><82><82><84>ll have an entire nation behind us, we<83><82><82><82><84>ll all be Romania and if we stay together we are capable of doing big things <83><82><82><82><80><9c> trust me.<83><82><82><82><9d>

<83><82><82><82> Emanuel Rosu writes for sport.ro.

Follow him on Twitter here.

The secrets behind the other squad members

Costel Pantilimon

The Watford goalkeeper<83><82><82><82><84>s parents, who worked at an aeroplane factory in the city of Bacau, are both deaf. They first took their son to play with the family<83><82><82><82><84>s football team when he was six. <83><82><82><82><93>At the age of eight or nine, my father told me I should be a goalkeeper, because I am pretty tall and it should be easier,<83><82><82><82><9d> Pantililon remembers. He now stands at 6ft 8in. After becoming a professional, he always made sure to send money to his parents and still goes on holiday with them sometimes. Pantilimon<83><82><82><82><84>s father rarely attends his matches but brought good luck when he did, seeing Poli Timisoara beat Shakhtar Donetsk in the Champions League third qualifying round in 2009. <83><82><82><82><93>I thank my parents for all they did and still do for me,<83><82><82><82><9d> he says. <83><82><82><82><93>The fact that they are deaf has never affected me at all. When I am away, we keep in touch by SMS and via the internet.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Gabriel Torje


Born in Timisoara, Torje was brought into the local top-flight team by Gheorghe Hagi, the coach at the time, who saw big potential in the 16-year-old. He then signed for one of Timisoara<83><82><82><82><84>s big rivals, Dinamo Bucharest, who bragged at the time: <83><82><82><82><93>We got their heart.<83><82><82><82><9d> A few years later he caused controversy when caught on camera at a party singing a song in support of Dinamo<83><82><82><82><84>s fierce city rivals, Steaua, which went: <83><82><82><82><93>Steaua is the only one, all the world should know this.<83><82><82><82><9d> To confuse matters further he then cried when Dinamo lost a cup final to Steaua, causing the Steaua fans to devise a song along the lines of <83><82><82><82><93>Cry, Torje, cry.<83><82><82><82><9d> He is not into electronic football games like Fifa, but does play a lot of Call of Duty on his computer.

Razvan Rat

Rat is an avid wine collector, a hobby he began while playing for Shakhtar Donetsk in Ukraine <83><82><82><82><80><9c> where he met his wife, too. He grew up in a small Romanian town, Piatra-Olt, where he watched the country<83><82><82><82><84>s legendary 1994 World Cup campaign at his neighbours<83><82><82><82><84> house because his family did not have a television. These days, he loves fast cars and owns two Ferraris.

Nicolae Stanciu


Stanciu is the national team<83><82><82><82><84>s newest star <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t like it if you call him <83><82><82><82><93>Nicusor<83><82><82><82><9d>, which is a diminutive of Nicolae. When he returned home from his first ever game of football as a boy he was upset, complaining: <83><82><82><82><93>Nobody passes to me.<83><82><82><82><9d> At home, he helped his parents work in agriculture. <83><82><82><82><93>We didn<83><82><82><82><84>t take him in order to work, but just so that he wasn<83><82><82><82><84>t left alone. He always ran off to play football, though,<83><82><82><82><9d> remembers his mother. Indeed, sometimes Stanciu left home at 6am, took a 15km bus ride to the nearest city, and returned at 9pm. He asked for his bedroom to be painted in red and blue with the logo of his favourite team Steaua <83><82><82><82><80><9c> for whom he now plays. In the past, he was passionate about fruit machines and sports betting.

<83><82><82><82> Lucian Lipovan writes for sport.ro.

The generation Im part of has an asset  the unity inside the group, he says. Im not one for making statements; I just need to stay focused. It would be a mistake to think of anything other than my game. His impact in the Premier League and, latterly, Serie A might not have been the most positive  Chiriches has started just 18 league games in the last two seasons  but he has retained his aura in the national team. Romanias defence is their selling point; they conceded just twice during the qualifying campaign, fewer than anyone else, and the commanding centre-back was at the heart of that achievement. Perhaps it helps that Chiriches is used to getting straight back up after being hit. He spent a season as a youth player at Benfica but was forced to return home after a series of bad injuries, at one point fearing that his career would not get off the ground. God helped me with my every decision. I was training with Benficas first team and then two injuries ended everything for me  but that didnt destroy me. And it was exactly as she said. I owe her a lot. She was the one who insisted I took my school studies seriously too, and I was very good in maths and history. Now he goes to Euro 2016 with the aim of showing the world a new version of Romanian brilliance  perhaps not the same kind which the likes of Gheorghe Hagi, Adrian Ilie, Dan Petrescu or Adrian Mutu displayed, but one based on a collective strength that could be the envy of its peers. webTitle: Olivier Giroud divides opinion but was pivotal as France conquered Romania
trailText: Olivier Giroud did what he does best as France beat Romania in the opening game of Euro 2016, missing chances before scoring the opener to ease pressure on Didier Deschampsâ squad
headline: Olivier Giroud divides opinion but was pivotal as France conquered Romania
standfirst: The Arsenal striker had one of his trademark mixed nights inside Stade de France, fluffing his opening lines yet scoring a goal to set the hosts on their way
byline: Owen Gibson at Stade de France
body:
First of all, they are not booing him now. And second, a penny for your thoughts, Karim Benzema?

As the controversially excluded Real Madrid striker was (presumably) settling down to watch his French team-mates kick off under huge pressure to get off to a winning start and force a hitherto preoccupied nation to focus on football, opportunity knocked for Arsenal<83><82><82><82><84>s Olivier Giroud.

And, after a typically uneven performance from the France No9 <83><82><82><82><80><9c> all ungainly elbows and grimaces amid the flowing beauty of his quicksilver colleagues <83><82><82><82><80><9c> it was a chance he gobbled up, grabbing the goal that temporarily sparked a glorious release of tension all round the Stade de France. A curate<83><82><82><82><84>s egg of a season for Arsenal in which he still registered 24 goals, 16 of them in the league, has given way to a warm-up phase in which he has established himself as the preferred <83><82><82><82><93>pivot<83><82><82><82><9d> around which Didier Deschamps seeks to rotate an embarrassment of attacking riches, yet has still fully failed to convince the French public.

Related: Dimitri Payet<83><82><82><82><84>s stunner rescues France<83><82><82><82><84>s welcome party against Romania

There were moments during a lively first half, in which France confirmed pre-tournament expectations that they would be gripping going forward and wobbly in defence, when one could see why Giroud is so highly prized by his coach. There were other times when one could see why he is sometimes widely mocked and, had he been more clinical, France could have secured the early goal they so craved as they surged forward with early energy.

So it was appropriate that it was Giroud<83><82><82><82><84>s gloriously ugly header, snatched from the fingertips of the flapping Romanian goalkeeper, Ciprian Tatarusanu, from a delicious Dimitri Payet cross before the hour, that gave France the lead. Equally typically, minutes earlier he had been fed by Payet and badly scuffed his shot.

With Giroud, who has scored seven goals in his past seven games for his country, it is as if the normal order is inverted. Deschamps possesses so many lightning-quick, fleet-footed attacking players that it is the old-fashioned striker who provides something different. For all his talents, and leaving aside the fact that his absence over the convoluted Mathieu Valbuena sex tape affair had little to do with football, Benzema arguably offers more of the same, whereas Giroud is able to give his team-mates someone to play off.

Yet it still feels wrong that Benzema is missing. The 28-year-old is at the peak of his powers but was last seen heading for Los Angeles with a French music producer called Track Dilla.

Another reason Giroud appeals to Deschamps is that his ability in the air makes him the perfect target for Payet<83><82><82><82><84>s laser-guided crosses.

Yet here his heading ability failed him to begin with. The match could have taken a very different shape had he opened the scoring from the first clear-cut chance of the match. Payet ghosted down the left and delivered a perfect cross but Giroud was unable to find the target with his near-post header.

And in the very last act of the half he lost his marker Vlad Chiriches, having spent much of the match exchanging shirt tugs with the Romania captain, and connected with a Payet corner, only to miss the target again. All night long he remained a willing target, even when things appeared to be conspiring against the hosts.

In some ways it seems odd that a France side so blessed going forward <83><82><82><82><80><9c> with the trickery of Payet and the quicksilver Antoine Griezmann selected either side of Giroud <83><82><82><82><80><9c> should have as its attacking focal point a striker who has specialised in dividing opinion. This, after all, is a side that can afford to leave Anthony Martial and Kingsley Coman on the bench and Hatem Ben Arfa, among others, at home.

Giroud, in his final league game of the season against Aston Villa, was barracked and booed by the Emirates crowd yet scored a hat-trick. He scored in the victory over Bayern Munich yet ended the season with Ars<83><92><82>ne Wenger desperately crossing his fingers that Jamie Vardy says yes to a move. Similarly, for his country Giroud was booed when he came off against Cameroon in one of the hosts<83><82><82><82><84> final warm-up games despite having scored the first goal in a 3-2 victory. It is fortunate, then, that Giroud is not a man given to self-doubt, as evidenced by his adoption of the disturbing modern trend of wearing clashing neon boots.

Perhaps his finest quality, alongside his eye for goal, is simply his propensity to keep going. As the second half wore on and France started to live dangerously it was Giroud who continued to plough a lonely furrow and lead the line, finally getting his reward.

Payet<83><82><82><82><84>s brilliance rescued them at the end but France will have to play better than this if they are to energise a nation. The question for Deschamps may be whether to persist with his pivot or unleash Coman or Martial from the start.Yet it was telling that when Romania scored their equaliser from the penalty spot it was Griezmann rather than Giroud who was sacrificed to introduce the teenage Coman, as the Arsenal man remained the focal point of the attack. And when Martial belatedly came on as Deschamps went for broke it was Paul Pogba who made way.

Payet<83><82><82><82><84>s special winner makes it unlikely Deschamps will tinker too much for now; if Giroud<83><82><82><82><84>s goal was ugly, then the West Ham midfielder<83><82><82><82><84>s strike was a thing of beauty.

At the end of Act One Giroud joined him to take the applause of a very relieved crowd.

And if the Arsenal man bitterly divides opinion, he would not be the first No9 in blue to do so; step forward St<83><92><82>phane Guivarc<83><82><82><82><84>h in the summer of 1998. Things did not turn out too badly then.

webTitle: France 2-1 Romania: Euro 2016 opening game  as it happened
trailText: Dimitri Payet scored a wonderful late goal to give France a win on the opening day
headline: France 2-1 Romania: Euro 2016 opening game â as it happened
standfirst:
• Payet ignites home celebrations with spectacular winning goal
  • Read David Hytnerâs match report
body:
9.56pm BST

Full-time: France 2-1 Romania

Mission accomplished by France, who blended slickness and jitters throughout but were uplifted at the last by Payet, their best player on the night and the scorer of a superb winning goal. That<83><82><82><82><84>s a nice start for the hosts to build on, even if plenty of improvement will be needed for them to win here on July 10.

Related: Dimitri Payet<83><82><82><82><84>s stunner rescues France<83><82><82><82><84>s welcome party against Romania

Updated at 10.13pm BST

9.53pm BST

90+3 min: Matuidi releases Sissoko. He could announce his arrival in stye here ... but instead blasts a 20-yard shot wide.

9.51pm BST

France substitution: Payet ambles off to tumultuous acclaim and sudden national hero status. His replacements wanders on. From the sublime to Moussa Sissoko.

9.50pm BST

WHAT A GOAL! France 2-1 Romania (Payet 89)

He was the man of the match even before he received a clever short pass from Kant<83><92><82> at the edge of the area - and jinked to his left and curled a sumptuous shot into the top corner! This time last year it didn<83><82><82><82><84>t even look like he<83><82><82><82><84>d be picked for the tournament, now it looks like he<83><82><82><82><84>s won the opening match with a sumptuous goal!

Updated at 10.18pm BST

9.46pm BST

85 min: With a cheeky flash of skill Alibec wrongfoots two Frenchman and bears down on their defence. He briefly considers letting fly from 25 yards but instead flips the ball wide to Stancu, who loses it.

9.44pm BST

83 min: ... or for Grigore to bound offside and let them off.

9.43pm BST

83 min: Kant<83><92><82> takes down Torje, giving Romania a freekick mid-way inside the French half. Another chance for the hosts to show their setpiece defending prowess...

9.41pm BST

Romania substitution: Torje on for Popa.

9.41pm BST

81 min: Martial slaloms in from the left, then rolls the ball to Giroud at the edge of the area. Giroud, holding off the defender behind him, tees up Martial for a shot. But it lacks power and poses no trouble to the keeper.

9.40pm BST

80 min: There<83><82><82><82><84>s audible nerves all around the Stade de France, with both sets of fans knowing victory or a miserable defeat are both still very possible. Meanwhile in Marseille, just look what England fans are up to. Some people just shouldn<83><82><82><82><84>t be allowed out of the house.

9.38pm BST

Preamble

Hello and welcome: it<83><82><82><82><84>s showtime! After 266 qualifying matches, several weeks of rehearsals and a million selection squabbles, the 2016 European Championships is kicking off in Paris and it promises to be a lot of fun. The tournament<83><82><82><82><84>s cast has never been so big and while expansion to 24 participants means watering down the quality, drama is still guaranteed. There<83><82><82><82><84>s no telling how things will pan out over the next month. If the stars are properly aligned by Roy Hodgson, even England have an earthly. A competition with no flawless team looks perfectly unpredictable. A handful of countries can realistically aspire to outright victory <83><82><82><82><80><9c> including Poland and Austria <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but four sides start with stronger credentials than the rest: the holders (Spain), the world champions (Germany), the highest-ranked team (Belgium) and the hosts, France, who get things under way this evening against Romania, who were unbeaten during the qualifiers and only conceded two goals. They even kept Kyle Lafferty quiet.

France, of course, won the last two major tournaments that they staged <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the 1984 European Championships and the 1998 World Cup <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and that<83><82><82><82><84>s no easy feat, as evidenced by the fact that it has been nearly four decades since any other host won either competition (Argentina <83><82><82><82><9c>78). But of course it was much more than home advantage that brought those victories to France: on both occasions Les Bleus had bloody good teams. Can we say the same about them now? Well that<83><82><82><82><84>s what we<83><82><82><82><84>re here to find out. They sure have some exciting ingredients but they<83><82><82><82><84>re all in attack: their defence is vulnerable, although being able to field Laurent Koscielny and Adil Rami is actually an indication of France<83><82><82><82><84>s strength in depth in central defence: what other country would be able to pick a duo as decent as that after losing five players (Varane, Sakho, Laporte, Mathieu and Zouma) who would have been picked ahead of at least one of them? And looking at the calibre of attacking players that Deschamps has chosen to omit (Ben Arfa, Lacazette, Gameiro...) gives an indication of the awesome strike power that they he have called up: if Roman<83><82><82><82><84>s defence can stifle the likes of Greizmann, Payet, Pogba, Martial, Comon and potential golden boot winner Giroud, then they really are exceptional. Can<83><82><82><82><84>t see it myself, mind. Then again, France know all too well what it<83><82><82><82><84>s like to be shocked in their opening match, thanks to Senegal.
