webTitle: Ireland v Romania: Rugby World Cup as it happened
trailText: Keith Earls and Tommy Bowe scored two tries each as Ireland eased to a six-try win in front of a record World Cup crowd at Wembley Stadium.
headline: Ireland v Romania: Rugby World Cup –as it happened
standfirst:
• Earls and Bowe score twice each as Ireland ease to six-try win
  • World Cup record crowd watches match at Wembley Stadium
body:
6.36pm BST

Not a lot to be learned from that match, really. Ireland<82><84>s second string get a good run out and put in a satisfying performance. The two wings, Earls and Bowe, both looked very good and there<82><84>s a strong chance the latter has played his way back into the starting XV for France and Italy.

Romania lost heavily but weren<82><84>t blown away and once again didn<82><84>t look out of place at the World Cup. They can be more than proud of their performance today; they look like a side that could genuinely upset Italy.

That<82><84>s all from me, folks. Thanks for reading, bye!

Updated at 7.00pm BST

6.33pm BST

Full-time: Ireland 44-10 Romania

Ireland get a penalty thanks to good work from O<82><84>Brien in the tackle. Jackson quickly punts the ball into the corner. This should be the last move. Toner takes it, the maul forms, but Romania refuse to give in. Reddan goes inside to Bowe, but he<82><84>s driven back away from the line as he looks for his hat-trick. Bowe holds on and Romania get the penalty. It<82><84>s booted into touch and that<82><84>s that.

6.31pm BST

Conversion (Kinikinilau 79) Ireland 44-10 Romania

Kinikinilau takes over kicking duties and won<82><84>t have an easier one than that.

6.30pm BST

Try! (Tonita 78) Ireland 44-8 Romania

The throw goes too far, but Carpu recovers it well. The ball comes back inside and Tonita goes over the top of Jackson to score under the posts!

Updated at 6.57pm BST

6.29pm BST

77 min The maul has little effect for Romania, so they shift it inside. Surugiu snipes round the short side and gets a penalty for side entry, so Vlaicu pops it into the corner.

6.28pm BST

76 min A chance for Romania now as Murray, out of position on the wing, allows it to bounce before catching the ball in his 22 and he<82><84>s duly shunted into touch. Lineout 15 from the line.

6.27pm BST

Conversion (Madigan 75) Ireland 44-3 Romania

From just to the right, Madigan knocks it over easily.

6.26pm BST

Try! (Henry 74) Ireland 42-3 Romania

Into the corner it goes and Murphy takes the throw. The maul is far, far too powerful and it<82><84>s a very easy try, Chris Henry the man ending up with it.

Updated at 6.37pm BST

6.25pm BST

73 min Ireland rumble up over halfway before Cave dummies and slips through a gap, getting up to the 22. Surugiu dives into the ruck and plays the ball, so Ireland get the penalty out on the right.

6.24pm BST

72 min Another good effort at the scrum from Romania, so Zebo kicks clear with little front foot ball to work with. It<82><84>s returned by Fercu though and now Ireland can run it back.

6.24pm BST

71 min Bad news for Ireland: Kearney picked up a knock while scoring that try and has had to go off; Murray coming on in his place and going to the wing while Zebo returns to 15. Gal comes back from the sin-bin.

6.22pm BST

69 min Romania are still going as they surge from a scrum into the 22. It<82><84>s knocked on by Carpo, who has put in a mighty shift at eight but is puffing like Don Draper now. Irish scrum on their own 22.

6.20pm BST

68 min Loads of changes for Romania, as they empty their bench. Lazar on for Ursache, Burcea for Macovei, Surugiu for Calafateanu and Vlaicu for Wiringi at 10.

6.19pm BST

67 min Wide on the left again <82><80><9c> Ireland, like Australia earlier, are putting a lot of width on the ball today <82><80><9c> and Madigan<82><84>s conversion drifts off to the left.

6.18pm BST

Try! (Kearney 65) Ireland 37-3 Romania

Zebo gets some space after Reddan switches play from a centrefield scrum, and turns it on, sprinting clear and getting one-on-one with Fercu. Kearney is running the supporting line and Zebo pops it inside for the full-back to go over on the left.

Updated at 6.33pm BST

6.16pm BST

64 min More changes as Kearney comes back on for Earls, Furlong replaces White and, because Joe Schmidt is a cruel man, he unleashes O<82><84>Connell, coming on for Ryan.

6.15pm BST

Conversion (Madigan 64) Ireland 32-3 Romania

Another tough one for Madigan, on the right-hand touchline. He of the godawful hair gets it inside the far post very nicely though.

6.14pm BST

Try! (Bowe 62) Ireland 30-3 Romania

A good push from Romania, but Ireland get it quickly into the backs. Jackson comes on the loop and flings it wide for Bowe to get his second in the corner and Ireland have the bonus point.

Updated at 6.23pm BST

6.13pm BST

Ireland take the scrum. They<82><84>ll be eager for that bonus point, given that France got one.

6.12pm BST

61 min Reddan spins it inside and Cave steps neatly past his man and through the line. Ireland get up to the line and have advantage; the ball goes wide and behind the three-quarter line, so we go back for an offside against Gal. Yellow card for the inside centre.

6.11pm BST

60 min High ball from Calafateanu and Jackson jumps to take it on halfway. Ionita, the replacement wing, chases and mistimes his tackle, catching the Ulsterman while he<82><84>s still <82><80><9c> just <82><80><9c> in the air. It was very marginal, his foot was only just off the ground, so it<82><84>s a penalty only <82><80><9c> very good call that by Craig Joubert. Cronin and O<82><84>Brien replace Strauss and Heaslip, while Van Heerden comes on for Lucaci. Ireland get the lineout just inside the 22.

6.07pm BST

59 min There<82><84>s been a tiny momentum shift here and Romani are on the front foot, but again it goes loose and Ireland look to attack again. Bowe stabs through for Earls, but it<82><84>s too close to Botezatu and the wing fields it.

6.06pm BST

58 min Now it goes right and loose, so Botezatu hacks ahead. Zebo goes back and recovers; it goes back to Madigan on the back foot and he tries the cross kick to Earls, but it bounces into touch on halfway. Jackson comes on for Payne.

6.05pm BST

57 min Romania look to go from the lineout inside their own half, but Jordi Murphy steals it. Left they go, but Romania drift across and shut the move down.

6.04pm BST

56 min Earls comes back on having passed his head injury assessment. McGrath is on for Healy too. We<82><84>re having another HIA though, as Radoi goes off and Turashvili takes his place.

6.03pm BST

55 min That was only cleared about 10 metres upfield, so Ireland get good position with the lineout. They maul it, but it goes infield and Carpo wins the turnover. Indeed he gets a penalty too, as Heaslip goes in at the side.

6.02pm BST

54 min Romania lineout then, five from their own line and they just about get the ball. I<82><84>ve rarely heard a crowd this noisy and I<82><84>ve been to Thomond Park. For Romania, Ionita replaces Apostol and Tarus comes on for Ion.

6.00pm BST

53 min It<82><84>s a bit scrappy from Ireland and there<82><84>s nothing on, so Reddan chips towards the corner. Apsotol goes back and collects, but his clearance is brilliantly charged by the flying Kearney.

5.59pm BST

52 min Ireland have the scrum a few metres inside the Romania half as McGrath prepares to come on, presumably for Healy.

5.59pm BST

51 min An exchange of kicks, neither of which is much cop, then Romania look to run it. Again Ireland<82><84>s defence is solid and Radoi then drops a pass from Calafateanu that was up above his head.

5.57pm BST

50 min Romania lineout then, on the right, 16 metres inside the Irish half. Kearney has gone to full-back and Zebo to the wing, by the way. Ireland pinch the lineout and Madigan looks to send a raking kick across the field to touch, but Fercu reads it and fields.

5.56pm BST

49 min Penalty to Romania when the Irish back row don<82><84>t roll away from the tackle area on the 10 metre line. There<82><84>s an injury though, as Earls has taken an accidental knee to the head tackling Botezatu around the legs and will go off for an HIA. Rob Kearney is on in his place.

5.54pm BST

48 min Having cleared, Ireland win another turnover on halfway and Healy barrels through a tackle to make ground in midfield. Ireland go for the quick offloading game and there<82><84>s a sense of inevitability when Healy knocks it forward. Romania look to go on the counter.

5.53pm BST

47 min Now it goes right and Apostol does well down the wing, handing Reddan off. They recycle, getting into the 22 and the number 14 has another little forage down that side. He<82><84>s looking dangerous, but he<82><84>s well marked. After another three phases though, Ireland win the turnover and clear.

5.52pm BST

46 min Toner is again excellent at the restart and Reddan puts it up. Romania just about secure it on halfway though and shift it left, but Wiringi is isolated and driven backwards.

5.51pm BST

Conversion (Madigan 45) Ireland 25-3 Romania

From 15 metres in, Madigan slots the extras.

5.50pm BST

Try! (Earls 44) Ireland 23-3 Romania

From the back of the maul, Reddan dinks a very cute little grubber through towards the in-goal area behind the rush defence. Earls picks it up low to the floor and goes over in the left-hand corner.

Updated at 5.59pm BST

5.49pm BST

43 min They go through the phases though, just outside the 22 but Heaslip wins the 22 and Healy (!!) kicks ahead for Earls to chase. Fercu gets back and fields it near his own line, but Earls<82><84> chase is outstanding and the full-back can only find touch 10 metres out from his own line.

5.48pm BST

42 min Radoi<82><84>s throw is well taken and Romania get clean ball off the top. Their backs are running from deep and struggling to break the gain line though.

5.47pm BST

41 min Here we go again, Madigan gets us restarted and his short kick is brilliantly taken by Toner, who storms straight up to the 22. They recycle, but there<82><84>s a clearout round the neck by Henry and a penalty to Romania. Calafateanu kicks well to touch on the right, 40 metres upfield.

5.45pm BST

Looking at Wembley, there are at least 25,000 people at the bar.

5.45pm BST

We have a world record!

5.43pm BST

An email comes in! And it<82><84>s from a man simply called <82><93>Jonny<82><9d>. I don<82><84>t think it<82><84>s Sexton.

<82><93>Hello Mr. Dan, what a great start to the Ireland game it<82><84>s been. I was supposed to be there at Wembley today with my wife and kid but I lost my ticket in a poker game to my mate down the pub the other night. He<82><84>s there with them now. I<82><84>m in a world of pain right now but your MBM is getting me through the pain caused by my gambling and alcohol addiction. Many thanks.<82><9d>

Oh my.

5.41pm BST

That was 40 minutes of Wayne Jarvis-esque professionalism from Ireland. Joe Schmidt won<82><84>t be happy with a couple of turnovers, perfectionist that he is, and they probably will have wanted one more try before the break, but another half like that and they<82><84>ll be as satisfied as a man who has just eaten a massive steak and washed it down with a couple of glasses of Lagavulin.

5.31pm BST

Half-time: Ireland 18-3 Romania

It<82><84>s advantage Ireland at the scrum for an illegal pass, but they won<82><84>t need it as Madigan<82><84>s cross-chip is fielded by Bowe and offloaded back inside to Zebo, who is just scragged. That<82><84>s a great take, but when it comes back inside Madigan overcooks his pass to Healy and the prop knocks on.

5.29pm BST

39 min Ireland scrum, five metres infield and just over the Romanian 10 metre line.

5.28pm BST

38 min Earls fields Calafateanu<82><84>s clearance and gives it to Zebo. He<82><84>s turned over by an outstanding counterrruck, but then, having secured possession, it<82><84>s lost forward on the floor by a Romanian player.

Updated at 5.39pm BST

5.28pm BST

37 min It<82><84>s thrown to the back, but Romania defend the maul brilliantly. Down it goes and they get the turnover and scrum. Carpo gets pats on the back for his work in tying the ball up there and deservedly so.

Paul Devlin asks: <82><93>As a seasoned rugby reporter, perhaps you can enlighten me as to when the rules were changed. It was always the case that the forward pass was outlawed. Now however it seems to be a legitimate move. One Romania surge just past featured not one, but two forward passes out of three. A bit like watching gridiron with 15 quarterbacks.<82><9d>

It<82><84>s going to take me too long to respond in full, but it<82><84>s essentially down to the direction the hands are pointing in and momentum of a player going forward.

5.26pm BST

36 min Carpo then goes offside at the lineout though and it<82><84>s a penalty to Ireland. Madigan opts for touch again, giving his side a lineout eight metres from the line, on the right.

5.25pm BST

35 min It<82><84>s a strong scrum from Ireland and Romania buckle, but Carpo picks up well at the base. Calafateanu picks up and box kicks clear off the back foot, making good ground too as he gets it to touch beyond the 10 metre line.

5.23pm BST

34 min The move comes to an end when Healy <82><80><9c> who is back up <82><80><9c> knocks on in the double tackle. Ah, and now he<82><84>s down hurt again after that.

5.22pm BST

33 min Bad news for Ireland as Healy is down having treatment. Ireland continue to pick and drive, but Romania are knocking them back now as we go into the 12th phase.

5.21pm BST

32 min Ireland show Geoff Parling how it<82><84>s done and throw to the back of the lineout, where Toner takes. They go for the pick and drive, looking to suck Romanian defenders in.

5.20pm BST

31 min Penalty Ireland as Bowe is taken out in the air going for a high ball. Madigan sticks it into touch just outside the Romanian 22.

5.19pm BST

30 min From the left touchline this time, Madigan strikes the near post.

5.18pm BST

Try! (Earls 29) Ireland 18-3 Romania

Oh what a pass this is from Zebo! With Ireland simply crabbing back and forth across the pitch, he whips a beauty of a pass off his right, looping it over the top and wide for Earls to go speeding over from the 22.

Updated at 5.29pm BST

5.17pm BST

28 min Ireland go left off the lineout, then back right, but it<82><84>s pretty slow stuff.

5.17pm BST

27 min Henry steals the lineout, tapping it back and Ireland can attack from halfway. Madigan stabs a low kick through and a nasty bounce sees it fly up over Fercu<82><84>s head. He goes back and takes it, but then decides to run and is wrapped up. Calafateanu clears down the left, but barely gets it out the 22.

5.15pm BST

26 min This time Madigan sticks it in the corner, buoyed by that alst maul. They don<82><84>t get to form one this time though, as Heaslip is penalised for obstruction and Romania clear to touch.

5.14pm BST

25 min Toner takes it and here comes that Irish driving maul. The Romania pack splinters and they walk to within 10 before the penalty is given. It;s against the number eight Carpo, for entering at the side.

5.13pm BST

24 min Oof. Payne gets smashed by Tonita, but the lock was up far too quickly and is pinged for offisde. Madigan goes to touch again, on the left, this time on the 22.

5.12pm BST

23 min And now it<82><84>s a penalty against Radoi, as Henry completely stitches him up in the tackle and forces the hooker to hold on. Madigan to touch on the left, on Ireland<82><84>s 10 metre line.

5.11pm BST

22 min Good from Fercu, chasing and catching his own high kick in midfield. They look to get it through the hands, but there<82><84>s a touch of hesitation and a shortage of ideas among the backs. It goes right and Kinikinilau takes it up to within 10 metres, but ignores an overlap on his right!

5.10pm BST

Conversion (Madigan 21) Ireland 13-3 Ireland

Madigan<82><84>s kick from the touchline is excellent, drifting perfectly inside the near post.

5.09pm BST

Try! (Bowe 19) Ireland 11-3 Romania

Brilliant from Earls, regathering a high box kick close to the touchline and spinning back inside. He offloads and Ireland sweep the ball right across the pitch. It comes to Bowe, who shows great strength to stay infield and ground it in the right-hand corner as Fercu looks to tackle him into touch.

Updated at 5.15pm BST

5.06pm BST

Penalty (Madigan 18) Ireland 6-3 Romania

From 15 metres in and 27 out, Madigan curls it over.

5.06pm BST

17 min It comes inside then back out from the lineout and Earls makes ground, pumping the legs and pushing the tackler back. They go through the phases, sweeping right across the field and getting over the gain line. There<82><84>s a clearout around the neck earlier in the move though and so, when it breaks down, we go back for the penalty.

5.04pm BST

16 min From the lineout, Calafateanu box kicks clear to the 10 metre line.

5.04pm BST

15 min Wiringi gives it short to Kinikinilau and he barrels into contact down the left. It<82><84>s back inside to Fercu, but he loses the ball in contact and, when it goes left, Zebo comes away at pace. It goes back inside, then out again and Zebo is put away by Strauss after a great offload from Earls. He kicks ahead and regathers magnificently, with zero space, to go over in the corner for what looks like a stunning try. Endless tedious TMO replays eventually show that he had a foot millimetres in touch though.

Updated at 5.12pm BST

5.00pm BST

13 min Mistake from Wiringi as, after the lineout, he stabs his flat kick straight into the arms of Zebo. Ireland get it to Madigan, who looks for the corner but his kick is half charged down and now Romania have it inside the Irish half.

4.59pm BST

12 min Credit has to go to Romania for that patient, well-disciplined comeback after not seeing the ball for four minutes. Ireland put width on it from the restart, but when Payne loops round the outside of Earls he runs out of space and is taken into touch by Lucaci.

4.58pm BST

Penalty (Calafateanu 11) Ireland 3-3 Romania

From wide on the left <82><80><9c> 16 metres infield <82><80><9c> and just outside the 22, the scrum-half brings his kick around and inside the far post.

4.57pm BST

10 min Now it<82><84>s Romania<82><84>s chance to pile on the crash balls, before the Saracen Fercu looks to wriggle his way through. He can<82><84>t, but then Payne doesn<82><84>t roll out of the tackle and it<82><84>s a chance to level the scores.

4.56pm BST

9 min Wiringi, the Kiwi-born fly-half, restarts with a short kick. It<82><84>s gathered in, but a mistake from Reddan who puts his box kick out on the full from tight to his left touchline, 15 metres inside his own half.

4.55pm BST

Penalty (Madigan 8) Ireland 3-0 Romania

Straight through it goes and Ireland have something to show for their strong start.

Updated at 5.14pm BST

4.54pm BST

7 min From the lineout, Calafateanu sends it high and hte ball bounces back to Kinikinilau. He runs into the tackle from Strauss, then Macovei, the captain, goes off his feet at the ruck. Kinikinilau was holding on too, so Madigan will have a shot at goal from 40 metres, dead in front.

4.53pm BST

6 min Gal, the inside centre, tries to gain territory with a tactical grubber kick, but it<82><84>s a poor one and Bowe fields easily. The wing threads it down the line, into touch just outside the 22.

4.52pm BST

5 min It<82><84>s a relentless start from Ireland and you wonder how long that Romanian defence can resist. It<82><84>s already a thumpingly physical start, although Strauss coughs the ball up as he can<82><84>t quite clutch on to a cute offload from Ryan inside the 22.

4.51pm BST

4 min After three minutes, Romania get their hands on the ball as Ireland knock on in the tight. Calefateanu thumps the clearance to touch and Ireland come again from the lineout, 40 metres away from the line.

4.50pm BST

3 min Now Ireland make ground as Earls comes infield and gets it to Payne outside him. Into the 22 and they look to build, going through the phases 10 metres or so out in midfield.

4.49pm BST

2 min Madigan sends up a high one and it<82><84>s tapped back to Payne from the Romania 22. Bowe looks to wriggle free, but Romania<82><84>s defence is up quickly and hitting the tackles hard.

Updated at 4.59pm BST

4.48pm BST

Peep! Craig Joubert blows his whistle and Romania, playing today in white with a black stripe down the middle, get things start. Ireland carry up towards the halfway line, with Cave stepping inside and making a break.

4.46pm BST

Wait, I didn<82><84>t think that game through. Luckily, the rugby is about to get under way!

4.46pm BST

Anyone want to play a game? It<82><84>s called <82><93>What the hell is Paloma Faith choking on when she sings the word <82><93>union<82><9d>?

4.44pm BST

It<82><84>s another sell-out at Wembley, with 90,000-odd fans in there. Most of them supporting Ireland, you won<82><84>t be surprised to know. 89,019 is the record, set at this ground a week ago when New Zealand played Argentina. This could run it close.

Updated at 4.58pm BST

4.38pm BST

We have some thoughts! They are these:

On the telly, Joe Schmidt says they intend to give Cian Healy 50 or 60 minutes today.

4.36pm BST

29 years and 245 days. That<82><84>s the average age of the Ireland XV <82><80><9c> their oldest in World Cup history. There have been stories going around, including on here, that it<82><84>s the oldest in World Cup history, although I<82><84>m pretty sure this Romanian side is older.

4.33pm BST

So how are you feeling, Ireland fans? I<82><84>d be pretty confident about their chances. This line up actually shows one of their great strengths: this is very much a second string team but, half-backs aside, you wouldn<82><84>t say that it was that much weaker than the first team.

4.24pm BST

Time for some pre-match reading. Paul Rees has had a chat with a Usain Bolt-inspired Simon Zebo.

Related: Ireland<82><84>s Simon Zebo inspired by Usain Bolt as team prepare to play Romania | Kevin Mitchell

4.13pm BST

You can catch the last five minutes of Scotland v USA with Michael Butler, right here. Spoiler alert: Scotland are going to win it.

2.26pm BST

Preamble

Afternoon, folks. Oh great, another one of these. I get to MBM Australia v Uruguay earlier, now another mismatch. A tier one team, these ranked number five in the world, against some no-hope chumps. Romania, ranked 17th in the world, trying to stave off wave after wave of attack from an Ireland side confident enough to make 12 changes from the side that eased past Canada a week ago. Seriously, editors, why the eff are you making me do this?

But wait, I<82><84>m being obviously disingenuous! OK, yes, Ireland will probably <82><80><9c> probably <82><80><9c> have too much for the Romanians today, but a walkover akin to this morning<82><84>s is by no means guaranteed. Romania may be without the flanker Valentin Ursache, suspended for a dangerous tackle against France, but their grizzly set of forwards will be more than up for a bone-crunching battle with Ireland<82><84>s gnarled and wizened pack.

France may have ended up with a comfortable-looking 38-11 win on Wednesday, but they didn<82><84>t have it all their own way. It was only when Romania were down to 14 men that they finally crossed the line and then added a gloss to the score with a bunch of late tries. And Ireland, for all their grunt, don<82><84>t have the same fizzing backs game as the French.

Still, you expect Ireland to have too much behind the scrum, even if Romania can match them up front. You expect Joe Schmidt<82><84>s men to be too fit and to outlast Romania. You expect the four-day turnaround to prove costly to Romania as it was to Japan against Scotland.

That said, you expected South Africa to thrash Japan. You expected Italy to blow the cobwebs off and easily beat Canada. You expected Tonga<82><84>s backs to be too much for Georgia. You expected the All Blacks to stop Namibia from scoring a try. You expected England to beat Wales at Twickenham. And, as I write this, the USA have just taken the lead against South Africa.

There has only been one earth-shattering shock in this World Cup so far*. But it has been a far from predictable tournament and Ireland, while they are probably going to win and do so reasonably comfortably, probably shouldn<82><84>t get too complacent. People called Romanians they won<82><84>t go the house quietly.

Kick-off is at 4.45pm BST. That<82><84>s 6.45pm for those of you in Bucharest. Your teams are:

Ireland

Simon Zebo; Tommy Bowe, Jared Payne, Darren Cave, Keith Earls; Ian Madigan, Eoin Reddan; Cian Healy, Richardt Strauss, Nathan White; Donnacha Ryan, Devin Toner; Jordi Murphy, Chris Henry, Jamie Heaslip (capt).
Replacements: Sean Cronin, Jack McGrath, Tadhg Furlong, Paul O<82><84>Connell, Sean O<82><84>Brien, Conor Murray, Paddy Jackson, Rob Kearney.

Romania

Catalin Fercu; Adrian Apostol, Paula Kinikinilau, Csaba Gal, Ionut Botezatu; Michael Wiringi, Valentin Calafeteanu; Andrei Ursache, Andrei Radoi, Paulica Ion; Valentin Poparlan, Ovidiu Tonita; Viorel Lucaci, Mihai Macovei (capt), Daniel Carpo.

Replacements: Mihaita Lazar, Otar Turashvili, Alexandru Tarus, Johannes van Heerden, Stelian Burcea, Florin Surugiu, Florin Ionita, Florin Vlaicu.

*Remind me to edit this if the USA win.

Updated at 3.02pm BST
text: 6.36pm BST Not a lot to be learned from that match, really. Irelands second string get a good run out and put in a satisfying performance. The two wings, Earls and Bowe, both looked very good and theres a strong chance the latter has played his way back into the starting XV for France and Italy. Romania lost heavily but werent blown away and once again didnt look out of place at the World Cup. They can be more than proud of their performance today; they look like a side that could genuinely upset Italy. Thats all from me, folks. Thanks for reading, bye! Updated at 7.00pm BST  6.33pm BST Ireland get a penalty thanks to good work from OBrien in the tackle. Jackson quickly punts the ball into the corner. This should be the last move. Toner takes it, the maul forms, but Romania refuse to give in. Reddan goes inside to Bowe, but hes driven back away from the line as he looks for his hat-trick. Bowe holds on and Romania get the penalty. Its booted into touch and thats that.  6.31pm BST Kinikinilau takes over kicking duties and wont have an easier one than that.  6.30pm BST The throw goes too far, but Carpu recovers it well. The ball comes back inside and Tonita goes over the top of Jackson to score under the posts! Updated at 6.57pm BST  6.29pm BST 77 min The maul has little effect for Romania, so they shift it inside. Surugiu snipes round the short side and gets a penalty for side entry, so Vlaicu pops it into the corner.  6.28pm BST 76 min A chance for Romania now as Murray, out of position on the wing, allows it to bounce before catching the ball in his 22 and hes duly shunted into touch. Lineout 15 from the line.  6.27pm BST From just to the right, Madigan knocks it over easily.  6.26pm BST Into the corner it goes and Murphy takes the throw. The maul is far, far too powerful and its a very easy try, Chris Henry the man ending up with it. Updated at 6.37pm BST  6.25pm BST 73 min Ireland rumble up over halfway before Cave dummies and slips through a gap, getting up to the 22. Surugiu dives into the ruck and plays the ball, so Ireland get the penalty out on the right.  6.24pm BST 72 min Another good effort at the scrum from Romania, so Zebo kicks clear with little front foot ball to work with. Its returned by Fercu though and now Ireland can run it back.  6.24pm BST 71 min Bad news for Ireland: Kearney picked up a knock while scoring that try and has had to go off; Murray coming on in his place and going to the wing while Zebo returns to 15. Gal comes back from the sin-bin.  6.22pm BST 69 min Romania are still going as they surge from a scrum into the 22. Its knocked on by Carpo, who has put in a mighty shift at eight but is puffing like Don Draper now. Irish scrum on their own 22.  6.20pm BST 68 min Loads of changes for Romania, as they empty their bench. Lazar on for Ursache, Burcea for Macovei, Surugiu for Calafateanu and Vlaicu for Wiringi at 10.  6.19pm BST 67 min Wide on the left again  Ireland, like Australia earlier, are putting a lot of width on the ball today  and Madigans conversion drifts off to the left.  6.18pm BST Zebo gets some space after Reddan switches play from a centrefield scrum, and turns it on, sprinting clear and getting one-on-one with Fercu. Kearney is running the supporting line and Zebo pops it inside for the full-back to go over on the left. Updated at 6.33pm BST  6.16pm BST 64 min More changes as Kearney comes back on for Earls, Furlong replaces White and, because Joe Schmidt is a cruel man, he unleashes OConnell, coming on for Ryan.  6.15pm BST Another tough one for Madigan, on the right-hand touchline. He of the godawful hair gets it inside the far post very nicely though.  6.14pm BST A good push from Romania, but Ireland get it quickly into the backs. Jackson comes on the loop and flings it wide for Bowe to get his second in the corner and Ireland have the bonus point. Updated at 6.23pm BST  6.13pm BST Ireland take the scrum. Theyll be eager for that bonus point, given that France got one.  6.12pm BST 61 min Reddan spins it inside and Cave steps neatly past his man and through the line. Ireland get up to the line and have advantage; the ball goes wide and behind the three-quarter line, so we go back for an offside against Gal. Yellow card for the inside centre.  6.11pm BST 60 min High ball from Calafateanu and Jackson jumps to take it on halfway. Ionita, the replacement wing, chases and mistimes his tackle, catching the Ulsterman while hes still  just  in the air. It was very marginal, his foot was only just off the ground, so its a penalty only  very good call that by Craig Joubert. Cronin and OBrien replace Strauss and Heaslip, while Van Heerden comes on for Lucaci. Ireland get the lineout just inside the 22.  6.07pm BST 59 min Theres been a tiny momentum shift here and Romani are on the front foot, but again it goes loose and Ireland look to attack again. Bowe stabs through for Earls, but its too close to Botezatu and the wing fields it.   6.06pm BST 58 min Now it goes right and loose, so Botezatu hacks ahead. Zebo goes back and recovers; it goes back to Madigan on the back foot and he tries the cross kick to Earls, but it bounces into touch on halfway. Jackson comes on for Payne.  6.05pm BST 57 min Romania look to go from the lineout inside their own half, but Jordi Murphy steals it. Left they go, but Romania drift across and shut the move down.  6.04pm BST 56 min Earls comes back on having passed his head injury assessment. McGrath is on for Healy too. Were having another HIA though, as Radoi goes off and Turashvili takes his place.  6.03pm BST 55 min That was only cleared about 10 metres upfield, so Ireland get good position with the lineout. They maul it, but it goes infield and Carpo wins the turnover. Indeed he gets a penalty too, as Heaslip goes in at the side.  6.02pm BST 54 min Romania lineout then, five from their own line and they just about get the ball. Ive rarely heard a crowd this noisy and Ive been to Thomond Park. For Romania, Ionita replaces Apostol and Tarus comes on for Ion.  6.00pm BST 53 min Its a bit scrappy from Ireland and theres nothing on, so Reddan chips towards the corner. Apsotol goes back and collects, but his clearance is brilliantly charged by the flying Kearney.  5.59pm BST 52 min Ireland have the scrum a few metres inside the Romania half as McGrath prepares to come on, presumably for Healy.   5.59pm BST 51 min An exchange of kicks, neither of which is much cop, then Romania look to run it. Again Irelands defence is solid and Radoi then drops a pass from Calafateanu that was up above his head.  5.57pm BST 50 min Romania lineout then, on the right, 16 metres inside the Irish half. Kearney has gone to full-back and Zebo to the wing, by the way. Ireland pinch the lineout and Madigan looks to send a raking kick across the field to touch, but Fercu reads it and fields.  5.56pm BST 49 min Penalty to Romania when the Irish back row dont roll away from the tackle area on the 10 metre line. Theres an injury though, as Earls has taken an accidental knee to the head tackling Botezatu around the legs and will go off for an HIA. Rob Kearney is on in his place.  5.54pm BST 48 min Having cleared, Ireland win another turnover on halfway and Healy barrels through a tackle to make ground in midfield. Ireland go for the quick offloading game and theres a sense of inevitability when Healy knocks it forward. Romania look to go on the counter.  5.53pm BST 47 min Now it goes right and Apostol does well down the wing, handing Reddan off. They recycle, getting into the 22 and the number 14 has another little forage down that side. Hes looking dangerous, but hes well marked. After another three phases though, Ireland win the turnover and clear.  5.52pm BST 46 min Toner is again excellent at the restart and Reddan puts it up. Romania just about secure it on halfway though and shift it left, but Wiringi is isolated and driven backwards.  5.51pm BST From 15 metres in, Madigan slots the extras.  5.50pm BST From the back of the maul, Reddan dinks a very cute little grubber through towards the in-goal area behind the rush defence. Earls picks it up low to the floor and goes over in the left-hand corner. Updated at 5.59pm BST  5.49pm BST 43 min They go through the phases though, just outside the 22 but Heaslip wins the 22 and Healy (!!) kicks ahead for Earls to chase. Fercu gets back and fields it near his own line, but Earls chase is outstanding and the full-back can only find touch 10 metres out from his own line.  5.48pm BST 42 min Radois throw is well taken and Romania get clean ball off the top. Their backs are running from deep and struggling to break the gain line though.  5.47pm BST 41 min Here we go again, Madigan gets us restarted and his short kick is brilliantly taken by Toner, who storms straight up to the 22. They recycle, but theres a clearout round the neck by Henry and a penalty to Romania. Calafateanu kicks well to touch on the right, 40 metres upfield.  5.45pm BST Looking at Wembley, there are at least 25,000 people at the bar.  5.45pm BST We have a world record! It's a new #RWC RECORD CROWD at Wembley! 89,267 here - rough estimate at 87,000 being Irish fans #RWC2015 #IREvROM  5.43pm BST An email comes in! And its from a man simply called Jonny. I dont think its Sexton. Hello Mr. Dan, what a great start to the Ireland game its been. I was supposed to be there at Wembley today with my wife and kid but I lost my ticket in a poker game to my mate down the pub the other night. Hes there with them now. Im in a world of pain right now but your MBM is getting me through the pain caused by my gambling and alcohol addiction. Many thanks. Oh my.  5.41pm BST That was 40 minutes of Wayne Jarvis-esque professionalism from Ireland. Joe Schmidt wont be happy with a couple of turnovers, perfectionist that he is, and they probably will have wanted one more try before the break, but another half like that and theyll be as satisfied as a man who has just eaten a massive steak and washed it down with a couple of glasses of Lagavulin.  5.31pm BST Its advantage Ireland at the scrum for an illegal pass, but they wont need it as Madigans cross-chip is fielded by Bowe and offloaded back inside to Zebo, who is just scragged. Thats a great take, but when it comes back inside Madigan overcooks his pass to Healy and the prop knocks on.  5.29pm BST 39 min Ireland scrum, five metres infield and just over the Romanian 10 metre line.  5.28pm BST 38 min Earls fields Calafateanus clearance and gives it to Zebo. Hes turned over by an outstanding counterrruck, but then, having secured possession, its lost forward on the floor by a Romanian player. Updated at 5.39pm BST  5.28pm BST 37 min Its thrown to the back, but Romania defend the maul brilliantly. Down it goes and they get the turnover and scrum. Carpo gets pats on the back for his work in tying the ball up there and deservedly so. Paul Devlin asks: As a seasoned rugby reporter, perhaps you can enlighten me as to when the rules were changed. It was always the case that the forward pass was outlawed. Now however it seems to be a legitimate move. One Romania surge just past featured not one, but two forward passes out of three. A bit like watching gridiron with 15 quarterbacks. Its going to take me too long to respond in full, but its essentially down to the direction the hands are pointing in and momentum of a player going forward.  5.26pm BST 36 min Carpo then goes offside at the lineout though and its a penalty to Ireland. Madigan opts for touch again, giving his side a lineout eight metres from the line, on the right.  5.25pm BST 35 min Its a strong scrum from Ireland and Romania buckle, but Carpo picks up well at the base. Calafateanu picks up and box kicks clear off the back foot, making good ground too as he gets it to touch beyond the 10 metre line.  5.23pm BST 34 min The move comes to an end when Healy  who is back up  knocks on in the double tackle. Ah, and now hes down hurt again after that.  5.22pm BST 33 min Bad news for Ireland as Healy is down having treatment. Ireland continue to pick and drive, but Romania are knocking them back now as we go into the 12th phase.  5.21pm BST 32 min Ireland show Geoff Parling how its done and throw to the back of the lineout, where Toner takes. They go for the pick and drive, looking to suck Romanian defenders in.  5.20pm BST 31 min Penalty Ireland as Bowe is taken out in the air going for a high ball. Madigan sticks it into touch just outside the Romanian 22.  5.19pm BST 30 min From the left touchline this time, Madigan strikes the near post.  5.18pm BST Oh what a pass this is from Zebo! With Ireland simply crabbing back and forth across the pitch, he whips a beauty of a pass off his right, looping it over the top and wide for Earls to go speeding over from the 22. Updated at 5.29pm BST  5.17pm BST 28 min Ireland go left off the lineout, then back right, but its pretty slow stuff.  5.17pm BST 27 min Henry steals the lineout, tapping it back and Ireland can attack from halfway. Madigan stabs a low kick through and a nasty bounce sees it fly up over Fercus head. He goes back and takes it, but then decides to run and is wrapped up. Calafateanu clears down the left, but barely gets it out the 22.  5.15pm BST 26 min This time Madigan sticks it in the corner, buoyed by that alst maul. They dont get to form one this time though, as Heaslip is penalised for obstruction and Romania clear to touch.  5.14pm BST 25 min Toner takes it and here comes that Irish driving maul. The Romania pack splinters and they walk to within 10 before the penalty is given. It;s against the number eight Carpo, for entering at the side.  5.13pm BST 24 min Oof. Payne gets smashed by Tonita, but the lock was up far too quickly and is pinged for offisde. Madigan goes to touch again, on the left, this time on the 22.  5.12pm BST 23 min And now its a penalty against Radoi, as Henry completely stitches him up in the tackle and forces the hooker to hold on. Madigan to touch on the left, on Irelands 10 metre line.  5.11pm BST 22 min Good from Fercu, chasing and catching his own high kick in midfield. They look to get it through the hands, but theres a touch of hesitation and a shortage of ideas among the backs. It goes right and Kinikinilau takes it up to within 10 metres, but ignores an overlap on his right!  5.10pm BST Madigans kick from the touchline is excellent, drifting perfectly inside the near post.  5.09pm BST Brilliant from Earls, regathering a high box kick close to the touchline and spinning back inside. He offloads and Ireland sweep the ball right across the pitch. It comes to Bowe, who shows great strength to stay infield and ground it in the right-hand corner as Fercu looks to tackle him into touch. Updated at 5.15pm BST  5.06pm BST From 15 metres in and 27 out, Madigan curls it over.  5.06pm BST 17 min It comes inside then back out from the lineout and Earls makes ground, pumping the legs and pushing the tackler back. They go through the phases, sweeping right across the field and getting over the gain line. Theres a clearout around the neck earlier in the move though and so, when it breaks down, we go back for the penalty.  5.04pm BST 16 min From the lineout, Calafateanu box kicks clear to the 10 metre line.  5.04pm BST 15 min Wiringi gives it short to Kinikinilau and he barrels into contact down the left. Its back inside to Fercu, but he loses the ball in contact and, when it goes left, Zebo comes away at pace. It goes back inside, then out again and Zebo is put away by Strauss after a great offload from Earls. He kicks ahead and regathers magnificently, with zero space, to go over in the corner for what looks like a stunning try. Endless tedious TMO replays eventually show that he had a foot millimetres in touch though. Updated at 5.12pm BST  5.00pm BST 13 min Mistake from Wiringi as, after the lineout, he stabs his flat kick straight into the arms of Zebo. Ireland get it to Madigan, who looks for the corner but his kick is half charged down and now Romania have it inside the Irish half.  4.59pm BST 12 min Credit has to go to Romania for that patient, well-disciplined comeback after not seeing the ball for four minutes. Ireland put width on it from the restart, but when Payne loops round the outside of Earls he runs out of space and is taken into touch by Lucaci.  4.58pm BST From wide on the left  16 metres infield  and just outside the 22, the scrum-half brings his kick around and inside the far post.  4.57pm BST 10 min Now its Romanias chance to pile on the crash balls, before the Saracen Fercu looks to wriggle his way through. He cant, but then Payne doesnt roll out of the tackle and its a chance to level the scores.  4.56pm BST 9 min Wiringi, the Kiwi-born fly-half, restarts with a short kick. Its gathered in, but a mistake from Reddan who puts his box kick out on the full from tight to his left touchline, 15 metres inside his own half.  4.55pm BST Straight through it goes and Ireland have something to show for their strong start. Updated at 5.14pm BST  4.54pm BST 7 min From the lineout, Calafateanu sends it high and hte ball bounces back to Kinikinilau. He runs into the tackle from Strauss, then Macovei, the captain, goes off his feet at the ruck. Kinikinilau was holding on too, so Madigan will have a shot at goal from 40 metres, dead in front.  4.53pm BST 6 min Gal, the inside centre, tries to gain territory with a tactical grubber kick, but its a poor one and Bowe fields easily. The wing threads it down the line, into touch just outside the 22.  4.52pm BST 5 min Its a relentless start from Ireland and you wonder how long that Romanian defence can resist. Its already a thumpingly physical start, although Strauss coughs the ball up as he cant quite clutch on to a cute offload from Ryan inside the 22.  4.51pm BST 4 min After three minutes, Romania get their hands on the ball as Ireland knock on in the tight. Calefateanu thumps the clearance to touch and Ireland come again from the lineout, 40 metres away from the line.  4.50pm BST 3 min Now Ireland make ground as Earls comes infield and gets it to Payne outside him. Into the 22 and they look to build, going through the phases 10 metres or so out in midfield.  4.49pm BST 2 min Madigan sends up a high one and its tapped back to Payne from the Romania 22. Bowe looks to wriggle free, but Romanias defence is up quickly and hitting the tackles hard. Updated at 4.59pm BST  4.48pm BST Peep! Craig Joubert blows his whistle and Romania, playing today in white with a black stripe down the middle, get things start. Ireland carry up towards the halfway line, with Cave stepping inside and making a break.  4.46pm BST Wait, I didnt think that game through. Luckily, the rugby is about to get under way!  4.46pm BST Anyone want to play a game? Its called What the hell is Paloma Faith choking on when she sings the word union?  4.44pm BST Its another sell-out at Wembley, with 90,000-odd fans in there. Most of them supporting Ireland, you wont be surprised to know. 89,019 is the record, set at this ground a week ago when New Zealand played Argentina. This could run it close. Updated at 4.58pm BST  4.38pm BST We have some thoughts! They are these: @DanLucas86 Bowe & Earls will want 2 put in big shifts & plenty of quick ball, need 2 put 30-40+ on Romania, have 2 b clinical & disciplined On the telly, Joe Schmidt says they intend to give Cian Healy 50 or 60 minutes today.  4.36pm BST 29 years and 245 days. Thats the average age of the Ireland XV  their oldest in World Cup history. There have been stories going around, including on here, that its the oldest in World Cup history, although Im pretty sure this Romanian side is older.  4.33pm BST So how are you feeling, Ireland fans? Id be pretty confident about their chances. This line up actually shows one of their great strengths: this is very much a second string team but, half-backs aside, you wouldnt say that it was that much weaker than the first team.  4.24pm BST Time for some pre-match reading. Paul Rees has had a chat with a Usain Bolt-inspired Simon Zebo.  Related: Irelands Simon Zebo inspired by Usain Bolt as team prepare to play Romania | Kevin Mitchell   4.13pm BST You can catch the last five minutes of Scotland v USA with Michael Butler, right here. Spoiler alert: Scotland are going to win it.  2.26pm BST Afternoon, folks. Oh great, another one of these. I get to MBM Australia v Uruguay earlier, now another mismatch. A tier one team, these ranked number five in the world, against some no-hope chumps. Romania, ranked 17th in the world, trying to stave off wave after wave of attack from an Ireland side confident enough to make 12 changes from the side that eased past Canada a week ago. Seriously, editors, why the eff are you making me do this? But wait, Im being obviously disingenuous! OK, yes, Ireland will probably  probably  have too much for the Romanians today, but a walkover akin to this mornings is by no means guaranteed. Romania may be without the flanker Valentin Ursache, suspended for a dangerous tackle against France, but their grizzly set of forwards will be more than up for a bone-crunching battle with Irelands gnarled and wizened pack. France may have ended up with a comfortable-looking 38-11 win on Wednesday, but they didnt have it all their own way. It was only when Romania were down to 14 men that they finally crossed the line and then added a gloss to the score with a bunch of late tries. And Ireland, for all their grunt, dont have the same fizzing backs game as the French. Still, you expect Ireland to have too much behind the scrum, even if Romania can match them up front. You expect Joe Schmidts men to be too fit and to outlast Romania. You expect the four-day turnaround to prove costly to Romania as it was to Japan against Scotland. That said, you expected South Africa to thrash Japan. You expected Italy to blow the cobwebs off and easily beat Canada. You expected Tongas backs to be too much for Georgia. You expected the All Blacks to stop Namibia from scoring a try.  You expected England to beat Wales at Twickenham.  And, as I write this, the USA have just taken the lead against South Africa. There has only been one earth-shattering shock in this World Cup so far*. But it has been a far from predictable tournament and Ireland, while they are probably going to win and do so reasonably comfortably, probably shouldnt get too complacent. People called Romanians they wont go the house quietly. Kick-off is at 4.45pm BST. Thats 6.45pm for those of you in Bucharest. Your teams are: Simon Zebo; Tommy Bowe, Jared Payne, Darren Cave, Keith Earls; Ian Madigan, Eoin Reddan; Cian Healy, Richardt Strauss, Nathan White; Donnacha Ryan, Devin Toner; Jordi Murphy, Chris Henry, Jamie Heaslip (capt).Replacements: Sean Cronin, Jack McGrath, Tadhg Furlong, Paul OConnell, Sean OBrien, Conor Murray, Paddy Jackson, Rob Kearney. Catalin Fercu; Adrian Apostol, Paula Kinikinilau, Csaba Gal, Ionut Botezatu; Michael Wiringi, Valentin Calafeteanu; Andrei Ursache, Andrei Radoi, Paulica Ion; Valentin Poparlan, Ovidiu Tonita; Viorel Lucaci, Mihai Macovei (capt), Daniel Carpo.  Replacements: Mihaita Lazar, Otar Turashvili, Alexandru Tarus, Johannes van Heerden, Stelian Burcea, Florin Surugiu, Florin Ionita, Florin Vlaicu. *Remind me to edit this if the USA win. Updated at 3.02pm BST

webTitle: France v Romania: Rugby World Cup 2015  as it happened
trailText: Despite failing to get into gear, France recorded a dominant, bonus point win over Romania after fielding a second string side
headline: France v Romania: Rugby World Cup 2015 – as it happened
standfirst: Despite failing to get into gear, France recorded a dominant, bonus point win over Romania after fielding a second string side
body:
9.53pm BST

Well, the scoreline says that France dominated. And they did. But, certainly in the first half, they were a mess and they did not really get it going terribly well in the second either. Having said that, this was a team with 13 changes from that one that faced Italy, so perhaps that rustiness can be excused as they learned how to operate with one another. They can argue that they got the job done too: a win and a bonus point sets them up very nicely in Pool D.

Romania will be delighted by their try and their grunt in the first half. They had a few flashes it will be interesting to see how they play against Italy: they could well give them a game. Thanks for reading, I<82><84>m off.

Updated at 10.03pm BST

9.49pm BST

FULL TIME: France 38-11 Romania

France have suddenly woken up, first La Roux, then Guitoune burst up the pitch as they seek another try. It<82><84>s a bit late for that now. And with that, Peyper puts this out of its misery.

9.48pm BST

TRY AND CONVERSION! France 38-11 Romania (Fickou + Kockott)

78 min: Quick ball from a French lineout on the Romania 22 works its way at speed to Fickou, he steps inside catching the entire Romania line off guard and he nips through to score under the posts. For a team that haven<82><84>t been on form, France can be pretty chuffed with the scoreline.

Updated at 9.55pm BST

9.43pm BST

75 min: Guitoune is denied a hat-trick. He races up the left wing, chips the ball over the try line then catches it on the bounce. But he is unable to fully touch the ball down as he struggles not to go over the deadball line. Unlucky, he<82><84>s had a good game in the midst of a patchy French display tonight.

9.41pm BST

TRY! France 31-11 Romania (Ursache)

74 min: Hang on: where did that come from? Romania kick a penalty to touch in the corner and as France pack the middle of the lineout, expecting Romania to drive through from there, a small raiding party peel off the front and whizz over the tryline.

Updated at 10.01pm BST

9.38pm BST

72 min: Well, if Romania weren<82><84>t done and dusted already, they are now. France, though, are slightly flattered by this scoreline. They have not been at their best and can probably expect some more hot talk from Saint-Andre in the changing room afterwards.

9.36pm BST

TRY AND CONVERSION! France 31-6 Romania (Fofana + Kockott)

70 min: Kockott replaces Parra for France, and his impact is immediate. He sets up an attack from which Dulin can offload to Fofana, who bumps and bursts his way over the tryline. No doubt about him grounding that one. France are scoring tries in bursts tonight, and will be delighted to have got the bonus point. Kockott takes over kicking duties too, and places the conversion through the posts.

Updated at 9.44pm BST

9.33pm BST

TRY AND CONVERSION! France 24-6 Romania (Guitoune + Parra)

68 min: It looks as if Guitoune is stopped short, then gets the ball over the line with a double, it not triple movement. Not that the TMO cares. He gives the try. Parra slots another conversion over. Possibly a contentious one there.

Updated at 9.40pm BST

9.31pm BST

66 min: Is this a try? France run again from the back of a scrum, but after some slick interplay, Parra gets caught. He<82><84>s up to the Romania 22 and the forwards take over. They batter their way a few yards forward and then France spread the ball out to the right wing. Guitoune, from 10 yards out, wriggles and writhes his way to the line. He thinks he<82><84>s over. Peyper doesn<82><84>t and goes to the TMO.

9.28pm BST

63 min: Being honest, this is not a game featuring much in the way of quality. Still, France are trying to run it now. They break up the right but get held back. Then break up the left, offloading willy nilly for the first time in the match. Parra attempts to play Fofana in down the blindside but the ball goes down and that<82><84>s the end of that brief surge.

9.25pm BST

60 min: Turashvilli rumbles off, Andrei Radoi replaces him at hooker for Romania. Romania get on the front foot and for a moment Ursache then Van Heerden look as though they are going to break through the French line. But France win the ball back and find a halfway line touch.

9.22pm BST

58 min: They blow it though. From the maul after the lineout, two players run into each other and Peyper blows up for a Romania penalty for obstruction, which is wellied well up the pitch.

9.21pm BST

56 min: Finally France do a bit or running and would do well to take notice of the fact that it works: in various fits and bursts they get to the Romania 22. Parra passes to Fickou, who darts into a tackle, and France ruck and maul it forwards now. Mas goes now but the referee brings the ball back for a penalty. From in front of the posts, France kick for touch as they look for tries for a bonus point.

Preamble

It<82><84>s been a little while since Romania used to make France sweat. In the 20 years between 1960 and 1980, Romania were a problem for the French and beat them six times in 22 Tests. Back then, Romania were strong with the communist government keen to fund the sport. But what politics gave it also took away, and a side that beat France, Wales and Scotland in the 80s was decimated in 1989 by the revolution in Romania. Five players died in the fighting, then money got so tight that kits, balls, facilities and grounds became unaffordable. The sport fell off a cliff and it<82><84>s been 25 years since Romania last worried France. Andy Bull tells the full tale here.

This is the 50th Test between the two sides and the first since 2006, when France won 62-14. And Romania are going for it: their starting XV is experience, featuring 648 caps and is largely the same team that lost 21-16 to Tonga in their last warm-up match. They will be all about the grunt up front, their powerful pack their key weapon. But they do feature Saracens<82><84> Catalin Fercu at full back. Arguably the most talented member of their team, he missed the 2011 tournament because he was too scared of flying to get on the plane. Something that did not amuse his friends.

But if Romania are all about the experience, France are about youth. They have made 13 changes to the side that beat Italy on Saturday and with an average age of 28, this is the youngest side to represent France in eight years. A second win would put them firmly on course for qualification from Pool D, while a bonus point would be very welcome while they<82><84>re at it.

Cautiously attritional are the best words for this so far.  8.16pm BST 14 min: France roll a maul forwards from the lineout, but have a penalty in the bag after from Romanian indiscipline. They kick for touch.  8.15pm BST 12 min: Scrum on the halfway line, and theres more chaos in the French front row as Lazar shoves Antonio about the place. The scrum is retaken and Romania are in charge once again, but it turns too far and France are given the push in. France dig in against the Romanians power and Picamoles takes quick ball out of the back. A high kick goes up, which is marked in the Romanian 22 and cleared well.  8.12pm BST 9 min: Flanquart makes a hash of claiming the kick-off and Romania steal possession. They start flinging it about, but a loose chip over the top is mopped up by Dulin and France clear up the pitch.  8.10pm BST So Parra slots the penalty over instead. Updated at 8.18pm BST  8.10pm BST 7 min: Nakaitaci comes off the back of the lineout with the ball at pace and France probe for the line. Romania get themselves offside twice, giving France the advantage. Parra knows it, so chips for the corner, safe in the knowledge that if it doesnt pay off they have a kick in front of the posts in the bag. It doesnt come off.   8.08pm BST 6 min: France keep running it, throwing the ball wide. Romania are concerned that the French have too much pace for them, so they have pressed right up to stop them getting through. But it means they concede a penalty for obstruction, which France kick to touch. French lineout on the Romania 22.  8.07pm BST 5 min: A big up and under from Fercu is claimed by Fickou and he is subsequently mobbed. The maul collapses, and the ref blows up, giving the scrum put in to France. Will be exciting to see what the Romanian packs does here  the answer is not quite so much damage but some. France run the ball.  8.05pm BST 3 min: Interesting: the Romania pack has substantially overpowered the French one there. The France scrum goes down and the Romanian pack celebrate like theyve just scored a try. This is going to be a battle of French backs v Romanian forwards. Updated at 8.29pm BST  8.04pm BST 2 min: Romania kick long and the France wing Nakaitaci claims. He races forwards and attempts to chip the Romanian defence. He doesnt get enough on the ball though and Romania can mop it up with ease.  8.03pm BST Were off: Jaco Peyper blows his whistle to get us underway and manages not to consult the TMO over it. Tales kicks off, Romania in yellow claim and scrum half Surugiu clears the ball to the halfway line.   8.00pm BST Corbyn-watch: most of the French sing their anthem, and do so reasonably tunefully. For rugby players. The Romanians are virtually all giving it some proper gusto though. 1-0 to the men from Eastern Europe.  7.57pm BST Here come the teams. They march down the tunnel to some dramatic music. No pyro though. Which is a good thing. Anthems ahoy!  7.56pm BST Meanwhile, Owen Gibson is back is his old Olympic stomping ground. This is what it looks like inside the stadium: Here's the view from the back tier. I'll stop now. pic.twitter.com/GKf1BNhldj  7.55pm BST Expect France to attempt to outpace Romania, theres plenty of speed in their side tonight. We lined up a team that will look to move the ball and provide some momentum, the France backs coach Patrice Lagisquet said. We hope that this game plan will be easier to implement than against Italy, where there were loads of interruptions. Will it mean a game of free-flowing, running rugby? Or will Romania smother them?  7.47pm BST The France coach Philippe Saint-Andr is chit chatting before the match. He says his team need to be patient, and that all 13 players he has brought in can make a point to him about getting in the starting lineup against Ireland. Hes reasonably unimpressed by the Olympic Stadium though. To be honest, I came here for the Olympics, he shrugs.  7.35pm BST France are coming into this match on the back of three wins on the trot - against England, Scotland and Italy. Romania are arriving on the back of defeats to Tonga, Edinburgh and a 10-10 draw with Leeds Carnegie. So it seems likely that there is only one way this match is going to go. Theyre playing at the Olympic Stadium, which looks absolutely cavernous this evening. It also looks remarkably good filled with rugby posts, soperhaps its time for a rethink on its future occupants. Do Quins fancy moving in?  7.18pm BST Before we get to France v Romania, theres some hot breaking news for Argentina (and Gloucester, to some degree), which Ive lifted directly from PA: Argentina lock Mariano Galarza has received a nine-week ban and will miss the remainder of the World Cup. Galarza was cited for making contact with the eye or eye area of New Zealand forward Brodie Retallick during last Sundays Pool C game between the countries at Wembley. In a statement, Rugby World Cup Limited said: Galarza denied the act of foul play. Having conducted a detailed review of all the available evidence, including all camera angles and additional evidence, including from Retallick, the player and submissions from his representatives, the judicial officer Christopher Quinlan QC upheld the citing on the basis that the player had committed the act of foul play. With respect to the sanction, the judicial officer deemed the act of foul play merited a low-end entry point of 12 weeks. Due to the need to deter such acts of foul play, he added an additional period of one week. However, taking into account mitigating factors including his excellent disciplinary record, the judicial officer reduced the suspension to a period of nine weeks. Galarzas ban takes effect immediately, and he cannot play again until November 26. That means the Gloucester forward will miss part of his clubs campaign as his suspension does not expire until more than three weeks after the World Cup final. Galarza has 48 hours in which to appeal once he has received the written decision.  7.06pm BST France: 15. Brice Dulin; 14. Sofiane Guitoune, 13. Gal Fickou, 12. Wesley Fofana, 11. Noa Nakaitaci; 10. Rmi Tals, 9. Morgan Parra; 8. Louis Picamoles, 7. Fulgence Ouedraogo, 6. Yannick Nyanga; 5. Alexandre Flanquart, 4. Bernard Le Roux; 3. Uini Atonio, 2. Dimitri Szarzewski, 1. Vincent Debaty.Replacements: Benjamin Kayser, Eddy Ben Arous, Nicolas Mas, Yoann Maestri, Damien Chouly, Rory Kockott, Frdric Michalak, Mathieu Bastareaud. Romania: 15. Catalin Fercu; 14. Madalin Lemnaru, 13. Paula Kinikinilau, 12. Florin Vlaicu, 11. Adrian Apostol; 10. Danut Dumbrava, 9. Florin Surugiu; 8. Mihai Macovei, 7. Viorel Lucaci, 6. Valentin Ursache; 5. Johan Van Heerden, 4. Valentin Popirlan; 3. Paulica Ion, 2. Otar Turashvilli, 1. Mihai Lazar.Replacements: Andrei Radoi, Andrei Ursache, Horatiu Pungea, Ovidiu Tonita, Stelian Burcea, Valentin Calafeteanu, Ionut Botezatu, Csaba Gal Man in the middle: Jaco Peyper  3.56pm BST Its been a little while since Romania used to make France sweat. In the 20 years between 1960 and 1980, Romania were a problem for the French and beat them six times in 22 Tests. Back then, Romania were strong with the communist government keen to fund the sport. But what politics gave it also took away, and a side that beat France, Wales and Scotland in the 80s was decimated in 1989 by the revolution in Romania. Five players died in the fighting, then money got so tight that kits, balls, facilities and grounds became unaffordable. The sport fell off a cliff and its been 25 years since Romania last worried France. Andy Bull tells the full tale here. This is the 50th Test between the two sides and the first since 2006, when France won 62-14. And Romania are going for it: their starting XV is experience, featuring 648 caps and is largely the same team that lost 21-16 to Tonga in their last warm-up match. They will be all about the grunt up front, their powerful pack their key weapon. But they do feature Saracens Catalin Fercu at full back. Arguably the most talented member of their team, he missed the 2011 tournament because he was too scared of flying to get on the plane. Something that did not amuse his friends. But if Romania are all about the experience, France are about youth. They have made 13 changes to the side that beat Italy on Saturday and with an average age of 28, this is the youngest side to represent France in eight years. A second win would put them firmly on course for qualification from Pool D, while a bonus point would be very welcome while theyre at it. Updated at 7.02pm BST

webTitle: The great east European road trip part four: Romania
trailText: Romania’s Maramures region may be modernising in places but take a walk in the countryside among forests, wooden churches and hay stooks and you’ll feel like you’ve stepped back in time
headline: The great east European road trip part four: Romania
standfirst:
Romania’s Maramures region may be modernising in places but take a walk in the countryside among forests, wooden churches and hay stooks and you’ll feel like you’ve stepped back in time

• Week 1: Croatia Week 2: Albania Week 3: Bulgaria Next: Slovakia
body:
Driving over the Gut<83>i Pass into northern Romania<82><84>s Mara valley the signs were good: a summit mysterious with cloud, an old woman selling honey by the road, and as we dropped out of the forest and back into sunlight, long panoramas of rolling countryside dotted with hay stooks leading off into the purple ridges of the Carpathians. People say that if you want old Europe, a place steeped in the rhythms of nature and skills lost elsewhere, then Romania<82><84>s Maramures region is for you. Guidebooks talk of medieval isolation and ways of life unchanged since the third century AD. And then there was William Blacker<82><84>s sublime 2009 book The Enchanted Way which cast a deeply romantic glow over the entire place. No wonder we were fired up with great expectations.

So when we began to see the villages, there was some consternation. Yes, there were a lot of traditional wooden houses with great square ornamental gateways and barns where homemade haymaking tools were leaning. But there were other buildings too: block-built houses with ugly balconies and UPVC windows. These did not fit. Nor did the old man in a Chelsea football shirt. Expectations are vital in the travel trade and ours were not being met, not yet at least.

We reached the village of Breb and checked in at Pensiunea Marioara (doubles from <82>33 B&B). Did we want a room in the old wooden house in the garden, or one in the new, more substantial, concrete house? We chose the concrete house because we could look at the wooden house from our balcony. There was traditional Maramures music playing, but on CD. It was incessantly jaunty. Our hostess, Marioara, soothed us with excellent homemade delicacies. Next day we set out walking. The wooden churches of the area were a big reason to come here, but the first we came to was of concrete. A conversation with an old basket maker was abruptly terminated by three Italian tourists who stepped between us, taking pictures.

We wandered on, a little disconcerted, towards the village of Hoteni. The plum trees were laden with fruit and the freshly cut meadows were speckled with stooks. At the church I watched a man remove his straw hat <82><80><9c> the oddly conical be-ribboned traditional Maramures one <82><80><9c> and cross himself as he passed. Nearby, the road was being rebuilt and there were traffic lights and growling lorries: we cut away across country, following any path we could find. An eagle soared. We ate our lunch in the shade of a walnut tree. My wife Sophie and daughter Maddy headed back to Breb while I made a detour, up a hill to where two men, both named Vasile, were loading hay on a horse-drawn cart. One of them spoke French. I had a go at forking hay, but the older Vasile soon took the tool back. <82><93>There<82><84>s rain coming, we<82><84>ll have to be quicker.<82><9d> A few minutes later I found myself sitting on top of the wagon, lurching down secret back roads to his house where I was taught how to stook and rewarded with a tot of homemade spirits.

Where was the wooden church, I asked? Vasile showed me a path and along it I met another man, also called Vasile. My journey was interrupted with a trip to his house where I drank from his well. At the church I watched woodpeckers attacking the steeple, then wandered on, coming across an old man in a traditional smock, negotiating the price of a football-sized cheese with a man on horseback. I walked with him to his house and found his grandson helping to re-shingle the roof. <82><93>Where are you going?<82><9d> he asked. It turned out he was on holiday from a job in London. <82><93>Is your name Vasile?<82><9d> I asked. It was, and it was his grandfather<82><84>s name too.

<82><93>Maramures has changed a lot,<82><9d> he said, <82><93>People have gone abroad and made money and now are building new houses.<82><9d> But this Vasile, only 28 years old, had a view on that. <82><93>It all happened very fast, but now we are realising that we have to value the old and traditional too. I<82><84>m rebuilding my grandfather<82><84>s house, but I won<82><84>t change a thing <82><80><9c> it will be all traditional, exactly like a century ago.<82><9d>

He showed me inside, the two rooms hung with embroidered hangings and the roof studded with cooking pots. Back outside the 89-year-old was helping his 86-year-old wife dig out a ditch. When I asked for a photograph, she screeched in alarm and disappeared, only to reappear with a fresh headscarf, <82><93>You can<82><84>t photograph me in that old thing.<82><9d>

<82><93>They stay young by working,<82><9d> said the younger Vasile. <82><93>They don<82><84>t retire or watch television.<82><9d>

When I got back to Breb, Sophie and Maddy reported similar experiences: helping an old lady mash pears and plums ready for brandy-making and watching others spin wool with distaffs. Maramures, we concluded, still has enchantments and a few parts of life may be unchanged since medieval times, but not all.

The next day we drove right up the valley heading east, and took the Moc<84><92>ni<85>a, a steam railway starting from Viseu de Sus. The line was built in 1932 and run primarily for logging operations in the remote mountain forests on the Ukraine border. Tourists, however, now provide a big subsidiary income. The train lurched and shuddered up the gorge of the river Vaser in a charmingly random fashion, 22km up to a logging station, Paltin, where we had lunch and walked for an hour in one of Europe<82><84>s most remote forests. Back at the locomotive I chatted to our driver, Dumitru Brendea. <82><93>There is nowhere better than Maramures,<82><9d> he said. And the culture, I wondered, did he love it? Yes. And the music? His face clouded over. <82><93>No. Not me. I love The Rolling Stones.<82><9d>

<82> Wild Frontiers provided Kevin<82><84>s walking tour (a section of the Enchanted Way). Full 10-day tour is <82>1,745 inc food, accommodation, land transport, not flights, 020 7736 3968, wildfrontierstravel.com. Roving Romania assisted with the visit to the Moc<84><92>ni<85>a railway (roving-romania.co.uk)

Follow Kevin<82><84>s journey on instagram.com/kevinrushby; contribute your tips on things for him to see and do on the way on twitter.com/kevin_rushby; and read the previous weeks<82><84> dispatches at gu.com/p/4bjv9/stw

webTitle: Bringing in the scalps: the woman leading Romania's war on corruption
trailText: Laura Codruţa Kövesi presides over agency that has brought cases against mayors, MPs – and now the prime minister
headline: Bringing in the scalps: the woman leading Romania's war on corruption
standfirst: Laura Codruţa Kövesi presides over agency that has brought cases against mayors, judges, MPs – and now the prime minister
body:
Victor Ponta<82><84>s decision on Wednesday to resign as Romania<82><84>s prime minister may not be the end of his woes. Street protests this week were merely the culmination of months of pressure triggered by a fraud and corruption case against him.

Ponta is not alone. A slew of politicians, mayors, judges and prosecutors have been targeted in an anti-corruption drive quite unlike any other in eastern Europe <82><80><9c> or the world for that matter. And it is a quiet, unassuming chief prosecutor, Laura Codru<85>a K<83>vesi, who is bringing in the scalps.

<82><93>Before 2005, Romanian justice was not independent,<82><9d> says K<83>vesi, 42, in an interview given before Ponta<82><84>s resignation. <82><93>This is why there was not enough courage to open complex investigations against high-level officials.<82><9d>

Related: Bucharest nightclub fire: Romania's PM and government resign after protests

A specialist anti-corruption agency, known by the acronym DNA, was founded in 2003, and it took a few years for it to narrow its focus on high-level graft <82><80><9c> cases involving more than <80><9a>10,000 (<82>7,000) <82><80><9c> and for it to start bringing successful prosecutions.

Nowadays there are 120 prosecutors working on more than 6,000 cases. The entrance to the DNA<82><84>s central Bucharest offices is permanently staked out by television news crews waiting to see who will turn up next for questioning.

Last year the agency successfully prosecuted 24 mayors, five MPs, two ex-ministers and a former prime minister, not to mention more than 1,000 other individuals, including judges and prosecutors, with a conviction rate above 90%.

<82><93>This year we have investigated 12 members of parliament, two of them being former ministers,<82><9d> says K<83>vesi, who was appointed head of DNA in 2013. <82><93>We have investigated two sitting ministers, one of whom went from his ministerial chair directly to pre-trial detention.<82><9d>

In September, Bucharest<82><84>s mayor, Sorin Oprescu, was arrested after being accused of taking kickbacks from companies awarded contracts by the city.

However, Ponta is by far the biggest target to date. According to K<83>vesi, the investigations into the outgoing prime minister lasted about four months, at the end of which he was formally indicted on multiple counts of forgery, money laundering and being an accessory to tax evasion, dating from a period between 2007 and 2008 when he was still a practising lawyer.

Prosecutors had hoped to investigate him for activities while in office, but in June Romania<82><84>s parliament voted down an attempt to lift his parliamentary immunity.

Romanians seem to have been impressed by the activities of DNA: according to one recent poll, 60% of people said they trusted the agency, while only 11% said they trusted parliament.

However, not everyone is happy with DNA<82><84>s activities. Barely a week goes by without K<83>vesi being attacked in the media.

After he was formally indicted, Ponta denounced the prosecutor in charge of his case on his Facebook page, saying Romania<82><84>s only problem was <82><93>the obsession of a totally unprofessional prosecutor trying to make a name by inventing and imagining facts and untrue situations from 10 years ago<82><9d>.

Others have questioned the political motivations of prosecutors at DNA, though the agency has successfully gone after plenty of politicians on both sides of the parliamentary aisle.

Some have also criticised the use of wiretaps, suggesting it is behaviour taken from the playbook of the Securitate, the feared communist-era secret police.

K<83>vesi dismisses those concerns, saying that every wiretap has to be authorised by a judge and that such monitoring is <82><93>a tool used all over the world. It is used in EU member states. It is a common tool for prosecutors.<82><9d>

The criticism and public attention has apparently had little impact on K<83>vesi. <82><93>Before being chief prosecutor of DNA I was the general prosecutor of Romania for six years, so for the last nine years I have had enough time to get accustomed to these things. Fortunately there are people who also praise me, so things are balanced,<82><9d> she says.

The biggest challenges for prosecutors come from politicians, she adds. <82><93>Every two weeks they come with a new bill trying to change or amend the current provisions. Trying to limit our possibilities of investigations. Trying to amend the criminal code. Trying to deprive us of our tools to limit our possibilities of investigation. What<82><84>s curious is they never try to improve the legislation to help us more,<82><9d> she says.

Strong support in Romania and within the EU has made it harder to hinder the efforts and independence of DNA. <82><93>Every time we hear that they try to pass a new law limiting our possibilities, we go public and we take a stand regarding this issue,<82><9d> says K<83>vesi.

Despite all this, there is still a long way to go. Romania ranked joint last among EU members on Transparency International<82><84>s 2014 corruption perceptions index, alongside Italy, Greece and Bulgaria. But for K<83>vesi at least there is a sense that the agency is making a difference.

<82><93>I do think DNA<82><84>s activities have changed the mentality of Romanian citizens,<82><9d> she says. <82><93>They are aware now that they don<82><84>t need to pay bribes in order to be granted their rights.<82><9d>

Strong support in Romania and within the EU has made it harder to hinder the efforts and independence of DNA. Every time we hear that they try to pass a new law limiting our possibilities, we go public and we take a stand regarding this issue, says Kvesi. Despite all this, there is still a long way to go. Romania ranked joint last among EU members on Transparency Internationals 2014 corruption perceptions index, alongside Italy, Greece and Bulgaria. But for Kvesi at least there is a sense that the agency is making a difference. I do think DNAs activities have changed the mentality of Romanian citizens, she says. They are aware now that they dont need to pay bribes in order to be granted their rights.

webTitle: Arsenal sign Romania Under-16 captain Vlad Dragomir for 71,000
trailText: Arsenal have signed the Romania Under-16 captain Vlad Dragomir from ACS Poli Timisoara for £71,000
headline: Arsenal sign Romania Under-16 captain Vlad Dragomir for £71,000
standfirst:
• Midfielder was also wanted by Internazionale
• Gunners have been monitoring him, says agent
body:
Arsenal have signed the Romania Under-16 captain Vlad Dragomir from ACS Poli Timisoara for <80><9a>100,000 (<82>71,000) and he will begin his career at the north London club as a first-year scholar.

The midfielder, who was wanted by Internazionale, has been pictured holding an Arsenal shirt alongside Dick Law, the club<82><84>s transfer negotiator, and his agent, Catalin Sarmasan.

<82><93>I am very glad and I hope not to disappoint anyone,<82><9d> Dragomir, who signed a three-year contract, said. <82><93>The Arsenal offer seemed the best to me, I felt that this is my place.<82><9d>

Arsenal will announce the full list of their first-year scholars next week, with the majority of them having progressed from the club<82><84>s Hale End academy.

Sarmasan said: <82><93>I offered Vlad to Arsenal a year and a half ago and they have monitored him closely. In my opinion, he is one of the most talented young players in Europe at the moment.<82><9d>
