webTitle: Northern Irelands Michael ONeill hopeful of progress after Romania draw
trailText: After a 0-0 draw kept Northern Ireland second behind Romania in Group F, O’Neill said: ‘When we look back at it I think we will see it as a really good point’
headline: Northern Ireland’s Michael O’Neill hopeful of progress after Romania draw
standfirst:
• 0-0 draw keeps Northern Ireland second behind Romania in Group F
• O’Neill: ‘When we look back at it I think we will see it as a really good point’
body:
It speaks substantial volumes for the distance Northern Ireland have travelled under Michael O<82><84>Neill during this fruitful Euro 2016 qualifying campaign that there was a notable sense of deflation after the scoreless draw against Romania.

Northern Ireland have displayed discipline <82><80><9c> and even shards of magnificence <82><80><9c> in a campaign that had brought four victories out of five before the visit of the group leaders and favourites.

Related: Euro 2016 roundup: winning hat-tricks for Ronaldo and Lewandowski

There could not have been a greater contrast between the respective coaches, either; studious O<82><84>Neill, quietly obsessive and increasingly respected, and Anghel Iordanescu, a veteran football brain, bombastic former politician and military overlord.

Yet Iordanescu<82><84>s manoeuvrings failed to outflank O<82><84>Neill, who admitted that, while the Windsor Park encounter failed to showcase the prominent aspects of both teams, he had watched the best of Group F. Northern Ireland<82><84>s primary aim was to avoid defeat to keep on track for qualification <82><80><9c> and a composed display from the stand-in goalkeeper Michael McGovern of Hamilton, winning his first competitive cap, clearly helped. They were far from graceful on Saturday, but a point against a side ranked 12th in the world, and who had only conceded a single goal in their own campaign, has to be viewed in a positive light.

However, there was a sentiment that, having finished the stronger, all three points could have been claimed, particularly as Romania had to cope without five key players, including Lucian Sanmartean, the ringleader of the Irish tormentors in the previous fixture, a 2-0 win in Bucharest last November.

As it is, Romania remain top of the group, and with third-placed Hungary having closed the gap on the Irish to two points, following victory over Finland, there must be no hint of complacency. O<82><84>Neill possesses that vague, indefinable, managerial edge which suggests his men will maintain their collective work ethic.

In real terms, Northern Ireland will be booking their tickets to France next summer if they keep their nerve and work through occasional bouts of anxiety in possession.

A September double-header, away to Faroe Islands who beat a self-destructive Greece, and at home to the Hungarians, will be fascinating. Six much-anticipated points should suffice for a first appearance at the European finals.

O<82><84>Neill said: <82><93>We have a difficult game in the Faroe Islands especially since they won against Greece so they will be buoyant, then we have a massive game against Hungary here.

<82><93>I hope September puts us in a strong situation. This was always going to be a difficult game because of the scheduling and because it was Romania, but we have worked extremely hard in the six games so far.<82><9d>

These are strangely special, electric, times for Northern Ireland. Occasionally vulnerable on the counterattack against their opponents, this new status takes some getting used to. A forceful finish at a still under-construction Windsor Park will have pleased O<82><84>Neill though, despite a glaring miss from the in-form striker, Kyle Lafferty, the talisman of this ascendancy.

<82><93>We are slightly disappointed that we didn<82><84>t take the three points,<82><9d> O<82><84>Neill explained. <82><93>When we look back at it I think we will see it as a really good point.

<82><93>The most pleasing thing for me was the level of desire the team showed. We contested every single ball and covered a lot of ground. We have played better in the group <82><80><9c> there is no doubt about that <82><80><9c> but you have to give credit to the opposition because we were playing against a good team.<82><9d>

With four games remaining, the worst-case scenario is surely a play-off place. <82><93>At the outset of the campaign the top three was our focus,<82><9d> O<82><84>Neill said. <82><93>We are obviously in a very strong position to at least obtain that but we are at a stage that I as a manager and the players, want more than that.<82><9d>

The Northern Irish at least have a new handle on tetchy situations, and, in theory, the hardest fixtures are now behind them. Therefore, when Hungary check in to Belfast they can, potentially, add fluency, maximum points <82><80><9c> and long, aching, realisation of Euro ambitions.

Northern Ireland McGovern, C McLaughlin, McAuley, J Evans (Cathcart 80), Brunt; Baird, Ward (C Evans 80), Davis, Norwood, Dallas; Lafferty.

Romania Tatarusanu, Papp, Grigore, Chiriches, Sepsi; Prepeli<88><80>a, Pintilli; Maxim (Tamas 88), Torje; Chipclu (Stancu 61); Keseru (Andone 72)

webTitle: Northern Ireland 0-0 Romania | Euro 2016 qualifying Group F match report
trailText: Kyle Lafferty hit a late shot goalwards but only into the arms of the Romania goalkeeper as Northern Ireland drew 0-0 in Belfast
headline: Northern Ireland’s Kyle Lafferty fails to break Romania deadlock
standfirst: NA
body:
A sweeping sense of tension, but relief, nevertheless. Northern Ireland managed to hold their nerve against Romania to earn a gritty scoreless draw as Group F now takes on a fascinating shade.

Michael O<82><84>Neill<82><84>s men lacked craft and fluency for long periods and had to settle for a more prosaic approach against the group leaders and favourites, who went into this encounter without five key players. Indeed the Romania coach, Anghel Iordanescu, will be the slightly more satisfied with the result, cementing as it does the Tricolorii<82><84>s status.

Related: Republic of Ireland 1-1 Scotland | Euro 2016 Group D qualifier match report

The hosts could <82><80><9c> and possibly should <82><80><9c> have made real capital, as they pressed with due diligence in the latter stages, only to fall short when it came to composure in front of goal. Kyle Lafferty, the personification of Northern Ireland<82><84>s fine campaign with five goals so far to take them to these relatively rarefied heights, really should have netted late on.

Only he can explain how he managed to blast the ball straight at the Romania goalkeeper, Ciprian Tatarusanu, from close range. In front of a bank of home supporters, settled into the new east stand at an under-reconstruction Windsor Park, there was tangible frustration. It was that kind of night, with the new recruit Stuart Dallas also going close on three occasions.

Still, the Northern Irish lived dangerously themselves at times, with the Romanians looking potent on the counterattack, particularly in the first-half.

Fortunately for O<82><84>Neill, his side grew stronger as the game wore on. The outcome keeps the men in green in the mix and a home draw against Iordanescu<82><84>s side is hardly the stuff of a campaign sea-change.

Northern Ireland next travel to the Faroe Islands before a home tie against Hungary, both in early September. And while they are in a great position, five points from probable qualification, according to O<82><84>Neill, this will not be the last of the nervous fixtures.

<82><93>The two games in September are now crucial,<82><9d> the Northern Ireland manager said. <82><93>It keeps us a point behind Romania.

<82><93>I always said 18 points is key for us. All the games going forward will be difficult. Tonight<82><84>s game was the tensest for us so far as both teams were determined not to be beaten and the group will be decided by the finest of margins. We expect the rest of the games to follow into the same pattern. We<82><84>re pleased with a point, I wouldn<82><84>t say delighted. We had opportunities to win the game and I would say their goalkeeper was the busier of the two.<82><9d>

Related: Euro 2016 roundup: winning hat-tricks for Ronaldo and Lewandowski

Romania<82><84>s best chance fell to Gabriel Torje, sweeping goalwards through the middle, but his shot was deflected beyond the post by Jonny Evans with Michael McGovern wrongfooted. Both sides carried fortune, in the end.

O<82><84>Neill understands that his team must display more composure and finesse when it comes to the crunch, particularly now that third-placed Hungary have cut the gap to two points, spearing the group to a fascinating climax.

<82><93>We just didn<82><84>t capitalise on the opportunities we had, a little more care in the box or a little more precision with the finishing and we could have had all three, but it<82><84>s a big point,<82><9d> added O<82><84>Neill. <82><93>It cements our place in the top three I think and leaves it all to play for in September.<82><9d>

Ultimately, a draw at home to Romania, in the wider context, can still be viewed as something of a success.

webTitle: Roy Carroll misses Northern Ireland summit with Romania after illness
trailText: Northern Ireland have been dealt a blow before their match against Romania, with the reserve goalkeeper Michael McGovern required to replace the ill Roy Carroll
headline: Roy Carroll misses Northern Ireland summit with Romania after illness
standfirst:
• Keeper has not recovered from abdominal pains for Euro 2016 qualifier
• Michael O’Neill confident that replacement Michael McGovern will excel
body:
Northern Ireland have been dealt a blow before their key match against Romania, with their No1 goalkeeper, the experienced Roy Carroll, failing to recover from illness. Michael McGovern, of Hamilton Academical, is set to replace him.

The 37-year-old Carroll has been suffering from abdominal pains through the week and did not train on Thursday or Friday. The manager, Michael O<82><84>Neill, had hoped the Notts County player would recover in time for the game against the Group F leaders at Windsor Park.

McGovern, who has only three caps, will thus be making his competitive international debut in a match where victory would elevate Northern Ireland to the top of the group halfway through the campaign. But O<82><84>Neill is confident McGovern will excel and a fine display by the 30-year-old in a friendly against Scotland at Hampden Park in March suggests Northern Ireland can rely on him.

The switch means the national goalkeeping coach, Maik Taylor <82><80><9c> officially retired and whose last game was in September 2012 for Millwall <82><80><9c> has been parachuted into the squad as back-up behind Trevor Carson of Cheltenham Town.

O<82><84>Neill says generating expectations and memories is fuelling his overachieving squad. He has worked tirelessly since the abject performances during the last World Cup qualifying campaign and, with four wins out of five, the 45-year-old former Northern Ireland international is in a welcome position of strength.

The Ulstermen and qualification for major tournaments have been strangers to each other for a generation. Not since the 1986 World Cup have Northern Ireland troubled the bigger stages.

The work put in by O<82><84>Neill, who took over in 2011, is beginning to bear fruit, with the country buoyed by the team<82><84>s industry and consistency. Everyone in the Northern Ireland camp is relishing Saturday night<82><84>s contest, the manager said.

<82><93>We want to create expectations; we want to create memories,<82><9d> said O<82><84>Neill, whose side are a point behind Romania. <82><93>Some players have had big nights but nothing that comes close to qualification. We have given ourselves an opportunity. It<82><84>s nice that people are talking about it [qualification] but we aren<82><84>t sitting here thinking <82><9c>formality<82><84>. It has taken three years to get to this point. We have a group of honest boys looking forward to this.<82><9d>

His squad hope to avenge their only setback in this campaign when a long night in Bucharest<82><84>s National Stadium ended in a 2-0 defeat.

Northern Ireland have a more solid team than they had in that game last November for what will be the biggest game in memory for many fans in attendance. Around 10,000 will be shoe-horned into Windsor Park, with building work accelerated since an enforced demolition of the popular west stand, after major cracks appeared in foundations following the 2-1 March victory over Finland.

The presence of the influential captain, Steven Davis, alongside the defender Jonny Evans and the winger Jamie Ward is a huge boost. It is also no coincidence that the defeat in Romania occurred with that trio absent.

<82><93>The nature of international football is that you need things to fall in line and with our resources we need that availability of players,<82><9d> O<82><84>Neill said. <82><93>I need Steven and Kyle [Lafferty] and Jonny to be fit.

<82><93>It<82><84>s credit to my players the condition they are in and how they have worked. We have had no withdrawals, which says a lot. I see an edge to the players and see how they are ready to play. I am looking forward to the game and we couldn<82><84>t have asked for the preparation to be any better.<82><9d>

It helps that O<82><84>Neill is getting the best out of the rangy striker Lafferty, who has five goals in qualifying, one behind the overall leading scorer, England<82><84>s Danny Welbeck. Yet, soaring hype aside, it is not, in essence, a win-at-all-costs match for O<82><84>Neill against his counterpart, the veteran Anghel Iordanescu.

<82><93>This isn<82><84>t a more significant game than Finland,<82><9d> he said. <82><93>Finland was more important as we had come off a defeat [in Romania]. I just think it is a game where we can take a massive stride but equally, if it doesn<82><84>t go our way, we will still be in second place.<82><9d>

Romania<82><84>s star midfielder, Lucian Sanmartean, and the vastly experienced defender Razvan Rat are out with injuries. is an admirer of Iordanescu <82><80><9c> nicknamed The General <82><80><9c> and feels Saturday night<82><84>s visitors will be positive in nature.

He said: <82><93>They have a more attacking team than the previous coach, who was slightly more conservative. I know what team they are likely to play. It<82><84>s hard to judge as they have only played two real games, but he set down a marker in Bucharest with his attacking approach and selection.<82><9d>

webTitle: Letter: Richard Johnson was held in high esteem in Romania
trailText: Sheila Seacroft writes: In the hugely popular Romanian historical epic Columna, directed by Mircea Drăgăn, Richard Johnson played Tiberius, a heroic Roman officer
headline: Letter: Richard Johnson was held in high esteem in Romania
standfirst: NA
body: Richard Johnson was held in high esteem in Romania. In the hugely popular Romanian historical epic Columna (1968), directed by Mircea Dr<84><92>g<84><92>n, he played Tiberius, a heroic Roman officer who attempts to unite the conquerors with the local Dacian people and create what will become the Romanian nation. His last film, Radiator, was shown at the Transylvania international film festival in Cluj last week, and Richard had been set to receive a lifetime achievement award. Radiator<82><84>s director Tom Browne accepted it in his honour.

In the hugely popular Romanian historical epic Columna (1968), directed by Mircea Drgn, he played Tiberius, a heroic Roman officer who attempts to unite the conquerors with the local Dacian people and create what will become the Romanian nation. Radiators director Tom Browne accepted it in his honour.

webTitle: Romania stake their claim as Tommaso Allan sends Italy home in style
trailText: With their Six Nations place under increasing scrutiny at the World Cup, Italy will have been relieved to have won their final game comfortably 32-22 against Romania at Sandy Park
headline: Romania stake their claim as Tommaso Allan sends Italy home in style
standfirst: NA
body:
Jacques Brunel maintained Italy were <82><93>not celebrating anything<82><9d> after they defeated Romania and secured automatic qualification for the next World Cup. But the coach<82><84>s words belied the relief he must have felt after their final performance in this tournament. Italy scored four tries, and could feel optimistic about the excellent performance of their young fly-half Tommaso Allan.

Whatever hopes Romania had of stealing third spot in Pool D ended when the lock Johann van Heerden was sent to the sin-bin in the 16th minute for trying to kick the ball out of scrum-half Edoardo Gori<82><84>s hands. The yellow card left Romania<82><84>s pack 118kg lighter and effectively decommissioned their most potent weapon, the scrum.

<82><93>I wasn<82><84>t very happy,<82><9d> said their coach Lynn Howells. <82><93>Every time we<82><84>ve been on the field against a tier one nation we<82><84>ve given away a yellow card and realistically it<82><84>s another 10 points and that<82><84>s the difference between winning and losing.<82><9d>

Yet a second-half performance that included three tries for the Oaks <82><80><9c> the most they have scored in a World Cup match in 12 years <82><80><9c> suggests they still have plenty to say on the subject of who deserves a place at European Rugby<82><84>s top table. As Howells said, <82><93>we were able to score points, which is something that Romania have not been renowned for, scoring tries. What it shows is how close it is. I think there<82><84>s an avenue to be able to go and play against these [tier one] teams.<82><9d>

The game had promised plenty and Romania took the lead from a penalty after their first scrum, two and half minutes in, monstering Italy in a maul as powerful as anything they delivered in their last-minute win against Canada. Their own defence was exposed minutes later. Gori exploited a gap from an Italian lineout and crossed; Romania were given a lifeline when the TMO showed he had failed to ground the ball.

Romania<82><84>s players just could not cover enough ground and Italy toyed with them, stringing the ball out wide, then sending it all the way back. A speedy interjection from centre Michele Campagnaro gave Leonardo Sarto an easy touchdown in the left-hand corner. Allan did not make the conversion, but it was a rare mistake. His highlights reel included a devilish kick into the corner, which would have brought about an instant try if Giovanbattista Venditti<82><84>s throw had been straight; a try from a solo sprint to the line; and another created for Francesco Minto in similar fashion.

Romania<82><84>s only first-half attack on Italy<82><84>s line demonstrated both the strength and weakness of their forward-oriented play. Their supporters chanted loudly as the Romanian pack, led by captain Valentin Ursache, butted themselves within touching distance of a try. But they worked themselves to an impasse, only releasing the ball to the backs when both momentum and overlap had been lost.

The crowd, who had swung their flags jauntily to Italy<82><84>s national anthem, seemed initially to be biased by the presence of the Exeter signing Campagnaro, making his first appearance at his new home ground. But they changed allegiance in the second half when, with half an hour left of their World Cup, Romania ran at the thick blue line with renewed verve, bringing tries from the replacement wing Adrian Apostol and second-row Valentin Poparlan and flashes of flair from Paula Kinikinilau.

Two minutes from full time, Romania won a scrum in front of the posts and Florin Vlaicu flighted a long pass to see Apostol over in the corner. It was a classy move, and one that made Romania look very much like Italy<82><84>s equals.

Tries Sarto, Gori, Allan, Zanni. Cons Allan 3. Pens Allan 2.

Romania Fercu; Lemnaru, Kinikinilau, Vlaicu, Botezatu; Wiringi (Gai, 41), Calafeteanu (Bratu, 60); Lazar (Pungea, 66), Turashvili (Radoi, 58), Ion (A Ursache, 41), Poparlan, Van Heerden (Antonescu, 55), V Ursache (capt), (Burcea, 48), Lucaci (V Ursache, 56), Carpo.

Tries Apostol 2, Popirlan. Cons Vlaicu 2. Pen Vlaicu.

Sin-bin Van Heerden.

Referee R Poite (Fr). Attendance 11,450.

webTitle: Irelands Simon Zebo inspired by Usain Bolt as team prepare to play Romania | Kevin Mitchell
trailText: Simon Zebo, Ireland full-back, has said his team are not taking victory over Romania for granted when the team’s meet in Rugby World Cup at Wembley
headline: Ireland’s Simon Zebo inspired by Usain Bolt as team prepare to play Romania
standfirst: The Ireland full-back says his team are not taking victory over Romania for granted when the team’s meet in Rugby World Cup at Wembley
body:
It is not just politeness that prevents the Irish from playing down their obvious superiority over Romania <82><80><9c> ranked 17th in the world and worth it <82><80><9c> at Wembley on Sunday afternoon. The team name that has seeped into conversations in the first week of the tournament, Japan, is enough to unsettle comfortable assumptions about who should be bowing down to whom and, although Romania are a rough and tumble outfit who gave France moments of flickering concern at the breakdown in midweek, Joe Schmidt is not one for assuming the sun will come up until it is blazing in his face.

Despite being hailed as the oldest Irish starting lineup in the 24-year-history of the tournament, his squad have no more of a baby-pink glow than do their gnarled opponents, who come with nothing to show for their contribution but a lot of hard-earned bruises.

Schmidt, as stats-savvy as any coach here, bore the look of a startled gazelle when his players<82><84> long-toothedness was put to him at their posh training camp at St George<82><84>s Park in Burton-upon-Trent on Friday. <82><93>Well, we<82><84>re the oldest and they<82><84>ve got 728 caps,<82><9d> he said, <82><93>so let<82><84>s throw away the Zimmer frames.<82><9d>

Like most maths myths, it is a tough one to pin down but, by the estimates of the travelling Irish media, the team<82><84>s average age is 28.9, contrary to calculations of 29 and 245 days on the official Rugby World Cup website, which has Romania 102 days older and Tonga, the alleged leading greybeards, at 29.4. What is not disputed is that the scrum<82><80><98>half, Eoin Reddan, is 55 days short of his 35th birthday.

Whatever the numbers crunched and the actualit<83> embroidered, the discussion confirms that age is a shifting concept in the modern game. Paul O<82><84>Connell, going strong at 35, will be scratching around on the bench like some fevered colt today, according to Schmidt, so keen is the regular Ireland captain, to get his hands on the Romanians <82><80><9c> or anyone, for that matter.

One who does get his opportunity from the starting whistle in a lineup showing 12 changes from the team that walloped Canada 50-7 is Simon Zebo, an athlete who seems forever young at 25, although he is a relative novice, still, at full-back. He is a mercurial talent, no doubt, and he has mischief in his smile.

Schmidt recognised his athletic gifts and the power of his personality from the start of his tenure, but reckons he is better suited to his needs at full-back rather than on the wing, where he has been intermittently brilliant and suspect. Whether Zebo agrees with the gaffer is difficult to tell, but is happy enough to go along with the plan. This seems to be a very happy Irish team.

How did he view Schmidt<82><84>s regime and strategy? <82><93>It<82><84>s hard to say,<82><9d> Zebo says, shifting in his seat. <82><93>It<82><84>s just a different style of coach. Joe would coach totally different to Rob Penney or Anthony Foley coaching. Every coach is different. There are certain things I have to do to please one coach, and another thing to please another, so ... it<82><84>s been a relationship that I<82><84>ve had to get used to. I<82><84>m a better player for having worked under him.<82><9d>

One aspect of Zebo<82><84>s play that needed work was cleaning out at rucks, an onerous task that comes the way of backs more closely involved in the heavy lifting upfront. <82><93>He<82><84>s so detailed in every little facet of the game,<82><9d> Zebo says, <82><93>and that<82><84>s probably an area I didn<82><84>t think would have needed so much work in the past but obviously it does, especially at this standard of play. You need to not have any weaknesses if you want to be a successful international.<82><9d>

Schmidt, a smart thinker, recognises the value of Zebo<82><84>s creativity as well. <82><93>Joe gives you the licence,<82><9d> he says. <82><93>And if it<82><84>s not [working] and you do something he<82><84>ll let you know about it.<82><9d>

The odds are that Zebo will not be drastically stretched against Romania who, for all the charitable words about their effort, have not beaten Ireland in eight attempts, shipping 346 points and posting 92. Surely, then, this is an opportunity to rack up plenty more. Zebo is not thinking along those lines. <82><93>We feel like we have to go out and win the game first,<82><9d> he says. <82><93>They showed they can easily upset anybody that<82><84>s not on their game. They posed a lot of problems for France.

<82><93>France had a lot of turnovers in the first half and Romania probably could have had a few more scores in the first half.<82><9d>

If he does get a burst of inspiration in what is expected to be a walkover, it might come from a recent meeting with Usain Bolt, who spent an evening with the team at their London hotel and struck Zebo, once an aspiring track star with a 100 metres best time of 11.1sec, as a locked-on legend. Zebo<82><84>s Martinique-born father, Arthur, was a good athlete, and his sister, Jessika, has represented Ireland as a hurdler. <82><93>It was like a dream come true. We have a big athletics background in our family and to be able to sit next to the greatest athlete that<82><84>s ever lived was amazing and just to get his insights into a few things around his training and his preparation for tournaments was something very special. I even got a FaceTime session with my sister back home, just so she could see him and drool over him even more.<82><9d>

The odds are Irish fans will be doing the drooling on Sunday and, if Zebo gets an opening, he could be the player to raise the loudest cheers.

He has never been to Wembley, but his good friend David Meyler was there for Hull City when they lost in the FA Cup final to Arsenal in 2014, and scored in the 5-3 semi-final win over Sheffield United.

<82><93>He<82><84>s going to miss this game, but he<82><84>s coming to one or two later in the tournament. He didn<82><84>t win there in a final, so I<82><84>ll have to slag him about that.<82><9d>

webTitle: France beat Romania thanks to Sofiane Guitoune but have room to improve
trailText: France found it tough going against a physical Romania and needed late tries to put gloss on a 38-11 victory in the Pool D game at the Olympic Stadium
headline: France beat Romania thanks to Sofiane Guitoune but have room to improve
standfirst: NA
byline: Andy Bull at the Olympic Stadium
body:
These teams have history. This was the 50th match between them, which means France have played Romania more often than they have, for instance, Australia. For years it was an annual fixture, and a fiercely fought one. The Romanians won eight and drew two of the first 35 games, and beat each of the French sides who won the Five Nations in 1962 and 1968, as well as the Grand Slam team of 1977. After that, the French press dubbed them the <82><93>world champions of defence<82><9d>. Those days are long gone. The last Romanian victory was in 1990. France have won all 15 fixtures since, and in the last five of those the average margin was 47 points.

Given that, this 38-11 defeat was almost a good result for Romania. As for France, their supporters seemed a little underwhelmed, though given Philippe Saint-Andr<83> had made 13 changes, this certainly was not their first XV.

Related: Rugby World Cup 2015: talking points from Wednesday<82><84>s matches

Twenty minutes before kick-off, the organisers ran a video tutorial in scrummaging on the big screens in the Olympic Stadium. As if either of these teams, or their supporters, needed any lessons. Romania have always loved to scrummage, and their canny Welsh coach, Lynn Howells, has encouraged them to play to their strengths. <82><93>The problem they had,<82><9d> Howells has said, <82><93>was they thought they were New Zealand. They had to keep it simple and do those simple things very well. And it is also a case of putting together a game plan that suits Romania.<82><9d>

So a fine Romania front row, as ugly as they come, bolstered on either side by two old pros, Paulica Ion and Mihai Lazar. Behind them, the excellent scrum-half Florin Surugiu, popping box kicks over the top for his pack to chase. Saint-Andr<83> opted to counter this with the cunning ploy of pulling a blue shirt over a brick outhouse and sticking it in at tighthead: the 6ft 5in, 25st, Uini Atonio, making his first international start. On the other side, Vincent Debaty. The contest at the scrums was utterly enthralling, for those who have always wondered what happens when one immovable object meets another. Romania won a penalty at their first encounter, against the head. Morgan Parra dallied too long before picking the ball up, and Debaty buckled.

That set the tone. France took the lead, Parra kicking a penalty for an offside. But Romania<82><84>s set-piece work meant they had an early foothold in the match. They stole two French lineouts in the first quarter. The second of them almost led to a try, after Adrian Apostol hacked the loose ball deep into the French 22, then followed it up with a fine tackle on the full-back Brice Dulin. Romania won the penalty and boldly opted to kick it into the corner. From the lineout, a series of six short bursts took them right up to the try line. Surugiu threw a miss-pass right to Florin Vlaicu, who clutched the ball to his gut and tumbled over the line. The video replay showed the ball had been held up, so they had to settle for a penalty awarded for offside. They should have taken the lead soon after, with another penalty, but Vlaicu missed it from 40 yards out, straight in front.

The match turned in the 30th minute, when Ion was sent to the sin-bin for collapsing a maul after a France lineout five metres from Romania<82><84>s line. Hard as Romania were fighting, they were unable to hold on while a man down. France scored 14 points while Ion was off the field. The first as Parra popped the ball to Sofiane Guitoune on the wing. One on one with Surugiu, Guitoune slid around him, then stretched out of the tackle to put the ball down. Three minutes later, another, as Dulin burst up-field after an aimless Romanian kick. He was bought down on the edge of the 22, but France sped the ball along the line to the right wing, where Yannick Nyanga cantered over. Parra converted both, which made it 17-6 at half-time.

After the break, stalemate. France kept coming but Romania, back to strength, were able to hold them at bay. It was, to be blunt, poor stuff, the crowd fell quiet, and a fair few made an early exit. Those who stayed were treated to an enjoyably harum-scarum final quarter, sparked by Guitoune, who scored France<82><84>s third after another scrum, again reaching out to down the ball after Surugiu had hauled him down. Romania were ragged with exhaustion. Wesley Fofana got the fourth, and so earned a bonus point, a few minutes later. Ga<83>l Fickou added a fifth in the final minute. But the loudest roar of the evening was the one that came when Romania scored a try of their own, Valentin Ursache twisting through a tackle to cross in the corner.

webTitle: Romania set sights on third place with World Cup victory over Canada
trailText: Romania’s coach, Lynn Howells, has labelled their Pool D game against Canada a ‘semi-final’ with Mihaita Lazar and Valentin Poparlan set for their 50th Tests
headline: Romania set sights on third place with World Cup victory over Canada
standfirst:
• Coach Lynn Howells calls game a ‘semi-final’
• Mihaita Lazar and Valentin Poparlan set for 50th Tests
body:
Canada v Romania
Pool D Leicester City Stadium Kick-off 4.45pm

Romania, last in the pool, still hold hope of finishing third and automatically qualifying for the 2019 World Cup. To achieve that they will have to beat Canada on Tuesday, then Italy on Sunday in their pool finale. <82><93>The Canada game is a semi-final for us,<82><9d> said their Welsh coach, Lynn Howells. <82><93>It<82><84>s that important. The players have put in a lot of hard work and this is what they deserve.<82><9d> Romania have made seven changes, for the eighth time in their past nine matches, and the prop Mihaita Lazar and the lock Valentin Poparlan will play their 50th Tests. Canada will be without their captain and No8 Tyler Ardron (knee) as they complete their pool matches with a fourth game in 17 days, hoping to keep alive their run of leaving every World Cup with at least a draw. Canada have made seven changes and the squad injury-replacement James Pritchard would appear in his fourth World Cup if summoned from the bench.

Canada H Jones; J Hassler, C Hearn, N Blevins, DTH van der Merwe; N Hirayama, G McRorie; A Carpenter, J Moonlight, J Sinclair, J Cudmore (capt), B Beukeboom, D Wooldridge, R Barkwill, H Buydens. Replacements B Piffero, D Sears-Duru, J Ilnicki, K Gilmour, N Dala, P Mack, C Trainor, J Pritchard.

Romania C Fercu; M Lemnaru, P Kinikinilau, F Vlaicu, I Botezatu; M Wiringi, F Surugiu; M Macovei (capt), V Lucaci, V Ursache, J van Heerden, V Poparlan, P Ion, O Turashvili, M Lazar. Replacements A Radoi, A Ursache, A Tarus, D Carpo, S Burcea, V Calafeteanu, A Apostol, C Gal.

To achieve that they will have to beat Canada on Tuesday, then Italy on Sunday in their pool finale. The Canada game is a semi-final for us, said their Welsh coach, Lynn Howells. Its that important. The players have put in a lot of hard work and this is what they deserve. Romania have made seven changes, for the eighth time in their past nine matches, and the prop Mihaita Lazar and the lock Valentin Poparlan will play their 50th Tests. Canada will be without their captain and No8 Tyler Ardron (knee) as they complete their pool matches with a fourth game in 17 days, hoping to keep alive their run of leaving every World Cup with at least a draw. Canada have made seven changes and the squad injury-replacement James Pritchard would appear in his fourth World Cup if summoned from the bench. Canada H Jones; J Hassler, C Hearn, N Blevins, DTH van der Merwe; N Hirayama, G McRorie; A Carpenter, J Moonlight, J Sinclair, J Cudmore (capt), B Beukeboom, D Wooldridge, R Barkwill, H Buydens. Replacements B Piffero, D Sears-Duru, J Ilnicki, K Gilmour, N Dala, P Mack, C Trainor, J Pritchard. Replacements A Radoi, A Ursache, A Tarus, D Carpo, S Burcea, V Calafeteanu, A Apostol, C Gal.

webTitle: Romania: a team of ageing journeymen somehow ranked No7 in the world | Jonathan Wilson
trailText: The side captained by Vlad Chiriches top their Euro 2016 qualifying group but even their world-weary coach Anghel Iordanescu believes their ranking is a farce
headline: Romania: a team of ageing journeymen somehow ranked No7 in the world
standfirst: The side captained by Vlad Chiriches top their Euro 2016 qualifying group but even their world-weary coach Anghel Iordanescu believes their ranking is a farce
body:
On the face of it, everything looks rosy for the Romania national side. They<82><84>re ranked seventh in the world and they sit top of their qualifying group for Euro 2016, having conceded only one goal in six games. If they beat Hungary away on Friday, they<82><84>d be a win from securing their place in France next summer.

Related: Roy Hodgson tells England they can pull off Euro 2016 success

The president of the Romanian Football Federation, Razvan Burleanu, has been happy to take credit for Romania<82><84>s rise, saying that he had a plan to take Romania into the world<82><84>s top 20, then the top 15, then the top 10, and merrily asserting that his country is ahead of schedule.

But that is not the full story, not by any means. <82><93>We used to have players at the biggest teams in Europe,<82><9d> said the national team coach Anghel Iordanescu, a member of the coaching staff and a late substitute in the final when Steaua won the European Cup in 1986. <82><93>Now our teams are out of Europe earlier than they have been for 11 years and our players who are in the strong leagues are <82><80><9c> with only a few exceptions <82><80><9c> fringe players for small clubs. We are not seventh in the world.<82><9d>

Quite how Romania have climbed to seventh in the world, in fact, is something of a mystery. In the past 15 years, the only tournament they<82><84>ve qualified for was Euro 2008, where they didn<82><84>t win a game and, although it was only a play-off defeat to Greece that cost them a place at the World Cup last year, they were a distant third in their group in qualifying for Euro 2012.

Burleanu<82><84>s advisor Andrei Vochin has tried to take credit for arranging tough friendlies to <82><93>take advantage of the system<82><9d> but the 0-0 draw against Argentina last year <82><80><9c> the only game that realistically falls into that category <82><80><9c> was under Burleanu<82><84>s predecessor, Mircea Sandu. This year, Romania have played four games. They<82><84>ve drawn 0-0 away to Northern Ireland and beaten the Faroe Islands 1-0.

That, somehow, has earned them more ranking points (786.91) in 2015 than any nation in the world other than Wales (817.58), who have won in Israel and at home against Belgium. Chile, making the foolish mistake of playing more than two games and winning the Copa America, have picked up just 579.37, fewer than Slovakia, England, Albania, Portugal, Argentina, Austria and the Czech Republic.

Iordanescu has always projected a sense of world-weariness, but it<82><84>s hard to argue with his assessment. The captain Vlad Chiriches, sold by Tottenham to Napoli this summer, is probably their highest profile player, although he missed training on Wednesday with injury, and while there is healthy competition in the goalkeeping department <82><80><9c> Fiorentina<82><84>s Ciprian Tatarusanu battling it out with Sunderland<82><84>s Costel Pantilimon while Silviu Lung Jnr, the son of Romania<82><84>s 1990 World Cup goalkeeper, is a promising third choice <82><80><9c> elsewhere the cupboard is largely bare.

Lucian Sanmartean is a sumptuously gifted playmaker, one who recalls the football of a former age in his languid elegance, but he is 35 and playing in Saudi Arabia. The Ludgorets centre-forward Claudiu Keseru is 28 but has only played five internationals <82><80><9c> although they have yielded four goals. The two holding midfielders, Ovidiu Hoban and Andrei Prepelita, are 61 years old between them but have just 15 caps <82><80><9c> and play in Bulgaria and Israel.

Related: Chris Coleman on verge of history in rebuilding Wales and reputation

Other than Chiriches, the only outfielders who play for clubs in Europe<82><84>s top five leagues are Rayo Vallecano<82><84>s 34-year-old left-back Razvan Rat and Stuttgart<82><84>s attacking midfielder Alexandru Maxim. The striker Ciprian Marica has been left out by Iordanescu after making just two substitute appearances since February. Having suffered a serious knee injury, Marica has made just four starts since the end of the 2013-14 season, a sorry decline for a 29-year-old who was once seen as one of the great hopes of European football.

A possible move from Konyaspor to PAOK fell through at the last minute but, with the Romanian window open until 7 September, a return to his homeland is still possible. His last international appearance ended in a red card in the 1-0 win over Greece in September last year. Iordanescu seemed strangely irritated to be asked about him, snapping: <82><93>This is about the fate of Romanian football, not the fate of Ciprian Marica.<82><9d>

Fate recently has been rather kinder to country than to forward. The rivalry with Hungary <82><80><9c> an underlying antipathy over the sovereignty of Transylvania led to clashes between Hungarian fans and Romanian police last year and the year before <82><80><9c> should ensure a ferocious encounter in Budapest on Friday, but beyond that it<82><84>s a hugely significant game in terms of qualification. A win for Hungary would reawaken their hopes of qualifying automatically; a win for Romania and they<82><84>ll have one foot in France. But they<82><84>re still not the seventh best team in the world.

webTitle: Romania's media haunted by communism and dominated by capitalism
trailText: Study illustrates the difficulty of developing press freedom in eastern Europe
headline: Romania's media haunted by communism and dominated by capitalism
standfirst: Study illustrates the difficulty of developing press freedom in eastern Europe
body:
It has been fascinating to watch the development of the media in the post-communist regimes of eastern Europe.

In several instances, steps forward towards the foundation of press freedom have been matched by steps backward, especially, of course, in those countries ruled by Soviet-style (and Russian-sponsored) despots.

Even in countries that have sought to embrace western-style democracy, it has been evident that western-style freedom of expression has been somewhat fragile.

One of the reasons, arguably the overriding reason, is the fact that in most of central and eastern Europe, monarchic dictatorship was replaced by communist dictatorship, so democracy had never previously been allowed to blossom.

Two academics who have examined the media landscape in eastern Europe, Paolo Mancini and Jan Zielonka, argue that democratic institutions and media institutions in the region <82><93>emerged simultaneously and interdependently, in a period of rapid and often chaotic reform.<82><9d>

It means that the kind of democracy evident in the west, underpinned by the rule of law, political pluralism and freedom of speech, did not exist prior to the collapse of communism and is still in its early stages in several states.

One such country is Romania, the subject of a study by Manuela Preoteasa and Andrei Schwartz, which has been published by a new thinktank, the Centre for Media Transparency.

Their report, <82><93>The men who bit the (watch) dogs<82><9d>, comes at a time of internal chaos, with two media tycoons sent to jail, another one facing various criminal charges and the prime minister, Victor Ponta, having been indicted on charges of tax evasion, money laundering, conflict of interest and making false statements.

The study, dealing with newspapers, TV and radio, concentrates on media ownership and follows three broad stages of development: 1990-1999, and a <82><93>quasi absence of foreign investment<82><9d>; 2000-2010, years of ownership opacity, with foreign investors acting as <82><93>front operators<82><9d> for Romanian businessmen; 2011 onwards, a period of disruption with several leading owners facing criminal investigation for a variety of offences.

Even more fascinating than this developing story are the five ownership profiles. Of those, one stands out. It concerns Ronald Lauder, son of the cosmetics tycoon Est<83>e Lauder, who was briefly a defence official in the Reagan administration and US ambassador to Austria.

The authors cite a critic as saying of him: <82><93>If you talk about tabloidisation and concentration, we can call Lauder a Murdoch.<82><9d> He founded the Central Media Enterprise (CME) and, by 1997, it had TV stations in Slovenia, Romania, Slovakia and Ukraine.

In Romania, the CME<82><84>s presence was most obvious through PRO TV, the country<82><84>s most watched channel that combines entertainment and news, with the accent on the former.

CME entered the Romanian market through Adrian S<83>rbu, a media affairs minister in Romania<82><84>s first post-communist government prior to setting up his own media group.

S<83>rbu, appointed as chief executive and chairman of CME, described himself as <82><93>the only Romanian appointed as a CEO of a publicly listed American company.<82><9d>

But, in February 2014, S<83>rbu was charged with tax evasion, money laundering and embezzlement. Lauder withdrew from the board. S<83>rbu sold all of his shares in CME and withdrew from all positions. And Pro TV was acquired by Time Warner.

In February 2015, S<83>rbu was detained for 30 days after being charged with tax evasion, money laundering and embezzlement. He has since been released while awaiting trial.

This case history is not, however, unique, which is the whole point of the study. It illustrates the way in which Romania<82><84>s media has not only been haunted by its communist past but also penetrated by, and dominated by, foreign capital.

Source: Centre for Media Transparency

webTitle: Romanias explosion of righteous anger signals a fragile hope | Claudia Ciobanu
trailText: The Bucharest nightclub tragedy has unleashed public disgust at corruption and civic failure – and brought down the prime minister, Victor Ponta
headline: Romania’s explosion of righteous anger signals a fragile hope
standfirst: The Bucharest nightclub tragedy has unleashed public disgust at corruption and civic failure – and brought down the prime minister, Victor Ponta
body:
Last Friday a fire broke out during a heavy metal concert at Bucharest nightclub, Colectiv. There was only one exit from the basement club, and other safety guidelines had not been followed. It soon transpired that local authorities had granted Colectiv permits without reference to legal procedures or conducting checks. Thirty-two people died and more than 150 were injured.

Most were young fans, but one was a Roma mother of five who was working for the club without a contract. Many Romanians felt clear about what to blame <82><80><9c> widespread corruption and a malfunctioning state apparatus <82><80><9c> and took to the streets. About 25,000 people marched in Bucharest, and thousands more marched across Romania. On Thursday this week, after a night of protests, the Romanian prime minister, Victor Ponta, resigned. Unconvinced, Romanians went back to the streets, with 70,000 out all over the country

Related: Bucharest nightclub fire: PM and government resign after protests

The explosion of pain and anger since the fire is massive but not sudden. In July, Ponta was indicted for tax evasion, money laundering and conflicts of interest. Last month a policeman in the security detail of the interior minister, Gabriel Oprea, died in a road accident during a trip whose official purpose is being questioned.

Protesters called for Oprea<82><84>s resignation but he refused to step down. This week protesters renewed their calls for Oprea and Ponta to resign, adding to the list Cristian Piedone, the local mayor responsible for granting Colectiv its permit. With next year<82><84>s elections in mind, Ponta must have seen the week<82><84>s marches as a final blow (and a chance for a less humiliating exit). Piedone too stepped down.

Yet Ponta<82><84>s resignation is not the real news from Romania. What is important is how Romanians have turned sadness and frustration into solidarity and responsibility. Lines to donate blood for the wounded were so long that hospitals had to send people home. Owners of music clubs announced that they were voluntarily closing down because they too would not pass safety tests. During the demonstrations, slogans read <82><93>Not caring kills<82><9d>, <82><93>I have been quiet <82><80><9c> now I am shouting<82><9d>, and <82><93>Reset Romania<82><9d>.

On Facebook pages of the protests (and there will be more), discussions are about how to ensure firefighters conduct proper checks of buildings, or the need to increase the health budget so that in the future the ambulance system and hospitals can cope with large numbers of severely wounded. Everyone is talking about relying on the power of citizens to change the system.

Like the anger, this is not new. It<82><84>s a constructive spirit that has been carefully cultivated by activists since 2013, when public mobilisation saved the village of Ro<88><84>ia Montan<84><92> from being destroyed to make way for a goldmine. Back then, protestors said the fight for Ro<88><84>ia Montan<84><92> was <82><93>the revolution of our generation<82><9d>. A language of hope and action began to grow, replacing the generalised post-socialist cynicism.

Once Ro<88><84>ia Montan<84><92> was saved, many activists stayed connected. They fought to save forests and parks, to oppose evictions of the poor from their homes and to limit police abuses. Tens of thousands more followed these efforts via social and traditional media.

Put to shame for not having covered Ro<88><84>ia Montan<84><92>, TV channels scrambled to cover activists<82><84> stunts and messages.

In today<82><84>s Europe, public anger is often capitalised upon by right-wing populists and the far right. Across the continent, from David Cameron<82><84>s UK to Viktor Orb<83>n<82><84>s Hungary, frustration with economic precariousness is often channelled into antipathy against migrants. In Poland each 11 November <82><80><9c> the country<82><84>s national day <82><80><9c> thousands of people (many of them marginalised youths) participate in marches organised by far-right groups.

But in Romania, grassroots efforts have managed to concentrate popular dissatisfaction with failures to take responsibility for public life. It<82><84>s not unique to Romania and it<82><84>s extremely fragile. But for a fleeting second, maybe we should acknowledge the possibility of a positive collective spirit emerging from terrible tragedy.

webTitle: Ireland and Simon Zebo turn on speed to doom Romanias insurrection
trailText: Tommy Bowe and Keith Earls scored two tries each as a Simon Zebo inspired Ireland pulled away to beat Romania 44-10 after a sluggish start
headline: Ireland and Simon Zebo turn on speed to doom Romania’s insurrection
standfirst: NA
body:
This is an Irish team that can win the World Cup. Lynn Howells, Romania<82><84>s Welsh coach, certainly thinks so after watching his team succumb to the inevitable in front of a world-record crowd on an otherwise pleasant, warm Sunday afternoon.

Related: Scotland quash USA hopes of shock after Vern Cotter summons cavalry

Of course there is a long way to go <82><80><9c> a veritable marathon to follow the first-week sprint <82><80><9c> but Joe Schmidt<82><84>s side are purring nicely, as Ireland<82><84>s former touchstone Brian O<82><84>Driscoll, now a spectator in the ITV commentary booth, observed after a thoroughly sound and impressive win. <82><93>You can<82><84>t really ask for a whole lot more,<82><9d> he said, <82><93>two bonus-point victories in your first two games. It<82><84>s building nicely, under the radar.<82><9d>

So, tumult has been averted. The upstarts are still starting, occasionally startling, but not quite getting up. After minor inconveniences for Australia and Scotland earlier in the piece, following South Africa<82><84>s post-Japan rehab win, Ireland put down a doomed Romanian insurrection to restore order. It was Ireland<82><84>s ninth win from nine outings against their opponents, one as emphatic as any of the others. Ian Madigan was sound at No10, Simon Zebo reasserted his credentials at full-back, Devin Toner and Nathan White were strong in the middle of the pack, Chris Henry was immense in ball carrying and tackling and Tommy Bowe and Keith Earls threatened and struck with pleasing regularity for Schmidt, who likes a running game, especially against outgunned opponents.

However Rob Kearney, who interchanged twice with Earls, might need time to recover from a late knock. <82><93>Rob was involved in a high-speed play immediately after coming on,<82><9d> said Schmidt. <82><93>He jarred himself through his glute and hip. The next 24-48 hours will tell. We<82><84>d be hopeful at this stage he will be OK.<82><9d> Earls and Bowe were outstanding wide out as was Zebo in linking with the wings in territory he occupied with distinction himself until dropped at the end of last season. He has been excellent at full-back since.

Howells said later he had anticipated the Irish raiding along the perimeters. <82><93>For sure we knew they were going to play a wide game, it<82><84>s the way teams play against us.<82><9d> And, with a twinkle in his eye, he gives Ireland a realistic chance of lifting the cup: <82><93>It<82><84>s a possibility. I really do [think so]. I don<82><84>t see any reason why not <82><80><9c> especially after seeing Wales beat England <82><80><9c> which was most gratifying. I enjoyed that very much. I think Ireland have a more complete game than France.<82><9d> The only joy for his team, perhaps, was the marriage proposal made on-pitch by the appropriately named scrum-half Valentin Calafeteanu. (Apparently she accepted).

But this was Ireland<82><84>s day, their Yellow Submarine scenario: sky of blue, sea of green. What could possibly disturb the serenity? Along Wembley Way, a kilt-wearing Irishman played the bag-pipe for what his cardboard signed reckoned was a fund for his engagement ring. As the nostalgic, match-day odour of burning onion rings and sausages wafted through the smiling throng, there was no sense at all of the sanctioned mugging to come.

On the pitch, the acreage looked way too expansive for Romania to patrol and the attritional fire storm of the opening attacks turned into a growing rout. The first fruitful breaching of the defence arrived after 17 minutes. Earls pulled down a beautifully weighted Eoin Reddan chip, found Chris Henry and Jamie Heaslip inside, and watched the three-quarter line sweep the ball across to the other side. The move reached its deserved climax as Bowe made the final salmon-leap, avoiding the corner flag by the width of his arm hairs.

Related: Drew Mitchell breaks Australia tries record in trouncing of Uruguay

Inside the half-hour Earls gathered a 25-yard cut-out pass from Zebo and dived over unencumbered. Romania probably appreciated the odd cessation of hostilities near the scheduled break, when Cian Healy had to grope around for a contact lens briefly dislodged.

Ireland went in 15 points clear. Romania, trailed puppy-like behind them, many of their players already approaching the exhaustion cut-off point, and accepted their respite gladly. Their back row had made as many tackles as the entire Irish team.

The punishment resumed quickly, Earls scooping up a delightful grubber kick by Reddan, for a short-range score. After 47 minutes Romania made just their third incursion into enemy territory with ball in hand. It was repulsed.

There was a divergent cheer from the crowd <82><80><9c> for themselves; all 89,267 of them, announced as constituting a Rugby World Cup record <82><80><9c> for Ireland against Romania, of all fixtures. That<82><84>s some statement about the growth of the game. If only the fight was more even.

What followed was a snapshot of days gone by. As the fans entertained themselves with the harmless inanity of a few Mexican waves <82><80><9c> always a sign of boredom with the fare on offer <82><80><9c> the pounding continued unabated.

Florin Ionita hit Bowe in mid-air on the hour but he escaped the sin-bin or worse because the referee, Craig Joubert, took the soft option, claiming he could not see if either of his feet were on the ground. The South African official had no hesitation yellow-carding Csaba Gal for his illegal interference on the ground under his posts and, from the resultant move, Bowe stretched the lead <82><80><9c> and grabbed the bonus point.

Kearney got another, set up by Zebo, whose boots flew with the speed he once showed as a schoolboy sprinter. A mighty shove on the Romanian line saw Henry emerge from the melee a smiling try-scorer and, as some customers headed for an early scrum of their own on public transport, there was a growing perception that we<82><84>d probably seen enough. These were the final few punches of a fight that did no more than inflict bruises to the losers<82><84> sense of self-worth.

And then, as so often happens in sport, a twist: Ovidiu Tonita clawed back some family pride with a stretched-out arm that plonked the ball just over the Irish line. It was the least Romania deserved. The conversion by Vlaicu sprinkled a little icing on their otherwise mouldy cake.

Tries Bowe 2, Earls 2, R Kearney, Henry Cons Madigan 4 Pens Madigan 2

Romania Fercu; Apostol (Ionita, 54), Kinikinilau, Gal, Botezatu; Wiringi (Vlaicu, 68), Calafeteanu (Surugiu, 68); Ursache (Lazar, 68), Radoi (Turashvili, 56), Ion, Popirlan, Tonita, Lucaci (Van Heerden, 60) Macovei (Burcea, 68), Carpo.

You cant really ask for a whole lot more, he said, two bonus-point victories in your first two games. Its building nicely, under the radar. So, tumult has been averted. webTitle: Bulgaria, Romania and the new wave of wine
trailText: Winemaking in the Soviet satellites fell from grace in the late 1990s, but there has been a resurgence led by an exotic cast of aristocrats and Brits, says David Williams
headline: Bulgaria, Romania and the new wave of wine
standfirst: Winemaking in the Soviet satellites fell from grace in the late 1990s, but there has been a resurgence led by an exotic cast of aristocrats and Brits
body:
Like other distinctly 1980s food and drink brands <82><80><9c> Ice Magic, Cabana chocolate bars, Hofmeister lager <82><80><9c> I<82><84>d assumed that the once all-conquering Sainsbury<82><84>s own-label Bulgarian cabernet sauvignon had died a quiet death at some point in the past 10 years. What had been, at the height of its 1980s popularity, the single biggest-selling wine in the UK, was now, I thought, no more than a piece of nostalgia

After all, the fall from grace of the wine industries in both Bulgaria and its fellow late Soviet-era export success, Romania, had been as sad as it was spectacular and, in retrospect, inevitable. As late as the mid-1990s, the Bulgarians were selling more than 50m bottles of wine a year in the UK, with the Romanians, with their budget pinot noirs, not far behind. By the time I made my first trip as a wine journalist to Bulgaria in the early-2000s, however, both were selling less than a tenth of that. The reasons why were evident throughout that trip. During the day, I was shown a procession of near-derelict vineyards and unkempt, eerily quiet winemaking facilities (it was hard to call these grimly utilitarian buildings <82><93>wineries<82><9d>). In the evening, two doleful Bulgarian wine exporters detailed the difficulties facing winemakers both before and after the end of Communism: corruption; the haphazard redistribution of vineyard land to private owners with no wine-making experience; an absence of properly trained local winemakers; a general absence of money.

The mood was bleak; I have yet to go on a more downbeat wine trip. But there were already the beginnings of a recovery thanks to entrepreneurial winemakers who were aware that parts of Bulgaria and Romania had the climate and soils to make high quality wine and at considerably lower cost than elsewhere in Europe. They were also conscious that both countries were likely to join the EU, saw an opportunity and began to embark on the complicated process of buying up vineyard land. The investors were an exotic cast that included Italian textile magnate Edoardo Miroglio (whose eponymous set-up in Bulgaria<82><84>s Thracian Valley joins Piedmont<82><84>s Tenuta Carretta in his family<82><84>s wine portfolio), a German-born, Bordeaux-based aristocrat, Count Stephan von Neipperg (owner of top St-Emilion Ch<83>teau Canon La Gaffeli<83>re among others, and partner in the Enira project in Bulgaria<82><84>s Bessa Valley), and the British couple Philip and Elvira Cox (who own and run the large Romanian Cramele Recas winery). Their projects and wines may be very different in scale and ambition but collectively, their investment and experience seems to have flicked a switch in both countries.

In the decade since there<82><84>s been a flood of imaginative new ventures, the sort of individualistic, small-scale producers that would never have been possible in the Soviet era. I<82><84>m thinking of returning exiles such as Romanian royal Baroness Ileana Kripp-Costinescu, who, with her German husband, Baron Jacob Kripp (a couple straight out of The Grand Budapest Hotel), has revived her family<82><84>s 300-year-old Prince Stirbey estate in the Transylvanian Alps. Then there are maverick small-producers such as Ogi Tcvetanov and Adrianna Serebrinova, who have transformed a former state-run Bulgarian operation into a small-scale delight at Borovitza, or the New Zealand and Austrian-trained Petar Georgiev, the talented winemaker at creative new Bulgarian producer, Ross-Idi.

Not everything these producers or their peers make is outstanding, far from it. And with the possible exception of Cramele Recas (and its fellow British-affiliated producer, Halewood Romania) I don<82><84>t expect any of them to approach the sales of the 1980s. But retailers are much more willing to list wines from this part of the world than they have been in years <82><80><9c> and that in itself is a step forward after the dark days of the 1990s and 2000s. And the more new-wave Bulgarian and Romanian producers I taste the more I<82><84>m convinced these countries are going to be serious players in years to come. That, you could say, is the future. If you want a taste of the past, Sainsbury<82><84>s, while not exactly enthusiastic about it, assures me <82>4.75 will still buy you a bottle of so-so Bulgarian Cabernet in 488 of its stores.

Six of the best eastern European wines

Edoardo Miroglio Soli Pinot Noir, Nova Zagora 2011 (from <82>9.95, Swig.co.uk, The Wine Society; Roberson Wine)
Made at an Italian-owned winery by an Italian winemaker who used to work with top barolo producer Luca Sandrone, this is exceptionally good value pinot noir: succulently red fruited, silky soft, sweetly earthy and graceful.

Sant<82><84>Ilia Cabernet Sauvignon/Cabernet Franc/Melnik, Elenovo, Thracian Lowlands, Bulgaria 2012 (<82>8.99, Waitrose)
Bulgaria made its name with its great value take on Bordeaux-style reds. a little of the local melnik along with the two cabernets, this appealingly fresh, crunchy blend, with its blackcurrant and mint leaf, proves it still has the knack.

Cramele Recas Frunza Pinot Noir, Banat, Romania 2013 (<82>7, Oddbins)
Like the Bulgarians with cabernet, the Romanians have been doing budget pinots for years, and these days Cramele Recas are behind many of the most appetising examples. They may not be Burgundy-complex, but this is a vibrant juicy, rhubarb-and-strawberry lighter red for salmon.

Prince Stirbey Tamaioasa Romaneasca Sec 2013 (<82>9.95, The Wine Society)
Tamaioasa romaneasca is, according to the Wine Society, a Romanian relative of muscat, and there is a sense of that variety<82><84>s floral grapey charm in this dry white, which, combined with a fluent, spring stream freshness, makes for an irresistibly airy, refreshing spring-into-summer white.

Borovitza Bella Rada, Bulgaria 2011 (<82>13.95, Berry Bros and Rudd)
Rikatskeli has begun to get a following in the UK through the amphora-aged wines of Georgia, where the white grape variety originates. This dry Bulgarian take is just as interesting: full of pithy lemon and grapefruit but topped with a subtly honeyed character.

Bessa Valley Enira Estate Red, Bulgaria 2009 (<82>11.99, Ocado)
From St-Emilion star Stephan von Neipperg<82><84>s impressive Bulgarian project, a merlot-led Bordeaux-style red that balances creamy vanilla oak and ripe plum and blackcurrant fruit. Look out, too, for Enira<82><84>s reserve bottlings, such as the very serious BV 2009 (<82>37.50, hedonism.co.uk)

<82> This article was amended on 19 March 2015 to correct the spelling of Stephan von Neipperg<82><84>s name.

webTitle: Romanias reduced circumstances mask proud history allied with France
trailText: Michael Wiringi is one of four overseas-born players in Romania’s World Cup squad and he and his fellow newcomers join a nation with a proud history that makes recent decline more poignant
headline: Romania’s reduced circumstances mask proud history allied with France
standfirst: Michael Wiringi is one of four overseas-born players in Romania’s Rugby World Cup squad and he joins a nation with a proud history that makes the recent decline more poignant
body:
Among the 31 men in Romania<82><84>s squad is Michael Wiringi, a 30-year-old born and raised in Hawera, on the west coast of New Zealand<82><84>s north island. <82><93>A small-town boy that<82><84>s been given a huge opportunity<82><9d>, as he says himself.

In 2011, Wiringi answered an advert in his local paper placed by the semi-pro club Baia Mare, based 400 miles north of Bucharest. They were calling for overseas recruits. He got an email back inviting him over on the next flight out. Wiringi, who has qualified for the Romania team through residency, wanted to learn a little bit about the country before he travelled, so he started looking online.

Wiringi would have found plenty of reading material. Romania, who have played in every World Cup but never made it to the quarter-finals, have a long, proud history in the game. Not least in their rivalry with France, whom they play in the first World Cup match at the Olympic Stadium on Wednesday night. The two countries have played each other 51 times. Newcomers such as Wiringi might be surprised to find that the Romanians used to hold their own. Between 1960 and 1980 they won six and drew two of the 22 Tests the teams played.

Related: Rugby World Cup 2015 preview No20: Romania

It was students, studying in Paris, who first brought the game to Bucharest at the start of the 20th century, and Romania<82><84>s first proper Test was against France in 1924. The French, blackballed from the International Rugby Board until 1978, cultivated a partnership with the Romanians instead. They sent coaches to work in the domestic league and arranged annual fixtures. The bond grew stronger because the IRB kept both countries at arm<82><84>s length for so long. Romania<82><84>s application for membership was rejected in 1953, and in 1966 the board stopped Australia from accepting an invitation to play in Bucharest.

The IRB ban was lifted in 1970, but even then there was a proviso that matches against Romania would not have full cap status. By then Romania were one of the strongest teams in Europe, the players well-supported by the communist government which gave many of them jobs with the army and police force. The French team that won the grand slam in 1977 lost to Romania in Bucharest at the start of that very season. These were the glory years. They beat France again in 1982, then Wales in 1983 and Scotland in 1984.

It was then, too, that things started to fall apart. The Romanian economy slumped, funding was cut. Then the revolution came in 1989. Five of the national team<82><84>s players died in the fighting, among them the captain Florica Murariu, who had led the team in a six-point win over Wales in Cardiff the previous year. Domestic clubs lacked the money to buy basic kit such as jerseys and balls, and participation numbers dropped from a peak of 8,000 to fewer than 3,000.

Romania last beat France in 1990. They have been struggling ever since. Since the game turned professional they have never been within 30 points of a repeat. For this match the French have felt able to make 13 changes to their team. The Romanians are fielding one of their most experienced teams, with 684 caps between the XV, and two players, Paulica Ion and Danut Dumbrava, appearing in a fourth World Cup. Despite that, their squad looks a little different. In 2011 every single player was born and bred in Romania. But now Wiringi is one of four overseas-born players brought into the team in this past year. <82><93>I guess they didn<82><84>t find a young guy,<82><9d> he said, <82><93>and ended up taking me.<82><9d>

For all the excitement about the growth of rugby in Japan and elsewhere, it always feels a little poignant that the sport was allowed to decline in another country where it was once so well established.

webTitle: Closer To The Moon: this Romanian tragicomedy is a waste of a great story
trailText: A stellar cast, fascinating historical setting and novel structure can’t prevent this Soviet-era misfire from succumbing to cliche and a distracting sense of cheapness
headline: Closer To The Moon: this Romanian tragicomedy is a waste of a great story
standfirst: A stellar cast, fascinating historical setting and novel structure can’t prevent this Soviet-era misfire from succumbing to cliche and a distracting sense of cheapness
body:
Well, so much for elevated expectations. I liked the look of Closer To The Moon when I read about its background. It recounts the story of a real Soviet-era Romanian propaganda movie from 1959, which was interesting in that it was a bank-truck hold-up movie, based on real recent events and starring the very people who had held up the truck. Indeed, it was filmed after the robbers had already been sentenced to death.

All the robbers were Jewish, members of a wartime partisan group that had fought alongside the Red Army against the Nazi occupation of Romania. As successful partisans, they were rewarded under the post-1947 Soviet takeover with positions among the country<82><84>s political elite, but by the late 1950s, resurgent Romanian and Soviet antisemitism had rendered their position precarious. The propaganda movie was a meticulous reconstruction of the event, and was intended as part of a growing antisemitic campaign orchestrated by the government of Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej.

Sounds promising, right? Fascinating era, echoes of Costa-Gavras<82><84>s The Confession or P<83>l G<83>bor<82><84>s almost forgotten 1978 drama Angi Vera <82><80><9c> two great movies about apparatchiks under pressure in postwar Czechoslovakia and Hungary, respectively. And the film-within-the-film gambit recalled Dusan Makavejev<82><84>s Innocence Unprotected (1968), which is half original footage and half extracts from the first Yugoslavian movie ever made.

Well, we live in hope until we<82><84>re proved too clever by half. What I got instead was an exceedingly lightweight, tonally incoherent, seemingly endless little tragicomedy, filmed in Romania, with an entirely unintegrated cast giving every impression of having been flown in for the week. That impressive lineup <82><80><9c> including Mark Strong, Vera Farmiga, Christian McKay and the always excellent Anton Lesser <82><80><9c> seems to have consumed most of the film<82><84>s budget because, despite being filmed in Romania on some tax-break scheme, it gives no sense of the country that couldn<82><84>t have been reconstructed on the sound stages of Billancourt or Babelsberg.

Told in flashback during the filming of the movie, Closer To The Moon offers almost no sense of period or of Soviet-era grimness <82><80><9c> you just have to take the narrator<82><84>s word for it. Anachronisms abound <82><80><9c> <82><93>partying like animals<82><9d>? <82><93>awesome<82><9d>? <82><80><9c> outnumbered only by evil-empire cliches: the Securitate hacks are all rail-thin, the party bosses all have big, leonine Brezhnev-Milo<85>evi<84><80> hair-dos. As fluffed scenes piled up on top of botched opportunities, I briefly succumbed to the illusion I was watching it on an aeroplane <82><80><9c> the place it deserves to be watched <82><80><9c> while trapped in a bad movie inside an even worse movie.

webTitle: Prince Nicholas, Romanian royal with the common touch, cut from succession
trailText: Rumours of intrigue circulate after King Michael removes popular grandson from line to the throne, saying nation needs someone ‘dignified and moral’
headline: Prince Nicholas, Romanian royal with the common touch, cut from succession
standfirst: Rumours of intrigue circulate after King Michael removes popular grandson from line to the throne, saying nation needs someone ‘dignified and moral’
body:
Prince Nicholas of Romania had seemed an ideal heir to a monarchy fighting to carve out a niche in a modern republic. Charming and handsome, he is a committed environmentalist, enthusiastic sportsman and keen supporter of children<82><84>s charities. He had even moved out of the palace because he was fed up that pizza firms wouldn<82><84>t deliver to him there.

But this week, 94-year-old King Michael suggested that his 30-year-old grandson was not up to royal standards, formally cutting him out of the line of succession.

<82><93>[The King thinks] Romania will need a head of the family who is dignified, moral, thinks of others and is hardworking, respecting the principles of the family,<82><9d> said the royal family<82><84>s spokesman, Ioan Luca Vlad.

<82><93>At this point in time he believes that it is best if Nicholas continues to follow his own dreams outside of Romania, outside the line of succession and outside of the royal family.<82><9d>

The decision set off speculation in Romania and beyond about what had gone wrong. Swiss-born, British-raised Nicholas had only formally been named third-in-line to the throne five years earlier, when he moved to Romania to take up the unofficial role.

The King had already cut one daughter, Irina, out of the line of succession after she pleaded guilty to helping run a cockfighting business in Oregon with her husband last year.

Vlad said this case was different because Nicholas was not being punished for any misdeeds. <82><93>It is a preventive move, that stops this distinction between what he [Nicholas] wants and what the royal family is, from blowing up into something that would be irreparable,<82><9d> Vlad said. <82><93>It was a decision taken in harmony.<82><9d>

Some Romanians speculated that a jealous relative had sought to edge Nicholas out of the succession, the Associated Press reported, but the change in the line of succession <82><80><9c> which could be reversed by King Michael<82><84>s heir <82><80><9c> seems only to have made him more popular.

He has 23,000 likes on his Facebook page, topped by a photo of him with a mountain bike in beautiful mountain scenery, apparently on a 1,000km fundraising trip he made in April from Transylvania to the Black Sea port of Constanta.

On Tuesday, Nicholas <82><80><9c> who will now be known simply as Nicholas Medford-Mills, his father<82><84>s last name <82><80><9c> said he supported his grandfather<82><84>s decision and welcomed the chance to fade back into a life of anonymity. <82><93>I find the lifestyle and rigours of being a prince of Romania too heavy for me so I will continue to pursue my activities outside of Romania,<82><9d> the statement said.

Perhaps in a prelude to his departure from royal life, Nicholas had earlier this year moved out of the Elisabeta palace, which was also home to his grandfather, his aunt <82><80><9c> Crown Princess Margaret <82><80><9c> and her husband, Radu Duda. He took an apartment in a district 15 minutes drive away, near a park where he could walk his Jack Russell terrier.

Although the family have no official position in modern Romania, they have taken on some roles similar to royals in other European countries, working with charities, representing the country informally and sometimes dabbling in politics.

His grandfather first took the throne more than 80 years ago as a child, and played a key role in overthrowing Romania<82><84>s fascist dictator Ion Antonescu in 1944, but abdicated and left the country three years later. He said the communist government blackmailed him to step down, threatening to kill more than 1,000 imprisoned students if he did not leave.

He would not return for over 40 years, when his popularity alarmed the government and he was effectively barred again. But in the 1990s he won back his citizenship and in 2001 the government granted him the same rights as all other former heads of state <82><80><9c> including an official residence with staff and security, a car and chauffeur and a living allowance.

On his 90th birthday, the king made his first speech to parliament in over six decades, calling for cleaner politics and a shifting of the guard. <82><93>The time has come ... to finally break with the bad habits of the past,<82><9d> Michael said, adding there should be an end to <82><93>demagogy, selfishness and attempts to cling to power<82><9d>.
