webTitle: Bucharest city guide: what to see plus the best bars, hotels and restaurants
trailText: Though much of Romania’s capital was bulldozed by the communists, the old town survived and is abuzz with bars, cafes and restaurants
headline: Bucharest city guide: what to see plus the best bars, hotels and restaurants
standfirst: Though much of Romania’s capital was bulldozed by the communists, the old town survived and is abuzz with bars, cafes and restaurants
body:
It<82><84>s fair to say that Bucharest is unlikely to win any awards for beauty or style, yet the Romanian capital surprises many first-time visitors with its cosmopolitan vibe and energy.

During the period between the wars, Bucharest<82><84>s epithet as the <82><93>Paris of the east<82><9d> was accurate, up to a point. However, today<82><84>s cityscape is largely one of imposing socialist architecture, the result of former dictator Nicolae Ceau<85>escu<82><84>s savage redevelopment project during the 1980s <82><80><9c> the bleakest of communist years for Romanians.

Things are much brighter these days, however, and lurking among this tangle of concrete are some wonderful art nouveau buildings (many housing terrific museums), ancient churches and monasteries, lush parkland, lakes and elegant boulevards. Bucharest<82><84>s culinary scene is at last worth getting excited about, while the city has few peers anywhere in the Balkans when it comes to nightlife.

Above all, though, the old town <82><80><9c> also called Lipscani after the main street that crosses the area <82><80><9c> has become the city<82><84>s go-to party place and, on any given night, you<82><84>ll find the bars full to bursting.

With the ferocious summer heat just a hazy memory, late autumn is the perfect time to explore this compelling city<82><84>s unexpected delights.

What to do and see

Bucharest<82><84>s old town was mercifully untouched by second world war bombs and Ceau<85>escu<82><84>s bulldozers and is the city<82><84>s most charismatic neighbourhood. Although much of the area remains agreeably tatty, a massive regeneration project has transformed many of its hitherto grubby-looking streets and buildings, the most spectacular example being the new C<84><92>rture<85>ti Carusel bookshop (carturesticarusel.ro) on strada Lipscani. The pint-sized Stavropoleos Church, with ornate carvings in stone and wood both inside and out, is another architectural must-see.

Whether you consider it a thing of beauty or (more likely) brute ugly, the Palace of Parliament (aka the People<82><84>s House, cdep.ro) is indisputably jaw-dropping. Constructed at Ceau<85>escu<82><84>s behest, its scale and opulence are head-spinning: 12 storeys (including four underground levels, one a nuclear bunker), 1,100 rooms, 4,500 chandeliers, and so on <82><80><9c> although apparently not even 700 architects could satisfy Ceau<85>escu<82><84>s, or rather his wife<82><84>s, ever-changing whims. Guided tours (<82>5) take in a dozen or so of the largest and most extravagant rooms and conclude on the balconied terrace, affording fabulous views down bulevardul Unirii.

For more Ceau<85>escu-linked culture, head to the piata Revolutiei and check out the pockmarked buildings. The square was the focal point of fighting during the 1989 revolution, which led to the end of the dictator<82><84>s regime.

The National Village Museum (adults <82>2, seniors <82>1, children 50p, muzeul-satului.ro) is on the shores of lake Her<84><92>str<84><92>u and exhibits vernacular architecture from all over Romania. Comprising some 300 dwellings <82><80><9c> churches, workshops, windmills and so on <82><80><9c> there<82><84>s much ground to cover, so keep a keen eye out for the ingenious dug-out (or <82><93>pit<82><9d>) homes from Oltenia and the iconic wooden churches from Maramure<85> in northern Romania.

Take a stroll around Ci<85>migiu Gardens, the oldest and largest park in central Bucharest. It<82><84>s a welcome dollop of green space in the city and there<82><84>s a boating lake for would-be rowers.

For a break from the noise of downtown, make your way to the enchanting Mogo<85>oaia Palace (entry <82>1, palatebrancovenesti.ro), which is about 10km north-west of the centre. Designed by the 17th-century ruler of the Wallachia region, Constantin Br<83>ncoveanu (who occasionally resided here), it<82><84>s a red-brick structure typical of the region, and the interior retains some lovely detail, not least dazzling Venetian mosaic flooring and carved wooden doors. After, it<82><84>s worth taking a walk around the grounds and woods.

Where to eat

Fine dining remains something of a novelty concept in Bucharest, but elegantly understated The Artist (13 strada Nicolae Tonitza, +40 728 318871, theartist.ro), discreetly tucked away on one of the old town<82><84>s quieter streets, is leading the way. The restaurant<82><84>s young Dutch chef creates inventive dishes such as roasted quail and crab with apricot and white chocolate (<82>12), and elderflower parfait with black cherries and prosecco (<82>5); and if choosing between the dishes proves impossible, have a cheeky bash at the spoon-tasting menu (<82>12), for a little taste of everything.

Home-style cooking doesn<82><84>t come much better than at Beca<82><84>s Kitchen (80 strada Mihai Eminescu, +40 744 344 700, becaskitchen.ro), a little family-run restaurant on an unassuming residential street, a short walk north of the city centre. Dishes <82><80><9c> around half a dozen starters and a similar number of mains <82><80><9c> are chalked up on a blackboard, which Beca herself will bring to the table and delight in explaining. There<82><84>s nothing particularly fussy or complicated about the food <82><80><9c> for example, baked seabass with roasted veg and beetroot (<82>10), or rhubarb tart with vanilla sauce (<82>3) <82><80><9c> it<82><84>s the simplicity, much like the place itself, that makes it a winner.

The location isn<82><84>t the most exciting but that shouldn<82><84>t dissuade anyone from venturing to Pukka Tukka (13 pia<85>a Amzei 13, +40 733 145034, pukkafood.ro), a super organic food bar. Try a cooked <82><93>Pukka Tukka<82><9d> breakfast (<82>6), or a lunch of salmon with baby spinach (<82>8). All the drinks, including coffee, fresh apple juice and a selection of local wines, are 100% organic, too. The wicker-walled interior features barely half a dozen small tables, each with stools made from cork, but there is a pleasantly shaded patio for alfresco eating.

Caru<82><84> cu Bere (5 strada Stavropoleos, +40 213 137560, carucubere.ro), literally <82><93>beer cart<82><9d>, is the first restaurant many tourists make a beeline for but it<82><84>s also where the locals go, which says much about its authenticity. Chic waiting staff scuttle around the ornate restaurant, doling out Romanian standards such as mittitei (grilled spiced sausages, <82>3) and tochitur<84><92> (pork stew, <82>7), while the house musicians belt out Romanian folk tunes. Great fun.

Where to drink

Old town caf<83>s are ten-a-penny, but bright and buzzy Cremeria Emilia (38 strada Francez<84><92>, facebook.com/cremeriaemilia) knocks spots off all of them. The all-white interior looks fab but, on a sunny day, sitting at one of its pavement tables is the thing to do. The menu lists an irresistible selection of ice-creams, and enticing bowls of semifreddo and panna cotta, all of which are freshly made on the premises. The coffee<82><84>s not bad, either.

Romanian wine remains something of a mystery to outsiders, so Abel<82><84>s Wine Bar (10 strada Nicolae Tonitza, abelswinebar.ro) <82><80><9c> one of several to have emerged recently <82><80><9c> is just the spot to begin your education by sampling the many varieties of wine, most of which are available by the glass.

Of all the old town bars in which to while away the night, Bordello (9 strada <85>elari, bordellos.ro) stands out. Packed most nights, it<82><84>s a bit of an all-rounder, variously staging live music, cabaret, burlesque and quiz nights. Most people, though, are happy just to tuck into a plate of tapas (from <82>2) and a good old-fashioned pint (from <82>3).

Lots of coffee houses have opened recently but Origo (9 strada Lipscani, origocoffee.ro) is the one to aim for. It<82><84>s a small, easy-going joint run by an enthusiastic team of baristas who really know their beans; be it a cappuccino, ristretto or lungo, the quality is consistently high and the service impeccable. At dusk, the venue morphs into a brilliant cocktail-cum-wine bar.

Where to stay

Dating from 1914, the Athenee Palace Hilton (doubles from <82>250, hiltonbucharest.com) was formerly a hotbed of conspiracy and espionage <82><80><9c> in short, the sort of place you<82><84>d expect James Bond to stay. It<82><84>s infinitely more refined these days, though no less glamorous, with its magnificent marble lobby and luxury rooms. Facilities include a gym, spa and basement pool and the hotel<82><84>s English Bar is one of the most sophisticated <82><80><9c> and expensive <82><80><9c> rendezvous points in the city.

Tucked away on a sleepy residential street, Hotel Christina (doubles from <82>79, hotelchristina.ro) looks rather anonymous but it<82><84>s genuinely something a little bit special. The solar-panelled roof gives you some idea of the hotel<82><84>s orientation: its eco-driven ethos extends to its rooms, which come in four fetching colour schemes: pink, yellow, lilac and grape-green. There are ergonomically designed beds and LED strip lighting, and forget paper <82><80><9c> menus are presented on iPads. Oh, and it<82><84>s got free bike hire.

Bucharest is short on decent guesthouses, but the charming Flowers B&B (doubles <82>35, flowersbb.ro) is an exception. It<82><84>s in a tranquil spot, 20 minute<82><84>s walk from the city centre, and its 22 rooms are painted in warm, peachy tones. In warmer weather, breakfast is served on its shady terrace.

At the lower end of the scale, arty Umbrella Hostel (dorm beds from <82>10, umbrella hostel.com), occupying a beautiful early 20th-century house, offers a mix of four- and eight-bed rooms, alongside a couple of doubles, all with handcrafted wooden beds, individual lockers and reading lights; shower facilities are shared. Although breakfast isn<82><84>t provided, there<82><84>s a large kitchen for guests to use, and the shady courtyard is a lovely spot to kick back with a beer.

The menu lists an irresistible selection of ice-creams, and enticing bowls of semifreddo and panna cotta, all of which are freshly made on the premises. The coffees not bad, either. Romanian wine remains something of a mystery to outsiders, so Abels Wine Bar (10 strada Nicolae Tonitza, abelswinebar.ro)  one of several to have emerged recently  is just the spot to begin your education by sampling the many varieties of wine, most of which are available by the glass. Of all the old town bars in which to while away the night, Bordello (9 strada elari, bordellos.ro) stands out. Packed most nights, its a bit of an all-rounder, variously staging live music, cabaret, burlesque and quiz nights. Most people, though, are happy just to tuck into a plate of tapas (from 2) and a good old-fashioned pint (from 3). Lots of coffee houses have opened recently but Origo (9 strada Lipscani, origocoffee.ro) is the one to aim for. Its a small, easy-going joint run by an enthusiastic team of baristas who really know their beans; be it a cappuccino, ristretto or lungo, the quality is consistently high and the service impeccable. At dusk, the venue morphs into a brilliant cocktail-cum-wine bar. Dating from 1914, the Athenee Palace Hilton (doubles from 250, hiltonbucharest.com) was formerly a hotbed of conspiracy and espionage  in short, the sort of place youd expect James Bond to stay. Its infinitely more refined these days, though no less glamorous, with its magnificent marble lobby and luxury rooms. Facilities include a gym, spa and basement pool and the hotels English Bar is one of the most sophisticated  and expensive  rendezvous points in the city. Tucked away on a sleepy residential street, Hotel Christina (doubles from 79, hotelchristina.ro) looks rather anonymous but its genuinely something a little bit special. The solar-panelled roof gives you some idea of the hotels orientation: its eco-driven ethos extends to its rooms, which come in four fetching colour schemes: pink, yellow, lilac and grape-green. There are ergonomically designed beds and LED strip lighting, and forget paper  menus are presented on iPads. Oh, and its got free bike hire. Bucharest is short on decent guesthouses, but the charming Flowers B&B (doubles 35, flowersbb.ro) is an exception. Its in a tranquil spot, 20 minutes walk from the city centre, and its 22 rooms are painted in warm, peachy tones. In warmer weather, breakfast is served on its shady terrace. At the lower end of the scale, arty Umbrella Hostel (dorm beds from 10, umbrella hostel.com), occupying a beautiful early 20th-century house, offers a mix of four- and eight-bed rooms, alongside a couple of doubles, all with handcrafted wooden beds, individual lockers and reading lights; shower facilities are shared. Although breakfast isnt provided, theres a large kitchen for guests to use, and the shady courtyard is a lovely spot to kick back with a beer.

webTitle: Victor Ponta says he would face court as Romanian MPs uphold immunity
trailText: Prime minister says he has proof he is innocent of charges of money laundering and tax evasion while president calls for his resignation
headline: Victor Ponta says he would face court as Romanian MPs uphold immunity
standfirst: Prime minister says he has proof he is innocent of charges of money laundering and tax evasion while president calls for his resignation
body:
Victor Ponta, Romania<82><84>s prime minister, said on Tuesday that he was prepared to go to court to answer allegations of money-laundering, forgery and tax evasion as the country<82><84>s president called on him resign.

Prosecutors announced on Friday that they had launched an investigation into the prime minister over suspected money laundering and tax evasion, sending one of the EU<82><84>s poorest countries into a political crisis.

Ponta denies the allegations and says he has documentary proof of his innocence. In an interview with the Guardian, he rejected a renewed demand by Klaus Iohannis, Romania<82><84>s president, for him to resign, saying that neither Romania nor Europe could afford political instability in the face of Russian expansionist moves to the East.

<82><93>Romania is in the most sensitive area of Europe,<82><9d> Ponta said. <82><93>We hope we will close this small but intense political crisis and we will get back to work, because Europe requires Romania to be stable and predictable in this region. I think only Russia will open the champagne bottles if Romania will be in long political crisis.<82><9d>

Ponta was speaking in his office minutes after the country<82><84>s senate voted by a large majority against lifting his immunity to criminal investigation, drawing a stinging rebuke from the president and the prospect of a constitutional stand-off.

<82><93>I regret that has parliament has turned into a shield for the protection of an individual, Victor Ponta, who is suspected of criminal acts,<82><9d> Iohannis said in a written statement. <82><93>It is conclusive proof of huge irresponsibility and defiance towards the public, because the majority MPs are obstructing justice and will destroy the parliament as an institution, harming the image of Romania, in order to save one person.<82><9d>

The president added: <82><93>I furthermore consider the key to getting out of this situation is the resignation of Mr Victor Ponta as prime minister.<82><9d>

Ponta, the leader of the majority Social Democratic party, rejected the president<82><84>s demand for his resignation as politically motivated, intended to rally support for the Liberals in elections due next year.

<82><93>I<82><84>m sure that president Iohannis will simply do his job and his statements were simply statements to support his party who are in opposition and who want to win elections next year,<82><9d> Ponta said. <82><93>But the president should be the president of all citizens not just of his party.<82><9d>

The parliamentary vote to maintain the prime minister<82><84>s immunity only protects Ponta against some of the potential charges raised on Friday by the National Anticorruption Directorate (DNA) <82><80><9c> specifically those alleging conflict of interest while he has been in office. It does not apply to DNA allegations that Ponta was involved in money-laundering, forgery and tax evasion in 2007 and 2008 when he was working as a private lawyer. According to a statement issued on Friday by the agency, he is said to have falsified invoices for work he never performed to help a business associate dodge tax.

<82><93>I am still being investigated ... and I will answer to all the prosecutor<82><84>s questions regarding the allegation that eight years ago as a lawyer I was accomplice to another lawyer for a <80><9a>10,000 tax evasion. I will go in front of the prosecutor and if it<82><84>s going to be the case, in front of a judge as an absolutely normal citizen,<82><9d> he said.

Ponta vowed that, if he was found guilty on those charges, he would resign.

<82><93>If I am declared guilty by a judge, of course. That<82><84>s absolutely clear,<82><9d> he said. But he added that he could prove his innocence in court, and had not yet been asked to give his version of events.

<82><93>I did have all the checks by the fiscal authorities and the national integrity agency and both said everything was perfectly legal so I will just present all these papers to the prosecutor. I will give all the explanations, and I<82><84>m sure everything will be clear then.<82><9d>

The DNA confirmed that it was still pursuing the investigations into Ponta<82><84>s role in the tax evasion case. That case will be passed to an investigating magistrate who will decide whether it should go to court.

Meanwhile, Ponta said he stuck by his earlier call for the law to be changed to lift the immunity of MPs in cases of corruption. That did not apply to him, he insisted, as the allegations against him while prime minister involved alleged conflict of interest rather than corruption.

He also said he did not support legislative changes being considered in parliament to limit the power of state prosecutors, arguing that judicial self-policing was the answer to occasional over-zealous prosecutions.

<82><93>I don<82><84>t think the problem is the legislation,<82><9d> he said. <82><93>I just think we should find a mechanism that avoids abuses and mistakes.<82><9d>

Laura Stefan, an anti-corruption expert at the Expert Forum, a Bucharest thinktank, expressed scepticism over Ponta<82><84>s claims he was not behind the legislative push to curtail the DNA<82><84>s powers.

<82><93>He is the leader of the ruling party pushing for the changes. So how can he be against them when his party is pushing for them <82><80><9c> he just showed us all how he holds his party with a very strong grip,<82><9d> she said.

<82> This article was amended on 11 June 2015. An earlier version described President Klaus Iohannis as the leader of the opposition National Liberal party. Alina Gorghiu took over that post in December 2014.

webTitle: Romanian prosecutors arrest local mayor over Bucharest nightclub fire
trailText: Mayor of district where 41 people died in blaze at Colectif club gave venue permit despite lack of firefighter’s authorisation
headline: Romanian prosecutors arrest local mayor over Bucharest nightclub fire
standfirst: Mayor of district where 41 people died in blaze at Colectif club gave venue permit despite lack of firefighter’s authorisation
body:
Romanian anti-corruption prosecutors have arrested a former mayor over a nightclub fire that killed 41 people in Bucharest.

Cristian Popescu Piedone resigned as the mayor of the Bucharest district where the Colectiv club is located following mass protests.

Prosecutors said on Saturday that there was evidence Popescu had granted a permit for the club despite it not being authorised by firefighters.

<82><93>Given that several <82> events took place <82> in broadly unsafe public conditions, the lives, health and physical integrity of the audience and staff were permanently put in danger,<82><9d> the prosecutors said in a statement.

About 20,000 people held a demonstration in Bucharest on Tuesday evening, calling for the resignation of Popescu, the prime minister, Victor Ponta, and the interior minister, Gabriel Oprea. Ponta, his government and Popescu resigned the next day.

Another nine people died on Saturday from the injuries they sustained in the fire, bringing the death total to 41. Two died in the Netherlands, where they had been transported for specialist treatment.

The club<82><84>s three owners were arrested on 2 November. City hall clerks and the owners of the company that installed the fireworks that caused the fire are also under investigation.

The fire has prompted an outpouring of community support, with people donating money and blood, and volunteers taking food and drink to hospitals for medical staff and victims<82><84> families.

The interim prime minister, Sorin C<83>mpeanu said 107 people were still in hospital, 48 of them in a serious or critical condition.

The fire broke out last Friday night at a concert at the Colectiv, when fireworks set insulation foam alight and triggered a stampede towards the venue<82><84>s only exit. Many of the 400 people in the audience were trapped inside.

Tens of thousands of people subsequently took to the streets across Romania, angry at a public administration widely seen as corrupt. Protests continued even after the cabinet resigned.

Consultations over a new Romanian prime minister will resume next week after initial talks with political and civil society leaders yielded no candidate, the country<82><84>s president, Klaus Iohannis, said.

webTitle: Romanian side play away after mayor uses stadium for daughters wedding
trailText: The Romania league side Gilortul Targu Carbunesti were forced to play a home match 24 miles away after the mayor took over their stadium to host his daughter’s wedding
headline: Romanian side play away after mayor uses stadium for daughter’s wedding
standfirst:
• Gilortul Targu Carbunesti move fixture 24 miles from town
• Small town short of suitable restaurants for 1,000 guests
body:
Acts of God, foul weather and even stadium closures are often responsible for teams having to play their home games in a rival stadium but for Gilortul Targu Carbunesti it was an insurmountable problem with local politics that forced them to seek an alternative venue for their Romanian league match.

According to reports in the Romanian press, the mayor of Targu Carbunesti in southern Romania (population 8,731) decided the home stadium was the only appropriate venue for his daughter<82><84>s wedding, meaning the local team<82><84>s tier four fixture had to be rescheduled for the village of Stoina, 24 miles away.

The Romanian newspaper Libertatea reported that being such a small town, Targu Carbunesti was short of suitable restaurants to accommodate the mayor<82><84>s 1,000 guests.

The only obvious alternative was to lay down a red carpet in the football ground, erect a marquee and fill it with tables and chandeliers, forcing the football team to find an alternative patch of uncluttered turf.

The only obvious alternative was to lay down a red carpet in the football ground, erect a marquee and fill it with tables and chandeliers, forcing the football team to find an alternative patch of uncluttered turf.

webTitle: British army brigadier says he is a scapegoat in Romanian forest scandal
trailText: High-ranking official stands accused of colluding with criminals to illegally claim 43,000 hectares of forest land owned by the state
headline: British army brigadier says he is a scapegoat in Romanian forest scandal
standfirst: High-ranking official stands accused of colluding with criminals to illegally claim 43,000 hectares of forest land owned by the state
body:
A high-ranking British army official has said he is an innocent scapegoat in a scandal over an alleged illegal land grab of a huge tract of Romanian forest.

In a court hearing reported by Romanian media last week, Christopher Ghika, the commanding officer of the 1st battalion of the Irish Guards, was accused of working with an organised crime group to illegally claim 43,000 hectares (106,210 acres) of state owned forest.

A distant descendent of a Romanian prince, brigadier Ghika was said to have agreed to exaggerate his inheritance rights so as to claim the forest through Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s restitution process <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the process by which land that was taken by the communist state in the 1940s is returned to former owners.

According to press reports, a tape recording revealed a conversation between him and a man called Gheorghe Paltin Sturdza, a Romanian businessman accused of restitution crimes. The recording <83><82><82><82><80><9c> which was given as evidence by Sturdza himself <83><82><82><82><80><9c> was presented in court by a prosecutor who suggested it demonstrated that Ghika and Sturdza had colluded to issue false declarations which would entitle them to the ownership of the forest area.

A document said to be Sturdza<83><82><82><82><84>s notes of the meeting was also presented in court, and was said to show that Ghika had promised to write a false declaration <83><82><82><82><80><9c> translated by the Romanian media as a will <83><82><82><82><80><9c> which Ghika would be send to Sturdza along with his personal legal papers.

Following a two-year investigation by Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s National Anticorruption Directorate (DNA), investigators claim Sturdza has assembled a network of top Romanian politicians, judges and businessmen to carry out the restitution scam. They say that, assisted by a lawyer and member of Romanian parliament called Ioan Adam, the network spent millions of euros buying off influential figures and pushing Sturdza<83><82><82><82><84>s claim for the forest through law courts.

Last year, investigators said, with the deal seemingly secured, Sturdza signed a contract to sell the land for <83><82><80><9a><82>140m (<83><80><9a><82>105m) to German renewable energy and logging company Prokon.

According to Romanian press reports, Ghika is alleged to be a central part of this plan. Ghika<83><82><82><82><84>s inheritance entitles him to a small part of the disputed forest area. False declarations exaggerating the amount of land Ghika is entitled to would smooth the restitution process for Sturdza, who could push the claim through court in Ghika<83><82><82><82><84>s name.

Ghika said he has been made a scapegoat by Sturdza. Talking over the phone from the Fort Riley army base in Kansas, US, Ghika told the Guardian: <83><82><82><82><93>I am aware of the allegations being made by Sturdza. These are completely untrue. Sturdza tape-recorded our meeting and has then twisted the words in it. We discussed restitution issues but we came to no agreement. I have entered into no agreement then or since.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Since 1990, over 3m hectares of forest in Romania has been returned to purported former owners through the restitution process. An audit last year by the Romanian court of accounts claimed that 20% of these reclamations were illegal <83><82><82><82><80><9c> a total of 600,000 hectares. Prime minister Victor Ponta has referred to a <83><82><82><82><93>restitution mafia<83><82><82><82><9d>, a wide spread network of well-connected businessmen and politicians who have exploited corruption in the law courts to claim billions of euros of land and forest in the last two decades.

In the 25 years since the end of communism, Romania has lost 370,000 hectares of forest <83><82><82><82><80><9c> including some of Europe<83><82><82><82><84>s last areas of virgin forest <83><82><82><82><80><9c> to illegal deforestation, according to a report last year by the Romanian Court of Accounts.

Gabriel Paun, founder of the environmental crime investigation NGO Agent Green, says this is linked directly to the restitution process. <83><82><82><82><93>Restitution is rigged so that the forest goes to the big players in Romania. It is then sold or leased immediately to international logging companies, who clear cut huge areas without any respect for Romanian or European law,<83><82><82><82><9d><83><82><82><82><84> he says. <83><82><82><82><93>It<83><82><82><82><84>s organised crime on the biggest scale<83><82><82><82><9d>.

webTitle: Romanian PM faces calls to step down over corruption allegations
trailText: Victor Ponta named as suspect in crimes including forgery, money-laundering, conflict of interest and tax evasion
headline: Romanian PM faces calls to step down over corruption allegations
standfirst: Victor Ponta named as suspect in crimes including forgery, money-laundering, conflict of interest and tax evasion
body:
Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s prime minister is under pressure to resign after being indicted for forgery, tax evasion, and money laundering as part of a far-reaching anti-corruption drive by state prosecutors.

Victor Ponta, who has been prime minister since 2012, has refused to resign, saying only parliament could dismiss him, but the president, Klaus Iohannis, called for him to step down yesterday. Iohannis, who beat Ponta in presidential elections in November, said it was <83><82><82><82><93>an impossible situation for Romania<83><82><82><82><9d>.

Parliament is due to vote next week on whether or not to lift Ponta<83><82><82><82><84>s immunity from prosecution. If it votes to shield him, political observers predict it will trigger a constitutional crisis, pitting prime minister and parliament against the president and the judiciary.

Ponta was called in to the National Anticorruption Directorate (DNA) in Bucharest yesterday, to be presented with an extensive charge sheet. He is accused of filing forged invoices for a total of $45,000 for work he did not do in 2007 and 2008, when he was a lawyer.

The DNA statement also said that an investigation would continue into alleged conflict of interest during Ponta<83><82><82><82><84>s term as prime minister, for making his closest business associate a minister. The DNA said there was <83><82><82><82><93>reasonable suspicion<83><82><82><82><9d> of wrongdoing and said it would ask parliament to approve a criminal investigation into Ponti on those charges.

Victor Ponta, who has been prime minister since 2012, has refused to resign, saying only parliament could dismiss him, but the president, Klaus Iohannis, called for him to step down yesterday. Iohannis, who beat Ponta in presidential elections in November, said it was an impossible situation for Romania. Parliament is due to vote next week on whether or not to lift Pontas immunity from prosecution. If it votes to shield him, political observers predict it will trigger a constitutional crisis, pitting prime minister and parliament against the president and the judiciary. Ponta was called in to the National Anticorruption Directorate (DNA) in Bucharest yesterday, to be presented with an extensive charge sheet. He is accused of filing forged invoices for a total of $45,000 for work he did not do in 2007 and 2008, when he was a lawyer.  The DNA statement also said that an investigation would continue into alleged conflict of interest during Pontas term as prime minister, for making his closest business associate a minister. The DNA said there was reasonable suspicion of wrongdoing and said it would ask parliament to approve a criminal investigation into Ponti on those charges.

webTitle: UK-based Romanian author's first novel in English becomes a sensation
trailText: Murder mystery The Book of Mirrors, snapped up by publishers in 18 countries, is expected to make Eugene Chirovici a seven-figure sum
headline: UK-based Romanian author's first novel in English becomes a sensation
standfirst: Murder mystery The Book of Mirrors, snapped up by publishers in 18 countries, is expected to make Eugene Chirovici a seven-figure sum
body:
He came to live in Britain only three years ago, now Eugene Chirovici<83><82><82><82><84>s first attempt at writing a novel in English has become a global publishing phenomenon.

The Romanian author<83><82><82><82><84>s murder mystery, The Book of Mirrors, has been snapped up by publishers in 23 countries <83><82><82><82><80><9c> with auctions having involved up to 11 publishers in each territory. Smaller countries such as Iceland, which tend to wait until an untested English-language book has proved itself in the UK and US, have also bought the novel before its publication in 2017.

Chirovici, 51, who lives in Reading, wrote 10 <83><82><82><82><93>literary mystery<83><82><82><82><9d> novels in Romania over the past two decades, but the market was too small for him to live off his books and he worked as a journalist. Now he is expected to make a seven-figure sum from the publishing deals alone.

He said: <83><82><82><82><93>I<83><82><82><82><84>m not sure I realise what<83><82><82><82><84>s happening. It is very overwhelming and unexpected.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Related: The top 10 Agatha Christie mysteries

The author, who writes as EO Chirovici, was signed up by the first British agency he tried, Peters Fraser and Dunlop (PFD), after he was rejected by six US agents. Recalling their rejection letters, Chirovici said: <83><82><82><82><93>They didn<83><82><82><82><84>t explain why.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Rachel Mills, of PFD, described The Book of Mirrors as <83><82><82><82><93>a really well-plotted murder mystery<83><82><82><82><9d>. She added: <83><82><82><82><93>It is such an incredible novel, so sophisticated. You would never know it was written by someone whose first language wasn<83><82><82><82><84>t English.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Marilia Savvides, who has only just become an agent at PFD, had fallen in love with it immediately and signed him up as her first author five weeks ago.

PFD began submitting the manuscript worldwide three weeks ago. An Italian publisher was in touch within three hours, while 11 German publishing houses fought for it. Nine wanted it in France and six in the UK, where it has been acquired by Century, an imprint of Penguin Random House.

In a statement, Century<83><82><82><82><84>s editor, Francesca Pathak, described the book as a cross between Donna Tartt<83><82><82><82><84>s The Secret History and Carlos Ruiz Zaf<83><92><82>n<83><82><82><82><84>s The Shadow of the Wind. She said: <83><82><82><82><93>[It] is a truly brilliant book which grabbed me from the first page. This is going to be a huge debut launch for us.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Set in the present day, Chirovici<83><82><82><82><84>s novel is a story about the murder of a charismatic professor at Princeton University in the late 1980s. It begins with a New York literary agent receiving a partial manuscript called The Book of Mirrors in which the author <83><82><82><82><80><9c> a student at Princeton at the time of the murder <83><82><82><82><80><9c> hints at a confession or a revelation about who committed the murder.

The writer dies before the literary agent has a chance to find out more, sparking a quest to solve the crime. Mills said: <83><82><82><82><93>The opening is really good. There<83><82><82><82><84>s a letter that comes with the manuscript ... saying this manuscript is going to tell you what really happened.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Chirovici said that his literary inspirations are <83><82><82><82><93>very classical<83><82><82><82><9d>, and include Ernest Hemingway, John Steinbeck and William Golding.

He came to Britain because his son was studying at Cardiff University and his wife had a great job offer as a financial analyst. <83><82><82><82><93>My intention was to become a full-time writer,<83><82><82><82><9d> he said.

webTitle: Sculpture at heart of Romanian identity waits to hear her fate
trailText: Owners have to offer the state first refusal before selling the Wisdom of the Earth by Constantin BrÃ¢ncuÈi â but they may be in for a long wait
headline: Sculpture at heart of Romanian identity waits to hear her fate
standfirst: Owners have to offer the state first refusal before selling the Wisdom of the Earth by Constantin BrÃ¢ncuÈi â but they may be in for a long wait
body:
The woman, carved from limestone, sits with her arms resting on her pulled-up legs and looks enigmatically ahead. She is regarded as one of Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s finest modernist artworks, yet the Bucharest government<83><82><82><82><84>s refusal to say whether it wants to buy her has left the <83><82><80><9a><82>20m (<83><80><9a><82>15m) sculpture in a murky legal limbo, and its owners unable to sell.

The statue, The Wisdom of the Earth by Constantin Br<83><92><82>ncu<83><86><82><84>i, has a history that reflects the tumult in its creator<83><82><82><82><84>s native land. First sold in 1911, it was confiscated by the communists in 1957 and became the subject of a lengthy legal battle after the fall of the dictator Nicolae Ceau<83><86><82><84>escu, ending in 2008 with it returned to the family of its original owner.

The latest instalment began in September 2014 when the family announced it was putting Br<83><92><82>ncu<83><86><82><84>i<83><82><82><82><84>s statue, his most celebrated work still in Romania, up for sale.

As an artwork considered a national treasure, Romania has a right of first refusal should it wish to keep the Br<83><92><82>ncu<83><86><82><84>i out the hands of a foreign gallery or collector. But by failing to officially respond or enter into meaningful negotiations, those involved in the sale say the Romanian state has in effect blocked the legal owners from selling to anyone else.

International galleries such as the Tate Modern, which already owns four Br<83><92><82>ncu<83><86><82><84>i sculptures and could be one potential destination, are unlikely to push ahead while legal uncertainties exist.

<83><82><82><82><93>If you want to sell a work of art that is a national treasure, the state has a pre-emption right to buy, but it must give an answer within 30 days of notification,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Bogdan Grabowski, the lawyer acting for the Romascu family, the sculpture<83><82><82><82><84>s owners. <83><82><82><82><93>Until now the state hasn<83><82><82><82><84>t proposed a certain sum or asserted that it is willing to take its pre-emption rights.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Br<83><92><82>ncu<83><86><82><84>i, who spent much of his life living in Paris, is considered Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s most important artist, and his sculptures change hands for up to <83><82><80><9a><82>26m. The Wisdom of the Earth is considered one of his defining works.

<83><82><82><82><93>The truth is that it is an iconic sculpture for Romanians; it<83><82><82><82><84>s an iconic image that is present in all the books about our national identity. The state used it a lot in its cultural propaganda and transformed it into an icon of the Romanian soul,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Alexandru Baldea, managing partner of Artmark, the Romanian auction house charged with selling the piece.

<83><82><82><82><93>Legally we<83><82><82><82><84>re allowed to sell it. But as a matter of fact we cannot sell it. Basically we are obliged to wait for an official response from the state.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The challenges surrounding first the ownership and now the sale of The Wisdom of the Earth underscore the difficult situation in Romania in relation to the many works of art confiscated by the former communist regime.

Roxana Theodorescu, the director of the National Museum of Art of Romania, told MPs in January that since 2000 the National Museum had returned 2,000 works of art to their original owners, and that in the near future it would be returning 253 more, with several hundred others under litigation.

<83><82><82><82><93>I invite you to visit our museum as quickly as possible because with the frequency we are returning works it is possible that in the near future you won<83><82><82><82><84>t have anything to look at,<83><82><82><82><9d> she told those present, according to Romanian media.

Many believe that the Romanian state simply doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t have the funds available to buy the sculpture, despite earlier comments made by the then minister of culture, Kelemen Hunor, who last September told Romanian media that if the price was right the authorities needed to find the money in the budget.

There have been suggestions that a public campaign within Romania could raise part of the money needed through donations. There is a precedent: one of Bucharest<83><82><82><82><84>s main concert halls was partly funded through a public offering in the 1880s.

Those involved in the attempted sale of The Wisdom of the Earth have little sympathy for the Romanian state.

<83><82><82><82><93>It is a similar situation with the works of art confiscated by the Nazis,<83><82><82><82><9d> claimed Grabowski, the family lawyer, who said the legal process behind reclaiming works of art confiscated during the communist period had been unnecessarily complex.

The Wisdom of the Earth was originally purchased in 1911 by Gheorghe Romascu, a Romanian engineer and art lover. His daughters began the process of trying to reclaim the sculpture shortly after the 1989 revolution but encountered a drawn-out legal process that only ended in 2008. One of the two daughters died in 2006. The surviving daughter is 92.

<83><82><82><82><93>She is expecting at any time that the state will cause more problems. She would prefer it to be sold overseas,<83><82><82><82><9d> Grabowski said.

The Romanian ministry of culture did not respond to repeated interview requests for this article.

webTitle: Romanian ambassador bitter over C4s migrant series
trailText: The Romanians are Coming documentary incited âhatred and discriminationâ, say Bucharest MPs
headline: Romanian ambassador âbitterâ over C4âs migrant series
standfirst: The Romanians are Coming documentary incited âhatred and discriminationâ, say Bucharest MPs
body:
Channel 4<83><82><82><82><84>s documentary The Romanians Are Coming has sparked a diplomatic row, with the Romanian embassy expressing its <83><82><82><82><93>bitterness and disappointment<83><82><82><82><9d> over the programme.

Ion Jinga, the Romanian ambassador in London, has written to the producers of the three-part series accusing them of reinforcing negative stereotypes. Meanwhile three members of the Romanian parliament have written to the British ambassador in Bucharest to claim that the channel was inciting hatred and discrimination.

The MPs<83><82><82><82><84> letter, seen by the Observer, adds: <83><82><82><82><93>We kindly ask you to consider what your reaction would be if TVR, the Romanian public television channel, would launch a campaign of denigration pointed towards the British citizens in our country, generalising cases of alcoholism and paedophilia displayed by some British citizens (cases we are sure you are aware of), and turning them into the general image of all British citizens in Romania. The documentary broadcast by Channel 4 does the exact same thing.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Channel 4 says the series <83><82><82><82><80><9c> which ended on Tuesday <83><82><82><82><80><9c> explored the lives of Romanians trying to make a new life in Britain, and sought the truth behind the headlines about immigration.

The first programme featured Alex, who lived in a car park next to Victoria station in London, and a Romany man who struggled to settle in Liverpool.

The second and third episodes also examined the poverty of Romania, where the richest 10% would be among the poorest 10% in the UK. The narrator says: <83><82><82><82><93>When you live in a place as poor as this, then where can you find hope?<83><82><82><82><9d> One immigrant coming to the UK says to camera: <83><82><82><82><93>I am sure the English will throw us a rope.<83><82><82><82><9d>

A review in this newspaper described the programme as <83><82><82><82><93>an intelligent programme likely to dispel prejudices<83><82><82><82><9d>, and it has been widely applauded for its humanity. However the response from some Romanians in the UK has been far less complimentary, with a silent protest recently held by students outside C4<83><82><82><82><84>s offices.

The ambassador complained that the programme has <83><82><82><82><93>ignored the fact that, in their overwhelming majority, Romanians living in Britain are well integrated into the local society<83><82><82><82><9d>. He further claims that there are more than 4,000 Romanian doctors and nurses in Britain.

Immigration is likely to be one of the major issues during the general election campaign.

Last week an analysis from Oxford University reported that the migrant population of England had risen by 565,000 since 2011, with two-thirds coming from the EU.

The figures suggest the foreign-born population of every local authority in the country may have risen.

The Migration Observatory unit said it came up with the projections because similar official data will not be available before the general election.

On 1 January 2014, Bulgarians and Romanians gained the same rights to work in the UK as other EU citizens.

A spokesman for C4 said: <83><82><82><82><93>This sensitively handled series confronts, head on, many of the stereotypes and widely held prejudices about Romanians coming to the UK by providing an honest account of the experience of different individuals attempting to make a life in Britain.

<83><82><82><82><93>The series makes it clear, throughout, that the majority of Romanians in the UK are professionals with guaranteed jobs who pay their taxes and contribute to the British economy.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The MPs letter, seen by the Observer, adds: We kindly ask you to consider what your reaction would be if TVR, the Romanian public television channel, would launch a campaign of denigration pointed towards the British citizens in our country, generalising cases of alcoholism and paedophilia displayed by some British citizens (cases we are sure you are aware of), and turning them into the general image of all British citizens in Romania. webTitle: Dozens killed in fireworks accident at Bucharest nightclub
trailText: At least 27 people died and another 180 were injured after pyrotechnic display sparked blaze during concert at Colectiv venue in Romanian capital
headline: Dozens killed in fireworks accident at Bucharest nightclub
standfirst: At least 27 people died and another 180 were injured after pyrotechnic display sparked blaze during concert at Colectiv venue in Romanian capital
byline: Kit Gillet  in Bucharest and agencies
body:
A fire sparked by stage pyrotechnics at a nightclub in the centre of Bucharest has left at least 27 people dead and 180 injured.

There were 300 to 400 people in the Colectiv Club in the Romanian capital on Friday night. Some remained unaccounted for on Saturday morning.

According to one witness speaking to Romanian media, a fireworks display around the stage set nearby objects alight. Another witness told Reuters that a pillar and the club<83><82><82><82><84>s ceiling caught fire, then there was an explosion and heavy smoke.

<83><82><82><82><93>There was a stampede of people running out of the club,<83><82><82><82><9d> a man who escaped without shoes told Reuters.

A young woman who sustained minor injuries described the club bursting into flames. <83><82><82><82><93>In five seconds the whole ceiling was all on fire. In the next three we rushed to a single door,<83><82><82><82><9d> she told television station Antena 3.

The victims were admitted to 10 hospitals in Bucharest, said Raed Arafat, the head of emergency response at the interior ministry.

<83><82><82><82><93>The situation is slowly stabilising ... we have many people with burns, intoxicated with smoke and people squashed,<83><82><82><82><9d> he said.

Arafat, who was visiting each of the hospitals to console families and check on the situation, told the Guardian: <83><82><82><82><93>This incident is unprecedented in Romania. All of the wounded have now been identified, and those who died are being examined by the medical examiners.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Media reported that clubgoers initially thought the flames were part of the show and did not immediately react.

Victor Ionescu, who was at the club with his girlfriend, told Antena 3 TV by telephone that there were huge flames.

<83><82><82><82><93>People were fainting, they were fainting from the smoke. It was total chaos, people were trampling on each other,<83><82><82><82><9d> he said.

A young man filmed by Antena 3 said that fire engulfed clubgoers, burning their skin and hair.

Some people were initially treated on the streets outside and others taken to hospitals. Two of the band playing on stage were said to be in a critical condition.

Early on Saturday morning at one of the main hospitals, the Universitar, crowds of poeple waited for news about friends and loved ones. Inside orderlies call the names of families to come forward.

A man in his mid-20s waiting at the hospital told the Guardian: <83><82><82><82><93>I found out two of my colleagues were there tonight. They are doing badly. They are currently in intensive care, with severe burns.

<83><82><82><82><93>Doctors keep giving numbers of how badly burnt they are but it is hard to tell. I wasn<83><82><82><82><84>t there but live nearby and heard the fire trucks and ambulances. I checked with my friends and colleagues to make sure everyone was all right and found out about the two.

<83><82><82><82><93>Around 10 of us have come down to the hospital. The families have seen them but now we won<83><82><82><82><84>t know more until the morning. Tomorrow is probably going to be the hardest day.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Romanian media reported that a code red was declared, with off-duty doctors and nurses at nearby hospitals being called in to help deal with the emergency.

Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s health minister, Nicolae B<83><80><9e><82><92>nicioiu, said that <83><82><82><82><93>every effort is being made to save those who can be saved. The victims are being transported to emergency hospitals. Doctors and nurses have been called in from home, ventilators have been redistributed from other hospitals.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Many of the victims did not have identification on them. The government set up a hotline for people who might have known someone at the club.

President Klaus Iohannis said he was shocked by the deaths. <83><82><82><82><93>It is a very sad day for all of us, for our nation and for me personally,<83><82><82><82><9d> he said in a statement published online. <83><82><82><82><93>I am deeply grieved by the tragic events that happened this evening.

<83><82><82><82><93>I assure the families affected by this terrible event of the full support of those involved in the rescue operations and I ask them to trust that the responsible institutions are doing their best to limit the effects of the catastrophe. I urge you all to stand together by the grieving families and prove our solidarity and compassion.<83><82><82><82><9d>

One line of inquiry being pursued by investigators, according to local media, was whether the club had the necessary fire safety permits.

Romania<83><82><82><82><84>s interior minister, Gabriel Oprea, went to the nightclub, along with emergency services. An emergency meeting of cabinet ministers was set for early on Saturday.

The British Foreign Office said it was not aware of any Britons involved in the incident.

Several major nightclub fires have been blamed on pyrotechnics igniting foam used for soundproofing, including The Station nightclub fire in the US that killed 100 people in West Warwick, Rhode Island, in 2003 and the Kiss nightclub fire in Brazil, which killed 242 people in the university town of Santa Maria in 2013.

Romanias health minister, Nicolae Bnicioiu, said that every effort is being made to save those who can be saved. The victims are being transported to emergency hospitals. Doctors and nurses have been called in from home, ventilators have been redistributed from other hospitals. Many of the victims did not have identification on them. The government set up a hotline for people who might have known someone at the club. President Klaus Iohannis said he was shocked by the deaths. It is a very sad day for all of us, for our nation and for me personally, he said in a statement published online. I am deeply grieved by the tragic events that happened this evening. I assure the families affected by this terrible event of the full support of those involved in the rescue operations and I ask them to trust that the responsible institutions are doing their best to limit the effects of the catastrophe. I urge you all to stand together by the grieving families and prove our solidarity and compassion. One line of inquiry being pursued by investigators, according to local media, was whether the club had the necessary fire safety permits. Romanias interior minister, Gabriel Oprea, went to the nightclub, along with emergency services. An emergency meeting of cabinet ministers was set for early on Saturday. The British Foreign Office said it was not aware of any Britons involved in the incident. Several major nightclub fires have been blamed on pyrotechnics igniting foam used for soundproofing, including The Station nightclub fire in the US that killed 100 people in West Warwick, Rhode Island, in 2003 and the Kiss nightclub fire in Brazil, which killed 242 people in the university town of Santa Maria in 2013.

webTitle: How has Victor Spirescu  Romanian immigrant No 1   got on in the UK?
trailText: He arrived at Luton airport a year ago after a change in EU visa regulations, to be met by the press â and some apocalyptic warnings from Nigel Farage
headline: How has Victor Spirescu â Romanian immigrant No 1 â got on in the UK?
standfirst: He arrived at Luton airport a year ago after a change in EU visa regulations, to be met by the press â and some apocalyptic warnings from Nigel Farage
body:
Age: 30.

Appearance: Bemused.

I<83><82><82><82><84>m bemused, too. Who is he? He was the first migrant to arrive here after EU visa restrictions on Romanians and Bulgarians were lifted last year.

Oh, yes! The first of the waves that Nigel Farage and others promised, of benefit-claiming East Europeans who would engulf this green and pleasant land. Apr<83><92><82>s him, the deluge! It was feared/politically useful to pretend they would be seeking to suckle at the bounteous teat of Britain<83><82><82><82><84>s social security system. Though it turned out that their immigration numbers actually fell after the rule change.

Whatevs. There was an advert in the Daily Telegraph about them all being criminals. Placed by Nigel Farage.

Yes, so I knew it was true. He has a face you can<83><82><82><82><84>t help but trust. The ad said that 7% of all crime in the EU was carried out by Romanian gangs. 7%! No wonder he said people were right to be concerned if a group of Romanians moved in next door <83><82><82><82><80><9c> imagine having only an 93% chance of not being killed by them in the night! Would it help if I told you that it was all crap?

No. Tell me, how much has Spirescu managed to drain from us over the past year? He left his first job, carwashing in Biggleswade, after a day ...

Aha! To float luxuriously on a sea of universal credit and housing benefit, I presume? No, because media attention made it impossible for him to stay. He went to London to work on building sites instead and now makes about <83><80><9a><82>80 a day.

Oh. Well, I bet he<83><82><82><82><84>s planning to milk the system at some stage. He<83><82><82><82><84>s planning to go home, actually.

Why? What<83><82><82><82><84>s wrong with here? Is his wallet too small for his 50s? Are all our diamond shoes too tight? <83><82><82><82><93>I miss my village, my life in Romania. It<83><82><82><82><84>s all right but I come here to make some money and then I<83><82><82><82><84>ll go back. I don<83><82><82><82><84>t want to live for ever here.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Unbelievable! He comes over here, takes a job that someone else could have had ... but for some reason wasn<83><82><82><82><84>t taking ...

And then doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t even have the courtesy to stay! He<83><82><82><82><84>d rather go home! To a country full of chickens and vampires! Yes. There<83><82><82><82><84>s just no pleasing some people, is there?

Do say: <83><82><82><82><93>Home is where the heart is.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Don<83><82><82><82><84>t say: <83><82><82><82><93>Your home appears to be where the semi-electable bigots are.<83><82><82><82><9d>

webTitle: Supporting deafblind children in Romania
trailText: Cristiana Salomie, director of Sense International Romania, on how her typical day at work unfolds
headline: Supporting deafblind children in Romania
standfirst:
Cristiana Salomie, director of Sense International Romania, on how her typical day at work unfolds

• More from our international hub
body:
I've always been an early riser and am usually up and about before 6am. I start the day by watering my house plants and often squeeze in a swim or a trip to the gym before work. Doing this in the morning helps my energy levels and makes my whole day better. Thankfully I only live a 10 minute stroll away from my office in central Bucharest.

I've been the director of Sense International Romania since 2001, when the charity first established a presence here. We work across Romania in partnership with maternity units, schools and hospitals to identify deafblind children and support them and their families.

I started my career as an English teacher and did this for 20 years. In the weeks following the revolution here in 1989 I met representatives from the British Red Cross who came to bring aid to the orphanages that had hit the headlines around the world. I started volunteering for the charity and then went on to work with them, supporting children in the orphanages.

It wasn't long before we came across huge numbers of children with both sight and hearing problems. We knew that these children needed specialist support and contacted Sense International in London for help. Fast forward to the present day and Sense International Romania now employs six full time staff and is the country's leading organisation in supporting deafblind people.

When I arrive at work my day begins by going through my emails and replying to anything urgent. I check with my team and find out what needs to be prioritised that day. An important part of our work is a screening programme to identify deafblind children at birth and ensure that they receive the support they need straight away. This might be as simple as providing assistive devices such as glasses and hearing aids or more complex such as physiotherapy. Often I will spend a morning liaising with neo-natal units who are responsible for identifying deafblind babies and discuss staff training needs.

Understanding the impact of both sight and hearing loss is important for staff and they also need to be able to prepare parents for the next steps for their child. Explaining how a deafblind child will learn to communicate is key, and we have to train staff to be able to answer questions about sign language and understand tactile communication for children with more complex needs.

Most of the time I grab lunch at my desk and take a few minutes to catch up with the news online. In the afternoon I often have a chance to get out the office and I try to regularly visit programmes we are running with partner organisations.

Working with the government and decision makers is an important part of my role and I try to keep in regular contact. Getting to know people at the ministry of education, child welfare department and health officials makes my job a lot easier and means that I can ask for support when we need it. When I first started out we convinced the Romanian government that deafblind children can be educated <82><80><9c> by initially setting up two deafblind special education units and demonstrating effective teaching methods. We now work in partnership with the education ministry, supporting their 42 specialist education units across the country through training teachers to understand the impacts of dual sensory loss.

Being part of Sense International means that I work with colleagues in the UK and around the world. Although our experiences are radically different in many ways, deafblindness wherever you live has some common characteristics. Supporting children to develop communication skills and ensuring access to an appropriate education are fairly universal. We are also part of Deafblind International, a network of organisations from around the world who specialise in deafblindness. In 2015 we will be hosting a conference for specialists from around the world to come together and share learning on how best to support deafblind people. We are really looking forward to hosting the conference in Bucharest but it is a lot of work. Hence the last part of my day can be Skype calls with colleagues overseas and tracking down experts in health, social care and education to take part in the conference.

When I finish work I meet friends, head out for dinner or to the cinema. My work is extremely challenging but I'm very proud of how far we've come. When I first started this job we were often told "there are no deafblind children in Romania" and many people did not want to acknowledge the needs of disabled children. But this has changed and although we still have a long way to go, I am confident that we are making good progress.

If you would like to feature in our Day in the Life series, or know someone who would, email socialcare@theguardian.com

webTitle: Romania have Satan on their side against arch rivals Hungary | Jonathan Wilson
trailText: Jonathan Wilson: Romania’s ultras promise a devilish atmosphere for the Euro 2016 qualifier against Hungary to match coach Victor Piturca’s nickname
headline: Romania have Satan on their side against arch rivals Hungary
standfirst: Bucharest’s ultras promise a devilish atmosphere for the Euro 2016 qualifier to match coach Victor Piturca’s nickname
body:
When the expected 2,800 Hungary fans arrive in Bucharest for their Euro 2016 qualifier against Romania on Saturday, they will be escorted directly to the stadium in an attempt to avoid the trouble that broke out when the sides met last year in a World Cup qualifier.

The stadium will be sold out, with tickets given by the Romanian football federation (FRF) to ultras from each of the major Bucharest teams. They have promised a ferocious atmosphere, which may or may not include a controversial new anthem composed for the qualifiers. It contains the line: <82><93>Let<82><84>s go at them, at their mothers,<82><9d> which apparently is not quite as offensive in Romanian as it sounds in English, but still prompted the former Romania international and manager Laszlo Boloni, who is of Hungarian descent, to comment that the people who wrote it must have been <82><93>of very, very low intellect<82><9d>.

The historical antipathy between the nations is understandable <82><80><9c> rooted in on-continuing Hungarian resentment that Transylvania, which had been part of Hungary, was given to Romania as part of the Treaty of Trianon after the first world war <82><80><9c> yet the notion of Hungarian fans as high-risk is, frankly, hard to square with the mood in Budapest in May, when I was among just over 3,000 who watched Hungary stumble to an unconvincing win over Albania in a friendly.

I<82><84>ve never known a crowd so apathetic, boredom palpable almost from the first whistle, the only real engagement coming when a Hungarian did something ludicrously bad <82><80><9c> a carefully placed pass out of play, an air shot, a sliced clearance <82><80><9c> which happened surprisingly often. The only goal was a late Tamas Priskin penalty that the former Watford and Ipswich forward had won with what appeared to be a dive.

That the travesty was played out in the Ferenc Puskas Stadium only made it worse: 60 years ago, Hungary lost a World Cup final they probably should have won and now, so absolute has been their collapse, their squad for Saturday<82><84>s game includes only three players who play in the top 10 leagues in Europe according to Uefa<82><84>s coefficient. And it is fair to say that even those three <82><80><9c> Hamburg<82><84>s Zoltan Stieber, Hoffenheim<82><84>s Adam Szalai and Dinamo Moscow<82><84>s Balazs Dzsudzsak <82><80><9c> would not have got anywhere near the Golden Squad of the 1950s. A 2-1 home defeat to Northern Ireland in their first qualifier hardly bodes well.

Romania, by contrast, started with a 1-0 win over Claudio Ranieri<82><84>s Greece and, while this squad are nowhere near as gifted as the team that reached the World Cup quarter-finals 20 years ago, they have realistic hopes of qualifying for their first major tournament since Euro 2008. That was their first appearance at a major tournament since Euro 2000. Linking those two qualifications and this campaign is one man: Satan <82>

An unnervingly macabre sight

The road is narrow, cut into the hillside, its surface stones and mud baked by the sun. On the way out of Craiova, we had passed the odd donkey-drawn cart and a couple of kids on battered old bikes, and then, when we had left the town centre far behind, there appeared on the horizon a smudge of dust. As we drew closer, it became apparent that it was a column of people, maybe 200 strong, at the head of which, sombrely swinging a thurible, strode a priest, dressed entirely in black. As we slowed and passed to one side, the procession opened out, and I saw, lying flat on his back on a low wooden trailer, another priest, huge, black-robed, grey-bearded and very obviously dead.

Given where I was headed, it was an unnervingly macabre sight. We went on to Dorobantia and specifically to the small cemetery that is dominated by a bronze statue outside of the tombs. It depicts a footballer, moustache and haircut dating him to the 1970s, left arm crooked across his chest, right arm straining backwards, as though to steady himself for a surge on to his right foot. Alongside the statue stands the tomb, the size of a small house, marked on one corner with a plaque reading <82><93>Ap. 20<82><9d> <82><80><9c> the number of the apartment in which he had lived in Craiova.

This is Florin Piturca, who was a well-respected striker for the second division side Drobeta-Turnu Severin when he died suddenly in December 1978, the evening after scoring in his side<82><84>s 2-1 victory over Metalul Bucharest.

His father, Maximilian, a local cobbler, was distraught, and spent what little money he had in establishing a lasting monument to his son. The night Florin was buried, Maximilian stayed in the tomb. He went on sleeping there every night until his death in 1994. <82><93>That was my husband<82><84>s house,<82><9d> Florin<82><84>s mother, Vasilica, said. <82><93>He worked every day, and every night he went to the cemetery to sleep by his son in the mausoleum.<82><9d> He is now buried alongside him.

Vasilica is certain her son died after being given performance-enhancing drugs; she believes he was used as a guinea pig before the stimulants were given to higher-profile players.

Florin<82><84>s cousin, Victor, was an even better footballer than he was. Victor won five Romanian league titles with Steaua, as well as the European Cup in 1986. Nicknamed Satan, he tends to wear black and his car registration number is 666. In club management, his record is modest <82><80><9c> just one league title won, and that back in 2001 with Steaua. But on each previous occasion he has managed them, Piturca has qualified Romania for a European Championship <82><80><9c> although following a disagreement with Gheorghe Hagi, he was sacked before Euro 2000.

Piturca has not ruled out Al Ittihad move

Promising as the Greece game was, Pituca may not make it to Euro 2016 either. He turned down an offer to take over at the Saudi club al-Ittihad last month, but seemingly only because they refused to pay his contract-release clause and he didn<82><84>t want to have to pay it himself. Piturca has made little attempt to hide the frostiness of his relationship with Razvan Burleanu, the 30-year-old who was elected president of the FRF in March, the day after the favourite to land the role, Gica Popescu, was convicted of money-laundering and tax evasion and sentenced to three years in jail. Piturca has not ruled out the al-Ittihad move, saying the door to negotiation is still open. Burleanu, for his part, says he has a Plan B should Piturca go.

He is there for now, though, and has created a stir by recalling to the team Lucian Sanmartean. He is 34 and hugely talented, but has been restricted to just seven caps largely because of his attitude. His return, though, has created great excitement, with overblown comparisons to the return of Hagi in 1999. He is likely to start as a creative midfielder, while the decision on who starts at centre-forward could also make waves. Ciprian Marica, the captain, is suspended after being sent off against Greece, meaning Piturca must choose between Bogdan Stancu, Raul Rusescu and Claudiu Keseru.

Keseru has been in tremendous form for Steaua this season, scoring six in one game against Pandurii and a hat-trick in the Europa League against Aalborg. He is also half-Hungarian. He doesn<82><84>t speak Hungarian, though, and has insisted he feels entirely Romanian.

Whether Hungarian fans, who on Wednesday released a logo proclaiming Bucharest to be <82><93>a Hungarian village<82><9d>, treat him like any other Romanian, though, remains to be seen. It promises to be feisty.

webTitle: Romania 2-0 Northern Ireland | Euro 2016 Group F qualifier match report
trailText: The defender Paul Papp scored both goals as Romania beat Northern Ireland 2-0 in their Euro 2016 Group F qualifier in Bucharest
headline: Paul Papp pops Northern Ireland’s bubble with late brace for Romania
standfirst: NA
byline: Julian Taylor at the National Arena
body:
Defeat in Bucharest <82><80><9c> but still far from downhearted. There remains a definite, positive pulse in this quietly determined Euro qualifying campaign for Northern Ireland even though there was a distinct gulf against a fluid Romania, who now top Group F.

Michael O<82><84>Neill<82><84>s side may have been edged off the summit after two superb goals from the defender Paul Papp in the latter stages but in the grand scheme of things the finals in France remain a realistic destination.

One has to go all the way back to October 1985 for the last time the Ulstermen played in the Romanian capital, when they smuggled a one-goal victory under the brutalist gaze of Nicolae Ceausescu<82><84>s communist regime. <82><93>We can be proud of our effort and commitment here,<82><9d> said O<82><84>Neill. <82><93>We can play better, no doubt about that, but we have to give credit to opponents who were excellent tonight. He declared: <82><93>For me, Northern Ireland were and still are a big surprise in this group. They are very organised and I<82><84>m sure they will record some more surprises before the end of the campaign.

<82><93>But we have made a major step towards the Euros. We have shaken off the pressure because we are the new leaders of the group.<82><9d> Northern Ireland<82><84>s own self-esteem remains high. Despite this setback there will be no room for navel gazing.

webTitle: Lynn Howells: Romania will surprise people at the Rugby World Cup
trailText: Bucharest Wolves start their European Rugby Challenge Cup campaign in Newcastle, but the primary aim of this scratch squad and their Welsh coach is to improve the national team
headline: Lynn Howells: Romania will surprise people at the Rugby World Cup
standfirst: Bucharest Wolves start their European Rugby Challenge Cup campaign in Newcastle, but the primary aim of this scratch squad and their Welsh coach is to improve the national team
body:
Lynn Howells whistles through his lips as he remembers his first day coaching Romania<82><84>s rugby players. <82><93>There was a metre and a half of snow on the pitch in Bucharest,<82><9d> he says. <82><93>And it was absolutely freezing! I tell you now, in Britain no player would have cleared that snow. But they just got on with it and trained as normal. I thought to myself: <82><9c>This is a good bunch of lads. I can do something here.<82><84><82><9d>

Two and a half years later, Howells<82><84> initial confidence has been reinforced by results. The Romanian national team won the 2012 and 2013 IRB Nations Cup and have qualified for next year<82><84>s Rugby World Cup, and the Bucharest Wolves <82><80><9c> whom he also coaches and who start their European Rugby Challenge Cup campaign in Newcastle on Friday <82><80><9c> were good enough to beat the Italian side Calvisano twice last season and run the Falcons and Brive close.

<82><93>We were in front against Newcastle until the last kick of the game,<82><9d> says Howells, who was Graham Henry<82><84>s assistant at Wales and has been a wandering minstrel ever since. <82><93>And we were also within three points of Brive. So you can see the progress we have made. When you start something and see it develop it<82><84>s exciting.<82><9d>

But Howells is a doughty realist. As he points out, the Wolves are a scratch squad, chosen from the eight professional sides in Romania<82><84>s domestic league. Their wages <82><80><9c> roughly <82>200 a month <82><80><9c> are tiny. And the task in this year<82><84>s Challenge Cup is far harder as there are no Italian teams in their group, just three thoroughbreds: Stade Fran<83>ais, Newport Gwent Dragons and Newcastle.

<82><93>You have to remember too that the Wolves are a development side,<82><9d> Howells says. <82><93>Our team is all Romania<82><80><98>based players and the primary aim is to identify players to improve the national team.<82><9d>

So far, so good: five Romanians play Top 14 rugby in France and the full-back Catalin Fercu has signed for Saracens. Even so, shooting for the knockout stages is not so much a stretch as <82><93>an impossibility<82><9d>, Howells says. Yet if the Bucharest winter strikes hard and early they may yet sink their teeth into a famous scalp.

<82><93>But the international team is a different story,<82><9d> he interjects. <82><93>We<82><84>ve recently beaten Tonga and Canada and I think we<82><84>ll surprise a few people at the World Cup. Our big goal is to win two games, which would mean automatic qualification for the 2019 competition <82><80><9c> that would be huge for Romania.<82><9d>

It won<82><84>t be easy: Romania start against France, then play Ireland before facing Canada and Italy. Howells is particularly looking forward to returning to Wembley for Romania<82><84>s game against Ireland <82><80><9c> his first visit since 1999, when a late Scott Gibbs try ripped the grand slam from England<82><84>s grasp.

<82><93>I remember Clive Woodward arrived before us and pinched the home dressing room, which should have been ours,<82><9d> he said with a chuckle. <82><93>That didn<82><84>t go down well with Graham Henry. And then in the tunnel Woodward went to the guy by the cup and said: <82><9c>You can put the white ribbons on that now.<82><84> It was unbelievable.<82><9d>

Has Woodward apologised for such arrogance? <82><93>Of course not <82><80><9c> but he doesn<82><84>t have to,<82><9d> he says. <82><93>My memory of that game was that we shouldn<82><84>t have been in it but we were given the opportunity and we took it.<82><9d>

The World Cup gives the emerging nations, teams such as Romania and Georgia, a place at the top table every four years but Howells says it is not enough. Though he praises the IRB for helping smaller nations, he says the gap between the haves and the rest will never inch closer when the tier-one countries award themselves most of the cash sloshing around the game.

One of Howells<82><84> solutions is to have promotion and relegation from the Six Nations. <82><93>There is already a Six Nations B and it would only be good for the game to have a yearly play-off between the worst team in the Six Nations and the winners of the B competition,<82><9d> he says. <82><93>We played in Georgia last year and we had a crowd of 62,000, so you can<82><84>t tell me there isn<82><84>t the demand.

<82><93>You can understand why the likes of Scotland and Italy don<82><84>t want anything to do with it as they get a huge amount of money from the IRB but the fact is they are not playing well. And, on a given day if everything went our way, we could beat them.<82><9d>

Meanwhile, those people who have bought tickets to see Romania at the Rugby World Cup <82><80><9c> what should they expect? <82><93>The level of the top players is good,<82><9d> Howells says. <82><93>The difficulty is that our best players are all forwards. The backs have some way to go, to be honest.

<82><93>People have to appreciate that we are going to grind our way to tries. We are not going to be New Zealand or Australia.<82><9d>
